TALK.START.PARA: —I present the tenth report of the Select Committee on Superannuation, entitled Super Complaints Tribunal, together with submissions received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate my tabling speech in Hansard, and an oral report of the committee's activities during the 1993 budget sittings, in fulfilment of the requirement that the committee report on the last day of the budget sittings.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the withdrawal of Senator Watson's amendment in the Committee stage of the passage of the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill, a referral to the Superannuation Committee was made. The Committee was required to inquire and report on the implications of the withdrawn amendment concerning section 14 of the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act.

The tenth Report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation has specifically examined the issues surrounding the operation of section 14 and 15 of the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act. In doing so the Committee has made four recommendations which are aimed at preventing any adverse consequences arising out of the uncertainty of the Tribunal's jurisdiction in relation to decisions of trustees, made prior to the commencement of the Act.

The report concerns the problem of double payments that might result from appeals to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. This problem has been explained fully in previous debates but briefly the problem is that where a trustee has made a payment to a beneficiary, and the Tribunal determines that another person is entitled to all or part of that benefit, a trustee might be required to pay the benefit twice.

It is the ramifications of this that has created the need for the Committee's tenth report. Where the trustee does not have the power to pay the second benefit ordered by the Tribunal, a serious blow to the confidence in the scheme as a whole to make payments, will be delivered. Members will feel that their funds may not end up benefiting themselves or those they desire, thereby playing on one of the major fears that consumers have about the administration of the superannuation fund.

There are additional problems facing trustees and members of funds which the Committee has identified. First, where the trustees are unable to recover the initial benefit payment, they themselves may become personally liable to make the second payment. Second, as this situation is totally unacceptable for the trustees, their subsequent action in response may be damaging to other beneficiaries of the fund. A fear expressed by the Committee is that there may be a postponement of all payments for the time up to the commencement of the Act on 1 July 1994.

However under section 15, the trustee can gain a degree of protection against the danger of a double payments problem. By giving adequate notice to all relevant parties of a proposed benefit payment the trustee excludes any such party from appealing to the Tribunal against this payment, unless they first object to the trustee within a prescribed period. This provision greatly reduces the danger of the trustee being required to pay a benefit twice. The critical point here is that it is not conclusive as to whether this protection will apply to trustees who have given notice prior to the commencement of the Act.

Currently, the only certain protection for trustees is to wait until the commencement of the Act. The danger is trustees may choose to postpone all further payments until this period has elapsed. Overwhelmingly, the view expressed by the superannuation lawyers, who submitted to the inquiry, was that this would indeed be the case. In the meantime beneficiaries that depend on the fund for their livelihood are left in limbo, receiving no benefits and subsequently suffering great hardship. It is for this reason that the Committee has recommended that both the Government and the Senate seek to clarify this position. It is the opinion of the Committee that the section 15 protection for trustees, which entails the giving of adequate notice, should apply to decisions made before and after the commencement of the Act. The result of this is that by giving adequate notice to all relevant parties, not only will the interested parties be clearly aware of their rights but also, objections must then be made within the prescribed period. The advantage of this, is that the risk of trustees being required to pay a benefit twice is substantially reduced. Also there will be no reason for the trustees to delay other benefit payments.

In order for trustees to give notice that complies with section 15, it will be necessary for them to do so within the `prescribed period'. The Committee recommends that the prescribed period in section 15(2)(a)(ii) should be 28 days. This will mean that subsequent to the death of a member, trustees will notify potential beneficiaries. If the Committee's recommendation is taken up, these potential beneficiaries will have 28 days to object to a proposed payment. If a person does not object within the prescribed period, they will not have an interest and will not be able to make a complaint to the Tribunal.

The Committee has concluded that the problem of double payments and the consequences that surround it will always exist. However, the adverse effects of this problem can be minimised. The Committee wishes to emphasise the ways in which trustees and beneficiaries can assist in ensuring that disputes such as these and all other superannuation disputes are kept to a minimum.

Of paramount importance is that trustees give notice to persons who may have an interest in a payment. It cannot be stressed strongly enough that trustees commence this procedure as soon as possible. Trustees should also ensure that fund members complete all the forms required to nominate beneficiaries. Fund members play an equally vital role in the process. By notifying their superannuation fund if their family circumstances change, members assist in minimising the possibility of dispute.

Finally, in examining these issues the Committee became aware of a dearth of relevant statistical data. The Committee has recommended that from its inception the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal establish procedures and structures to collect appropriate data on claims submitted to it by superannuation fund members.

It is hoped, that by following all of these recommendations the significant problems posed by the complaints process, specifically those of double payments, can be minimised if not wholly avoided. It is the aim of the Committee that through these processes all the interests involved can best be served.

Before completing this speech I would like to make a number of brief remarks about the work of the Committee during the Budget sittings, and its program for 1994, to satisfy the requirement that the committee report on the last day of the Budget sittings.

During the Budget 1993 sittings the Committee presented its 8th, 9th and 10th reports. I might also add that during the winter recess the committee presented its 6th and 7th reports to the President of the Senate. Without doubt the most important of these reports was the 9th which addressed the Superannuation Industry Supervision package of Bills. The work of the Committee in this inquiry was critical to the final shape of the legislation, and for this I place on record my appreciation of the efforts of my fellow Senators on the Committee.

If 1993 has been the year of consolidation in the super industry following the events of 1992, which included the introduction of the SGC, 1994 will, I believe, prove to be a year of metamorphosis. The Committee will be examining moving from 9—12 per cent levels of minimum superannuation contributions, allocated pensions and their interaction with the social security system as well as the question of whether super funds should be in the business of financing member housing purchases.
No doubt the super industry will watch closely the implementation of the new SIS provisions and the role of the prime regulator, the ISC, in that process.

Consumers will be interested in the work of the new disputes tribunal which will commence on 1 July 1994 and be closely monitored by this Committee. I expect that consumers will also be interested in the initiatives that the Government will take to ensure that women, part-time employees and those on low wages are able to maximise their superannuation assets.

I expect that the national stock of super fund assets will continue to grow and that in 12 months time it will approach the $200 billion mark. That of course will depend on a number of factors, not the least of which is the performance of the various financial markets.

I am confident that the Select Committee will continue its monitoring role advising the Senate on a range of superannuation policy-related matters. If past practice is any guide I expect the Committee to be at the cutting edge of public debate on retirement incomes policy.

So, in conclusion, I commend the report to the Senate and I thank Committee members, Senators John Watson (who, through illness, is unable to present this report), Bruce Childs, Christopher Evans, Alan Ferguson, John Woodley, and the secretariat staff, Richard Gilbert, Krista Gerrard, Glenn Hunter, Cath Drinkwater and Stephen Wood for their work in developing this report in the shortest of time frames.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now pretty much towards the end of the second reading speeches on one of the most important pieces of legislation to come before the parliament—and arguably the most far-reaching set of proposals—with enormous implications not just for the Aboriginal community and for Aboriginal rights but also for the future economic development of Australia.

PARA.TAB: It would certainly be appropriate for me to say at the outset, as have many of my predecessors in this debate, that the opposition fully recognises the need to accept the High Court decision and what flows from it, to acknowledge the role that the Racial Discrimination Act will play in all future dealings in this matter, and, finally and by no means least importantly, to also state our firm view that land management issues are the responsibility of the states. We say that not simply on the basis of some sort of arid notion of states rights but very much because the constitution makes it clear that that is where the responsibility lies, and does so for very good reason. The reality is that the states are the ones which have to administer the way in which land title is handled and, of course, they are the ones which have to accept day-to-day responsibility in that area. That is why, of course, this bill needs to be dealt with in the most thorough and comprehensive manner possible.

In the face of all of the complexities and difficulties with which many lawyers have been trying to grapple in recent months and, indeed, since the bill was introduced, I think we have so far reached only the stage where there is a whole range of conflicting views about what many of the sections mean. We have, as recently as yesterday, received 189 amendments: 74 government amendments, 32 amendments from the Australian Democrats, and 83 amendments from the Greens. The consequence of that is that it is absolutely impossible for the Senate to give sensible consideration to the implications of those amendments.

There was an attempt to refer this matter to a Senate select committee. Unfortunately, that was not supported. Instead, we had to make do with a very hasty consideration of the matter by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which, in the time available to the committee, did an excellent job. The committee was not able, however, to travel to the main population centres of Melbourne and Sydney. It was not able to take evidence from people who were in a position to put this legislation in its proper social context and perspective. Accordingly, there is much more that needs to be done before anyone can claim to be able to understand the full ramifications of this legislation. It is no consolation to say that this will be a lawyers' picnic, because I do not think anyone has an interest in seeing inordinate delays, inordinate complexities and inordinate expenses incurred quite unnecessarily.

Of course, we have to remember that the government's first substantive response to the June 1992 decision did not come for at least 12 months thereafter. So there was no dramatic urgency in the early stages. Indeed, as members of the Aboriginal community have been quick to point out on many occasions, they have had to wait some 200 years before their rights have been recognised.

Against that background, there can be no earthly justification for railroading this legislation through the parliament in the way the government is proposing to do. Quite clearly, it is yet another example of the approach of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to these matters: get out on the highway, do a few delicate balancing tricks, throw a few balls in the air and leave it to others to pick up the pieces. That, of course, is nowhere near good enough for any legislation, but certainly for legislation with the enormous significance and ramifications of the Native Title Bill. It is utterly unacceptable. There is no need for this legislation to be rammed through the parliament, other than to meet the government's own political convenience. That ought to be the last justification for any such undue haste.

One has only to look at the experience in Canada, where there has been an Indian act for 117 years. Canada is currently in the process of dealing once more with a whole range of native title issues, and a royal commission on aboriginal affairs is required to report by 1995 to recommend a suitable framework for negotiation and settlement of outstanding issues.

In British Columbia, land claims currently cover an area equal to 130 per cent of the province. Investment and exploration in mining in British Columbia have fallen significantly in recent years. In other words, legislation is not by any means the end of the matter. It is really the start of a long and tortuous process. The more complicated the bill and the act are at the outset, the more difficult it will be to untangle all of those complexities. Therefore, it is absolutely crucial that what we should be doing at this stage is allowing further time for this matter to be properly considered, ideally by a select committee, but at the very least by a whole range of community interests.

I am certainly not speaking just about the pastoral and mining industries, which have, I think, very important and legitimate concerns, indeed going wider than their own industries. We all ought to have concerns about the economic consequences of this legislation because our future economic growth and prosperity will determine in large measure our ability to meet the cost of addressing Aboriginal disadvantage.

I want to be on the record as saying that, having travelled in outback Australia on many occasions over the last 15 or 20 years, I have seen at first hand the enormity of the task. It ought to be clear to anyone who has made even an occasional visit that we simply cannot address these issues by acknowledging land rights or native title rights which, as Noel Pearson acknowledges in respect of this bill, will benefit directly only five per cent of the Aboriginal community. The overwhelming task is to be able to address social and economic disadvantage on the part of the Aboriginal community and all the health, education, housing and welfare needs that will be with us indefinitely, as far as we can see at this stage. The capacity to afford those depends crucially upon Australia's economic future. To brush aside the concerns of the pastoral and mining industries is utterly short-sighted and indeed ultimately counterproductive.

It ought also to be said that the Aboriginal community itself is very concerned about the way in which the government has tried to ram this legislation through the parliament. A meeting of some 200 Aborigines only a couple of days ago called for this matter to be delayed. One has only to look at the appendix to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to see that there are very widespread groups of individuals who similarly want to see further time allowed to digest the complexities of this legislation. Therefore, it is my intention to move that there be a further period available before this matter is finally processed by the parliament.

I have listened very carefully to what the Greens have had to say in recent days. If we assume that they are not simply putting forward an ambit claim, if we assume that they do have the sincerity of their public statements and if we assume that the government will not accommodate them in all their demands, quite clearly the Greens ought to be voting against this legislation. If they do not, if and when that time arrives, they will be exposed as simply making rhetorical claims. I do not at this stage want to prejudge their attitude to the legislation, but what I think is critically important is that they themselves should acknowledge that it is not in anyone's interests that these matters be pushed through the parliament in the way in which the government is proposing to do for its own political purposes. It is not in anyone's interests. Therefore, I move:
That the debate be now adjourned.
