TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In winding up the second reading debate on Mabo, I state that this is unequivocally one of the most important pieces of legislation ever to come before this parliament. Accordingly, it deserves to be treated with utmost seriousness by all of us. I thank those who have contributed in that spirit during the second reading debate. I hope that in the forthcoming committee stage debate we will again focus, with the appropriate degree of seriousness and sense of responsibility, on the great issues that are involved.

PARA.TAB: As to the nature of the bill before us, I think its component elements were very well summarised by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his second reading speech. There are four key aspects of the legislation: first, ungrudging and unambiguous recognition and protection of native title; second, provision for clear and certain validation of past acts—including grants and laws, if they have been invalidated because of the existence of native title; third, the creation of a just and practical regime governing future grants and acts affecting native title; and, fourth, rigorous, specialised, and accessible tribunal and court processes for determining claims to native title, and for negotiation and decisions on proposed grants over native titled land.

The bill thus constructed on those foundations has—during the second reading debate—been subjected to a degree of assault both from the right, the opposition, and to some extent from the left, particularly from the contributions of the Greens. The assault from the right has had the following elements: that the bill is defective, and should be rejected or deferred on the grounds of its complexity and its alleged unworkability, unconstitutionality, unfederal character, and unfunded status and its alleged contribution to uncertainty.

These further points have been made: that the Aboriginal negotiators who have laboured so long and mightily to produce this document with the government are not representative; that there are still some divided views in the Aboriginal community; that—and this point has been made in a number of speeches—the bill is divisive; that it is in contrast with Parkes's original vision of one nation, one destiny; that the bill will lead to two nations; and that it will contribute to the very opposite of the reconciliation that we are seeking to achieve. The government obviously does not accept any of those criticisms.

I want to make some brief points in response. The bill has been the subject of a very protracted consultation process—a very open and transparent consultation process—with all key segments of the community. The elements of that consultative process were well summarised and spelt out in the Senate committee report and there is no need for me to repeat those elements here. The states have all been very much involved in that process, including Western Australia; notwithstanding what Senator Crane and others have had to say on that subject. It is not a matter of Mr Court being locked out of COAG or out of any consultative process. He chose to keep himself out of it. His officials have certainly been very much involved in that consultation on many occasions, both before and after that meeting.

The bill does give security to commercial and economic interests while, at the same time, providing justice for indigenous Australians. It is not a matter of the balance being tilted wildly in one direction or the other. It would only be fair if the opposition were prepared to acknowledge the degree of balance that has been achieved. The way in which that balance works itself out, clause by clause, no doubt will be the subject of detailed debate in the committee stage. I do not pre-empt that now. I simply make the claim—I think on thoroughly justified foundations—that that balance is there.

We are not creating two nations in this legislation, but establishing a process whereby, for the first time, newly recognised indigenous property rights can be registered and taken into account within the existing property law framework of this nation. We do not accept for a moment that the bill has any constitutional concerns associated with it. It has been very carefully drafted, very meticulously drafted, to cover off every possible objection on this score. If there is a challenge—and I guess we can inevitably expect one, not least from Western Australia—that will be for grounds of political motivation, not legal anxiety or any legitimate endeavour to defend the terms of the constitution.

The bill, so far as its alleged unfederal character is concerned, provides the most extensive possible opportunities for the states to maintain their primary role in land management, a primary role which the government is very ready to acknowledge. Recognised state bodies and processes will continue to operate within the framework of this bill, consistently with the national standards that are set down by it. There is not an attempt to recreate machinery that is otherwise effectively there for that purpose, unable to be mobilised for that purpose. The states' interests, to that extent, have been amply taken into account.

Of course, the bill does override—it is explicitly designed to have that effect—the Western Australian legislation. It does so for the very good reason that that legislation is simply manifestly unacceptable in this day and age, and in the light of the spirit of national reconciliation that we are trying very actively to recreate, particularly in the aftermath of the High Court's Mabo decision. That legislation involves a number of fundamentally unacceptable elements: in the first place and, overwhelmingly most importantly, the compulsory wholesale extinguishment of native title, a title which is now embodied in the common law. It overrides the inherent right of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who meet those criteria embodied in the law now. It involves the mandatory replacement of that right by a statutory title, one only conferred at the pleasure of government, one that can be extinguished in particular cases virtually at a minister's whim. It involves the establishment of a land management regime which provides only the flimsiest protections for Aboriginal people, protections far less than other land-holders enjoy. They are the reasons we believe that that Western Australian legislation should not only be overridden, but quickly put in its place by Commonwealth enactment putting beyond doubt the stature and continued status of the native title that has now been recognised by the High Court.

So far as objections from the left, as it were, are concerned, I guess they can be roughly summarised as follows: that Aboriginal people want recognition of their status as the prior owners of this land, and that some kind of sovereign treaty is really what is required; that the High Court judgment was conservative, providing no inherent right to compensation for dispossession; that the bill is unsatisfactory because, in some alleged respects, it leaves Aboriginal people worse off; and, of course, we have had the recurring argument that the process has been unsatisfactory in terms of those who have been involved in the negotiation and the character of the government's motivation.

Very quickly, in response to those points might I just say this: from any conceivable perspective, the bill does not leave Aboriginal people worse off. There are very considerable benefits inherent in the very structure of the legislation and there is the fact that it will override the Western Australian legislation which would leave them manifestly worse off. But more than that, more than the statutory recognition of native title and the statutory protection of native title that is inherent in this legislation, we do have the very explicit provisions that are manifestly beneficial: the establishment of the land fund; the provision for just terms compensation; the constraints on extinguishment of title that might otherwise apply if the common law were left to run its course; the tribunal process that has been established; and, the provisions for conversion of Aboriginal pastoral leases.

We have a series of provisions which do, in our judgment on any view, constitute special measures within the meaning of that expression in the International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination and the Australian Racial Discrimination Act. The delay of this bill or, even worse, its rejection, would not only leave Aboriginal people considerably worse off for all the reasons I have already mentioned, but we believe that delay or rejection would constrain or limit the prospects for future benefits accruing on a really quite significant scale in the future. The detailed objections that the Greens and others might have will again be the subject of debate in the committee stage. I will not now go into any further detail about those concerns.

Let me just say a final word about the kind of process that we have in mind for the debate in the committee stage. I do think it is important that these serious issues, as I said at the outset, be tackled seriously, systematically and responsibly by this chamber. It is proposed, after the motion for the second reading is put and carried in just a moment's time, that the debate then be adjourned to a later hour this day in order to enable two things to happen. Firstly, the Senate needs to consider a number of other pieces of legislation which need to be passed this session. Many of them have amendments associated with them which need to go back to the House of Representatives, so for the orderly management of the process from now on it would be helpful if that legislation could be debated and got out of the way first.

Secondly, it will allow the lapse of some hours before we get on to the committee stage, which will enable amendments which have yet to be tabled and circulated by the Democrats and the Greens in particular to be tabled. It will also enable the preparation of running sheets that will hopefully help the orderly management of the debate. The government's own amendments—over 70 of them, but constituting in practice only something over 30 different substantive areas—were, of course, tabled and circulated together with a supplementary explanatory memorandum yesterday. Accordingly, there has been opportunity, I hope, for those amendments to be understood and absorbed.

It is proposed, and this has been the subject of discussion with most others in this chamber, that when we get to the committee stage the amendments be grouped so as to bring together in one place all the amendments bearing on a particular subject area, even though there may be three or four amendments scattered over the whole course of the bill which bear upon that subject matter. Hopefully, quite shortly such a grouping of the government amendments will be circulated. I hope it will be possible during the course of the day equally to group the Greens' and the Democrats' amendments in a way that we can bring together the key elements of the debate and, in effect, debate cognately the amendments bearing upon each particular substantive issue as it arises in turn during the course of the debate. If it is appropriate or helpful to not put all the amendments thus grouped together but rather to put the amendments separately, we will of course do that as each occasion arises during the course of the debate.

I hope that, approached in that way and in that spirit, it will be possible to deal with quite a complex committee stage expeditiously and in the spirit that really is necessary for legislation of this magnitude. Mr Acting Deputy President, I commend the Native Title Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That this bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the bill in committee of the whole be an order of the day for a later hour this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1993INCOME TAX (FRANKING DEFICIT) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 25 November.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 and the amendments moved by Senator McMullan on behalf of the government.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, the opposition has circulated an amendment to clause 18 of the bill. I wonder if I could seek your guidance. I regret that Senator Watson is absent for this debate. I will be handling it for the coalition on his behalf. Just to get clear where we are, are we taking the bill as a whole?
—The answer is yes, but my understanding is that Senator Watson had two amendments to clause 18—amendments 1 and 2.

—Yes, which have been circulated. I do have some other comments on other aspects of the bill as well. I wonder perhaps, in the first instance, whether I could make a couple of comments about a particular aspect and come to my amendments later on. If Senator McMullan is listening to this, I would be grateful for his response.

PARA.TAB: I draw the committee's attention to a potential disadvantage facing many early-balancing companies, which are companies with a substituted accounting period after 30 November 1993. These companies may be denied the nine-week deferral of tax payments referred to in clause 165 of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) in the event that the bill, if passed, is not presented for royal assent before the time the payments of tax in question fall due. Thus, for example, an early-balancing company with a taxation year ending on 31 December 1993 in lieu of the succeeding 30 June 1994 would be disadvantaged in relation to later-balancing companies if it did not become entitled to rely on the deferral referred to in the bill before 28 January 1994 when the payment of tax in question would ordinarily fall due. I ask the minister whether he can give an assurance that royal assent to the bill will be granted prior to 31 December 1993. If that does not happen, as I understand it, those early-balancing companies will be disadvantaged.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is our intention that that should happen. Certain things have to happen in the Senate first. Assuming all of that takes place, that is our determination and intention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 18, page 5, line 7, omit "The amendments", substitute "Subject to subsection (2), the amendments".
2.Clause 18, page 5, at the end, add the following subsection:

"(2) The amendments made by this Division do not apply in relation to expenditure for which a deduction has been claimed in a return, furnished to the Commissioner before 5 August 1993 and not subsequently amended to include such a deduction.".

Those amendments were circulated some time ago by Senator Watson on behalf of the opposition. The purpose of the coalition's amendments to the government's retrospective amendment in relation to petroleum activities, which is contained in clause 18 of the bill—I stress that clause 18, as now drafted, is a retrospective move by the government—is to ensure that the amendments affected by division 2 of part 4 apply only in relation to taxpayers who claim a deduction on and from the date of the press release of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) on 4 August 1993.

PARA.TAB: In simple terms, the effect of the opposition's amendments is as follows: firstly, in cases where taxpayers have not previously claimed a deduction, the government's amendments would apply from the date of the introduction of the original amendments in 1990. Taxpayers who have legitimately claimed a deduction prior to August 1993 will be allowed that deduction. Taxpayers who have not claimed a deduction prior to 4 August 1993 will not be permitted to seek to amend their returns to claim a deduction.

The coalition's amendments have the support of the following bodies, all of which have grave concerns about the retrospective element of the government's own clause: the Law Council of Australia, the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the Taxation Institute of Australia and the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. The reason for the coalition's amendments is our concern about the length of time—two years—that it took the Australian Taxation Office and the government to bring about the change that is now contained in the bill. The apparent effect of the 1991 amendments was raised on two separate occasions by the professional bodies: firstly, at the National Tax Liaison Group Foreign Income Measures Subcommittee meeting, which was held as long ago as 26 September 1991, at which the Taxation Office representatives noted that the matter would be examined; and, secondly, at a later National Tax Liaison Group Foreign Income Measures Subcommittee meeting held on 2 February 1992, at which Taxation Office representatives advised that the matter was still being examined.

Given the time that has elapsed since those meetings, it is not unreasonable for tax advisers to assume that the ATO has accepted that the relevant provisions operated according to their tenor. This assumption was reinforced by the lack of a timely response by the ATO and the absence of any notice, other than a press release, that an amendment was forthcoming. We understand that the ATO has issued at least one private ruling—it may have issued others—to particular taxpayers acknowledging the deductibility of these expenses. The ATO will now have to discover a way to deal with these cases, given that all taxpayers must be treated in the same way on an issue.

Finally—and I believe this is a fundamental point—the proper administration of taxation laws depends on the cooperation and goodwill of professional bodies. I put it to the government that that process will break down if the ATO or the government acts retrospectively, to the detriment of the professional bodies and their clients, as a result of these issues of concern being raised. This issue has all the hallmarks of delay, similar to the procrastination that was associated with the notorious handling of the bottom of the harbour arrangements.

However, I hasten to add that, until the bottom of the harbour time, the deductions were legal and written in black-letter law in the statute. There was no ambiguity in the statute law enacted in 1991, hence there was no need to refer to a second reading, et cetera. The coalition is moving this amendment to clause 18 to remove that retrospective element. We believe it is a very serious matter. Therefore, I hope the amendment will have the support of the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Although we did cover this in the second reading debate and I do not wish to duplicate that, Senator Short has properly put the case on the record and I do not want it to stand uncommented upon. Senator Watson, Senator Kernot and I have essentially traversed this in a previous debate. If people want to see an extensive recording of it, they should consult that record. I will not duplicate it. It is an important issue of balance, and nobody could deny that the process by which this matter has been handled has been unduly delayed. I accept that and I do not seek to defend it. It should not have occurred in that manner. It is a complex and difficult issue. It could not have been dealt with in a day or a week, but the process has been too long, and we made that point before. Nevertheless, the balance of public interest in this matter is clear, notwithstanding that concern.

PARA.TAB: We are doing two things with this. First, we are making the tax law mean what it was intended to mean. Second, we are confirming a basic principle of tax law—that you cannot allow deductions for expenditure incurred for the purpose of producing exempt income. I reiterate that those two principles are correct, although they may be uncomfortable from the government's point of view in this circumstance because of the procedures. They are not merely arcane matters of principle. The cost to the revenue of the defect, if allowed to stand, could exceed $1 billion. If you do not accept the principle, opt for the money.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek a clarification regarding one of the points I made. My understanding is that at least one private ruling has been issued in respect of this matter, acknowledging the deductibility of the expenses. Assuming we agree with the basic principle that all taxpayers should be treated equally, what does the government propose to do about that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of private rulings given, but my understanding—and the tax office has sought to confirm this—is that there has not been such a positive private ruling in this matter. I cannot be absolutely sure because there is no capacity to check quickly every ruling that has been issued to every taxpayer in a private capacity. All the public ones are on the record, by definition, but it is not my understanding that there is such a private ruling. That is my advice.

—I guess that that will be confirmed or otherwise in due course. Regarding Senator McMullan's revenue figure of $1 billion, I do not know how well based that is. But the coalition cannot resile in any way from its basic objection to any retrospectivity in the taxation law. We have had this debate for a long time now. Retrospectivity is death to equity and fairness in taxation. The coalition's understanding of clause 18, as now drafted, is that it is retrospective. Therefore, we will be pressing this amendment. If we do not, then we are saying as a parliament, as a Senate, that retrospectivity is okay simply because the Taxation Office has been tardy in doing its job. That is a fundamental point with which we could not agree.
—It would have been retrospective even if they were quick.
—For both reasons we oppose it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make the point that 39 out of 40 companies clearly understood this. In the same way as the honourable senator thinks retrospectivity is a problem—and I agree with him—I think those who deliberately seek to evade, and smart lawyers, cost the revenue of this country, and the capacity for revenue raising in this country to be fairly shared. That is a huge cost to the public purse, which I think is equally important.

—I agree, but that is the fault of the Taxation Office; it is not the fault of the taxpayer. Surely the minister is not suggesting that the adoption of the opposition's amendment is a cost to revenue of $1 billion?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is my advice, and it is not really surprising. Just before I come to Senator Harradine's point, I refer to something Senator Short said. He said that the opposition's understanding of the proposal is that it is retrospective. I do not deny that; it is. I do not deny that that is an action with which we are not comfortable and that it must be taken only in the most extraordinary of circumstances. I do not seek to say that this is a way in which the tax law should, in the normal course of events, be handled. The broad thrust of what he said about retrospectivity is, I think, shared by the whole parliament, so I am not trying to challenge that principle.

PARA.TAB: I indicate to Senator Harradine that I cannot personally verify the arithmetic, but the order of magnitude is not really surprising. Although the number of companies affected by this is limited, it is a very large flow of income and of expenditures which might otherwise be able to be claimed.

What we have is a possibility that people may be able to claim as deductions against their taxable income in Australia a very large amount of expenditure which was earning income that is exempt from Australian taxation. Senator Kernot outlined the order of magnitude of the numbers of companies involved: if all those companies that had not claimed these deductions were to proceed to do so, it is unquestionable that it would be hundreds of millions of dollars. I cannot stand here and say in blood that it would be a billion because I do not know, but there must be, unequivocally, hundreds of millions of dollars flowing from taxpayers to companies. In that instance, they will be acting entirely in accordance with the law because the Senate would have resolved that that is what they are entitled to do. I hope the Senate does not resolve that, but I would not criticise it for doing it. We would have, in effect, carried a motion; we would have opened a door and invited them in. We cannot blame them for passing through the door.

It would be flowing to companies and reducing our capacity otherwise to fund things that we properly should, not at the moment by intention of the parliament but by inadvertence. I do not think that sort of windfall by inadvertence should be allowed to proceed, notwithstanding that it is a very rare circumstance when anybody in this parliament would vote for legislation that has that retrospective effect. I can envisage other circumstances. The outcome of Capital Duplicators may well have been another circumstance in which we may have done that on behalf of the states, but it is not something we would seek to do in the normal course of events.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Short's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of other points I want to draw attention to and seek some clarification from the minister. The first one relates to part 9 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill, which deals with amendments to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992, and in particular to clause 137.

PARA.TAB: The government's amendments contained in clause 137 will exempt the RSPCA from sales tax on goods used mainly in carrying out inspections and operating animal shelters. It will provide a credit to the RSPCA of sales tax paid on goods used in inspectorial and shelter activities that are purchased in the period 13 March 1993 until this bill receives royal assent. The coalition certainly welcomes that move. But there is an element of unfairness in granting the RSPCA that exemption when the largest companion animal shelter in Victoria, the Lost Dogs Home, which is doing exactly the same rescue and shelter work as the RSPCA, does not have this sales tax exemption extended to it.

Is there a particular reason for excluding the Lost Dogs Home or is it an oversight? Will the government consider granting the Lost Dogs Home the same exemption, putting it on the same basis as the RSPCA? They both do very important and valuable work. In my state of Victoria, they do rescue and shelter work in equal measure. The Lost Dog's Home is a larger operation than the RSPCA in Victoria. I hope the government will look at granting the same tax exemption to the Lost Dog's Home that it is rightly granting to the RSPCA.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have discussed exactly the same principle, in broad terms, on previous occasions when we have discussed this matter. I have a concern about specifying particular organisations in the tax legislation rather than categories of organisations or activity so that the same activity conducted by different organisations is taxed in the same way. It is not something I would do lightly. In fact, I argued against it on a previous occasion when an amendment was proposed to the sales tax legislation to exempt the RSPCA. I have to acknowledge that this amendment is inconsistent with the argument I put before, and Senator Kernot scored that point off me on a previous occasion.

PARA.TAB: We made the decision that the RSPCA deserved a special categorisation, not for its equivalent Lost Dogs Home activities but for its range of activities. I accept that every time a special categorisation is made—welcome and worthy as this one is—consequential problems are created. For the moment, I acknowledge Senator Short's point. It is something we will have to consider over the medium term, but for the moment we are making a one-off exemption for the RSPCA. I do not deny his point of principle, but we are not going to introduce a new category into the sales tax exemptions. I would prefer never to make one-off things like this. However, I think most Australians would think that, if we were going to do one, this is a pretty worthwhile area in which to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what I said last time.

—I do not want to start this debate again. We are all in a hurry and we have heard it several times before. In principle, I do not think we should do so. I would prefer that we find a consistent way of doing it, but here we are making an exemption, while the burden of tax principle is with Senator Short's and my previous position. It is a very worthy organisation. I know that Senator Short is not arguing that we should not be doing it and I was not trying to imply that. I think we have to accept that it is a less than perfect tax law but that it is giving assistance to a worthwhile organisation. We just have to hold our noses and do it.

—I do not want to pursue this matter at length either, but I ask the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) whether he can explain to the committee the distinction between the treatment of the RSPCA and that of the Lost Dogs Home? What is the principle that differentiates the two?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that Senator Short has not put that question in its correct form. The question should be: what is it that distinguishes the RSPCA from the 109 other organisations that do some of the activities the RSPCA undertakes? The example he has given is not the only one. If the honourable senator wants some more examples, I refer him to my previous speeches on this matter, eloquent as they were and successful, even if only temporarily.
—I wish Ian Warden were listening.

—He would not miss a word of what Senator Kernot has to say. I am sure he is sitting in his office listening. I think the RSPCA has a range of activities that none of the others can claim to have. Each of the activities it undertakes is undertaken somewhere else by someone else, but probably no-one else has the range. It is not a well-developed body of tax principle we are implementing here; it is a one-off thing that conflicts with tax principle, as properly constructed, but it helps a worthwhile organisation. If every time we make a one-off exception like this we get attacked because it does not deal with the whole 110 organisations, we can never make such exceptions.

PARA.TAB: I have the view that probably there is a case to say that one should not make such exemptions, but the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), in his magnanimity, has said, `Here is a very worthy organisation'. I think everybody shares the view that it is worthy. The debate we are having now proves exactly what the difficulty is in making one-off exemptions. I reiterate that it is a breach of good tax law principles, but it is in a worthy cause and I just cop it with as much grace as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to what the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) has had to say about the RSPCA's exemption from sales tax being a one-off thing. I know that the RSPCA has been working for a long time, but the government is opening up the gates. I have never really come to a conclusion about whether or not I will support the organisation. I always give non-committal answers. I am not used to doing that about anything. Once the gates have been opened, there will be a renewal of fervour by the Lost Dogs Home and then by lost cats, lost canaries, lost people, lost Democrats and so on. It will give them more reasons to go ahead. I welcome the one-off exemption for the RSPCA, in a way, but the trouble is that the government has opened up the gates and it will have two or three next year and four or five the year after. We have to be very careful about the flow-on effect.

PARA.TAB: It is just like the last clause we were talking about dealing with retrospectivity. I was a little late coming in, but I heard Senator Kernot say, `We cannot support Senator Short's motion because $1 billion may have escaped'. I thought at the time that Senator Short's amendment was pretty good. What I would like Senator Kernot to think about is the fact that every new tax act that comes in raises far more money than the government intended. I know that this has applied to the two principal taxes in the last seven or eight years, the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, and it applies to any new tax. But the government does not then say that it will cut the rate or give some of it back, or something like that. We have to balance that against what may have gone out the door. In the case of the RSPCA, we have to see how much more is going to go out the door with the lobbying that will go on. We will probably find another worthy cause. I urge the minister to proceed with caution on this matter—something that I seldom do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of additional points I want to raise. If I do not, apart from anything else, Senator Watson will kill me. The points refer to part 10 of the bill, which deals with amendments to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992. I am referring to clauses 144 to 152 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993. I note with some concern the proposed amendments to the shortfall provisions of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act. Those amendments are designed to allow a superannuation guarantee shortfall component to be paid into a complying approved deposit fund, or ADF, and to ensure that any shortfall component received by a complying ADF is a taxable contribution. Could the minister tell us briefly what evidence there is, empirical or otherwise, to indicate that this additional measure to handle superannuation guarantee shortfalls is necessary.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not introducing a new provision about the superannuation guarantee shortfall component as such, we are just extending the range of financial institutions into which it can be paid. We are saying that, as well as the ordinarily defined superannuation funds, it can be paid into an ADF. It is simply opening up an option for people. The superannuation guarantee shortfall component concept is already driven by the principal legislation. This is simply saying that, if this is paid into an ADF, it will be treated as if it were being paid into a superannuation fund. I assume that there will be people wishing to do that and, at the very least, it should not be the tax law that stops them. If they choose not to, it should be as a result of their decision about what they want to do with their superannuation funds, not because it is treated differently by the tax laws.

—Senator Watson's major concern, as I understand it, is that it is more flaws in the legislation and its administration that are leading to this supposed non-compliance. For example, in relation to small superannuation guarantee payments and associated administrative costs, we question: should the legislation be amended to provide an increase in the minimum size or number of payments to promote compliance and better administration? Is the legislation in need of amendment where an employee has a number of employers who are paying amounts into different funds, thereby increasing the employee's administration costs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson is, in his usual adept way, using a clause to make a point that I am sure he cares passionately about but which does not actually relate to this clause. It is a hook he is hanging it off. He is concerned about some aspects of the superannuation guarantee legislation in the broad, and one aspect of his concern relates to the fact that there is some element of non-compliance.

PARA.TAB: The only way that connects to this is that he is concerned about the events that cause the non-compliance. What we are dealing with here are the consequences of the non-compliance, not in any way in terms of imposing a penalty, other than that people have to pay the money. If they fail to pay, they have to pay. What we are dealing with here is a change to the act to change the range of financial institutions into which the money belatedly paid can be placed. I think most of us would think it is obviously beneficial, and I do not think Senator Watson or Senator Short disagrees with that. There is no extra cost to the taxpayer. If he wants to have a debate about whether we should change the broad thrust of the superannuation guarantee legislation, he should do it on another occasion.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: INCOME TAX (FRANKING DEFICIT) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 reported with amendments and Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill 1993 reported without amendment or requests; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.
The bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993DIESEL FUEL (EXCISE DUTY REBATE) ADMINISTRATION CHARGE BILL 1993DIESEL FUEL (CUSTOMS DUTY REBATE) ADMINISTRATION CHARGE BILL 1993EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Clause 6, page 4, after paragraph (a) insert the following paragraph:
"(ab) by adding at the end of item 1 the following sub item:

PARA.TAB: (D)Beer manufactured on particular premises providing to the public commercial facilities and equipment for use in the production of beer at those premises
15% of the rate for the time being that applies to goods classified to paragraph (C) of this item.".

SPEECH.PARA: The subject matter of this amendment has been canvassed in the second reading debate and I will not detain the committee for long. I simply say that we were faced with a decision as to whether we should support the government in imposing excise on the beer that is produced by micro-breweries. The micro-breweries had made an inquiry of the Customs Service before they established their premises and were told that, if they followed a particular procedure, no excise would be levied. On the other hand, if micro-breweries proliferate—as they have done in Canada, where evidence shows that they have proliferated to the extent of producing three to four per cent of total beer production—there would be a substantial loss to government revenue of something in the order of $30 million in Australia. We are concerned about that.

PARA.TAB: On that basis, the amendment seeks to impose an excise at the rate of 15 per cent which, together with wholesale sales tax, which I understand is consequential upon the imposition of excise, and the licence fees, which are also consequential, would bring the market price of beer produced in micro-breweries to approximately the level of the market price for beer produced by the manufacturing breweries.

Our intention in doing this is to fire a warning shot across the bows of micro-breweries and say that, while we certainly do not want to put them out of business, they cannot rely on a differential rate of excise—a preferential rate of excise, one should probably say—forever. I believe that this amendment is one that resolves to some extent the conflict of the two principles I outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not support the Democrats' amendment, but will be opposing the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on the record for the government that, first of all, we recognise the mathematics of the committee on this issue: with the opposition opposing full stop, if we voted against the Democrats' amendment we would end up with no excise at all. So, very reluctantly, we will support the Democrats' amendment at 15 per cent. I did put to the Democrats the proposition that it would be more effective around 30 per cent but, as I say, we recognise the numbers in this place on this particular measure. If we vote against it, we lose the lot; so 15 per cent is better than zero.

PARA.TAB: We will be reluctantly accepting the Democrats' amendment but, in doing so, I want to make a couple of points. We believe that it is necessary to establish the principle that beer produced at commercial premises—for example, brew-on-premises shops—is subject to the beer excise regime. The government, as I have just said, does not accept the principle espoused by the Democrats that there needs to be equivalence of retail prices. The market establishes the prices, not the government. Retail beer prices reflect significant differences between states, including different state licence fees. We know that recently the High Court made a ruling about those matters. The government believes that the overriding principle should be equity in the industry, that is, all beer brewed using commercial facilities should be subject to the excise regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about beer for sale?

—What we are emphasising is that, if it is brewed in a commercial enterprise which is operating as a commercial enterprise, it is in the marketplace. One can say that it is not for direct sale in the marketplace as a bottle of beer, but it is being brewed in a commercial enterprise that is operating at a profit. These micro-breweries would not be established on the basis that they were going to let individuals brew their beer and take it away and lose their money. The micro-breweries are being established to make a profit. That cannot be ignored. Although the bottles of beer produced are not actually sold, they are produced for people in the home-brewing market. But they use commercial premises and pay a fee for those premises to produce the beer. We believe that is a significant difference.

PARA.TAB: We believe that the assumption behind the Democrats' amendment, therefore, is entirely incorrect, that is, retail beer prices are the same between states; state licence fees on beer are the same between states; and sales tax is payable on the brew-on-premises shop price plus excise duty. Advice from the Taxation Office suggests otherwise. Excise should be a mechanism to equalise prices in the marketplace. Those are the reasons why we believe the assumption of the Democrats in the calculation of 15 per cent is incorrect.

The government's assessment is that the full rate of excise should be applied. However, given the concerns expressed, the government is prepared to modify its stance on the rate to ensure that BOP shops fall within the excise regime, even though it is at a level which is much less than we would like. I point out that, in our view, this does not solve the problem and that, in the future, the government may need to take further action. I want to emphasise this very strongly for the record. If the micro-breweries continue to develop in the marketplace and clearly start taking considerable market share, I warn this chamber, the parliament, and particularly the industry that we will seek to come back to the parliament and take measures to protect the excise revenue on beer overall.

One of the motivations for the government on this issue has been that we believe it is better to take early action before the industry develops—if it is going to develop, and it may develop—to such an extent that many more people would be employed and many more people would be investing if they saw that there was an advantage in the marketplace and if in a few years time, instead of having almost negligible production affecting the overall beer market, it was starting to run into many percentage points. I am told that in Canada the output of the micro-brewery structure that is operating in one of the provinces is now approaching eight or nine per cent of the consumption of beer. If we got to that sort of effect, I would have to ask this chamber to support a more difficult position, because we would have arguments from many more people claiming that they have already invested and from workers who are employed in these commercial micro-breweries. In our view, it would be a tougher decision to take then. I warn honourable senators and I warn the industry that, if it gets out of hand and starts getting into those sorts of percentage figures, we and the Australian Customs Service on behalf of the government will come back to take action to protect the excise revenue.

The other thing that does concern us a little is that, if these micro-breweries start to grow and get an increased percentage of the consumption of beer, we suspect that the existing fully fledged commercial breweries that are operating in the marketplace and paying their full share of excise will say, `We want to get into this area to protect our market share as a commercial venture'. If that starts happening, that would be of concern to us because that would start rotting the revenue in this area of excise, which all honourable senators would recognise is a very valuable contribution to government revenues. It has been accepted since Federation that at the Commonwealth level our right to excise in this area is an important contribution to the national revenues.

I have made those remarks because I think it is important to put the government's view on the record. I also want to suggest to Senator Spindler in particular that my advisers believe that there may be a better way to achieve the 15 per cent contained in his amendment than the way he has put it. We believe the amendment should read:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 6, page 4, after paragraph (a), insert the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(ab) by inserting after sub-item 1(B) the following sub-item:

SPEECH.PARA: (BB)Beer produced for non-commercial purposes using commercial facilities or equipment
15% of the rate applying to goods classified to sub-item (C).'.".

The effect certainly is the same as Senator Spindler's amendment but it adopts the wording used in the definition of beer, therefore maintaining consistency in the use of the relevant definition. I table that amendment, which I think is better worded. It is not a secret plot to do over Senator Spindler's amendment; it just makes it, in our view, more consistent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept in good faith what the minister says. If it assists the clarity of the provision, then I seek leave to amend my amendment in the terms of the minister's proposal.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is desirable that we should put on record the fact that, to the best of my knowledge, this is the first occasion on which excise has been charged on goods that are not for sale. I believe that it is a vast leap in the excise area, and it should be noted for other people for other occasions that that is what this now implies.

PARA.TAB: Reference was made to the extension of the brewed-on-premises situation. I do not wish to speak on these clauses and I undertook not to, with the need for expedition, but, seeing that it has been raised, I wish to reiterate what I said in the second reading debate: the opposition, too, was warning against this becoming a proliferation. If this was going to become the alternative to home brewing, I could see no difference. But if it is going to be an extension, if the percentage did get up to a meaningful level and it did start to erode the traditional situation, then we had undertaken that we would scrutinise the position and take action if it became necessary. I would not want it to be the impression of the committee that we were not also committed to that line of action.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I appreciate Senator Archer's remarks and I appreciate that Senator Spindler, in accepting on faith our amendments, is making his amendment better. I certainly appreciate his accepting it to expedite the business of the committee.

PARA.TAB: I say to Senator Archer that I appreciate his commitment to expedite this legislation, but I also say to Senator Archer—as well as to Senator Spindler—that we appreciate the opposition putting on the record that, if there were any, as we use the phrase, rotting of the excise because of the development of commercial micro-breweries, the opposition would be willing to consider legislation.

I point out also that the problem on the excise position raised by the honourable senator is because of amendments in the 1970s. Prior to that, home brewed beer was excisable. That was not for sale and it was excisable—

TALK.START.PARA: —Never claimed and never paid.

—I just want to put out the history of it. It seemed quite reasonable in the 1970s to establish home brewing in response to demand from the electorate. Sooner or later someone may work out, as they have in this case, how to establish commercial micro-breweries to take advantage of it. But we will monitor it, and I thank the committee for its cooperation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I want to make a very brief comment on Senator Archer's statement that this is the first time excise has been applied to goods that were not for sale. I believe there is a distinction to be made between the purely technical legal definition of whether an item is for sale and whether, as it is claimed in this case, it is actually produced by the purchaser using somebody else's facilities. Micro-breweries, while they provide equipment for people to come and stir the ingredients in a kettle a couple of times and then come back in two weeks time and bottle it, essentially in substance—and I draw the distinction between substance and legality—are still a method of providing cheaper beer to the purchaser.

PARA.TAB: Request agreed to.
Bill agreed to with a request.

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 5, page 3, lines 13 to 24, omit paragraphs (a) and (b).
Clause 17, page 12, lines 22 to 33, omit paragraphs (a) and (b).
These amendments involve the removal of the provision limiting claims to three years from the time of purchase.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Democrats support the three-year limit, for the reasons I gave in my speech in the second reading debate, so we will not be supporting this amendment. I indicate to the Senate that we will support amendment (10A), which extends the time.

—It may be appropriate and expeditious if I outline that amendment (10A) allows six months, in which time an AAT hearing in this area will bring down a decision and allow claimants to make claims. If it goes through as from 1 January, it will not give them that time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We accept the amendment to change the date to 1 July 1994, but we reject the amendment which will effectively give six months further time for applications. We believe that could be seen to be in conflict with the 1 July date. The 1 July date makes it clear, whereas the amendment is saying that it is except where the applicant gave notice prior to 1 July 1994 of an intention to make an application on the grounds set out in the notice. We believe that is unnecessary and may lead to some confusion about what rights people have where an applicant gave notice prior to 1 July 1994. Going from 1 January to 1 July 1994 is six months extra, which should be more than enough time for people to take account of the points raised by Senator Archer.

—It is not a matter of the time to take notice, it is the time it is going to take, unless Senator Schacht can give us an idea of when the AAT ruling is likely to come down. All this amendment says is that we would expect the AAT to produce its ruling within six months. That is all this amendment is about.

—We accept the reasoning of the opposition in this instance. We believe that the AAT ought to be able to do its task and that we ought not to pre-empt any judgment that that tribunal makes. We can see the sense in extending the time until 1 July. We believe that it ought not to pre-empt the possibility of those who could benefit from a positive judgment by the AAT. We have no idea what judgment they will make. We are persuaded by the opposition's arguments in that case. We do not think it opens a floodgate; it simply gives people the opportunity to indicate their interest in a positive judgment by the AAT.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats now indicate that they are willing to support the opposition. I ask the Senate to consider this point carefully. I have been advised that the provision for notices to be given, rather than the obligation to formally make claims for rebates, has been prompted by self-interested consultants, who see opportunities here to sign up potential claimants who might become eligible as a result of AAT or Federal Court appeals against negative decisions by Customs. That is put in a robust way, and I certainly accept that.
—It's Reds under the bed.

—No. I may have been the minister responsible for Customs for only eight or nine months, but in that time I have learnt very quickly that there is a substantial industry of consultants who spend an enormous amount of time trying to find every possible way in which they can use the existing law, or interpretations of the existing law, to gain a financial advantage for the clients they advise. That is their democratic right; that is part of our system. But it also means that we will have people using every opportunity to find ways in which applications can be lodged.

PARA.TAB: I recently brought before the Senate legislation dealing with the car industry and an impossible interpretation of the export facilitation program. With the cooperation of the Senate, that legislation was passed. That program had been operating successfully since the mid-1980s, but a customs consultant believed that there was a possible legal interpretation that those companies that were not in the export facilitation program—that is, car importers not manufacturing in Australia—could claim the benefit for themselves in one form or another. Those claims would have run into hundreds of millions of dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —You got the support of the opposition.

—Yes, everybody supported it. We made sure we closed off that loophole, even though we did not concede, legally, that he would win the case in the court. I am using this case as an example of the fact that people in this `consultant industry' are combing legislation looking for every opportunity for advantage. If they do find an advantage, or believe that they have found an advantage, it means big income for them and savings for their clients.
—If that eventuates, we will help you fix it.
—We believe it is always better to be prepared beforehand and make sure that these things do not happen. People might say that I am raising a scare campaign—
—I would never say that.

—Senator Woodley may not say that; he probably is giving me the benefit of the doubt. I would have to say to the committee that if we give the six-month period and people do round up a lot of applications to be lodged as a result, there will be some problem with it. I do not think it will be in the spirit even of what Senator Archer is proposing in this amendment. Of course, once it is through, it is through. No-one will be able to do much with it because no-one is going to come back in here in nine months time and try retrospectively to legislate, in view of the workload of the Senate and in view of the fact that a lot of people in the Senate, including myself, are a little careful about retrospective legislation. I want to make that point to the committee.

PARA.TAB: My advisers have provided me with some information that is also relevant here. If there is to be a notice of intention, as per the opposition amendments, we want to emphasise the need for that notice to include certain details so that it cannot be used, as we say, to clog up the system and become an abuse of the scheme's intent. I do not know whether Senator Archer or Senator Woodley can respond to that suggestion. This is what we are trying to achieve here. We have conceded the 1 July date, which we think covers most of the point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nothing further to say. I undertook not to speak on this. It is Senator Schacht who is speaking.

—I know; I appreciate that. I had been given advice that the second amendment was also going to be opposed by the Democrats. I do not know whether I got wrong advice or we thought it was going to be defeated. That is why I have had to get up and put something on the record.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—Senator Archer, we need some clarification here. Can you tell the committee which amendment you are referring to?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is going to expedite things, I will withdraw amendment (10) and substitute (10A). Then we can deal with (2) and (10A), which is nice and tidy. I seek leave to withdraw amendment (10).

PARA.TAB: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: (10A) Clause 17, page 12, paragraph (a), proposed subsection 78A(4AB), line 24, omit "1 January 1994", substitute "1 July 1994".

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I have more information I want to put on the record concerning the amendment and the lodging of applications. If this amendment succeeds—and I suspect it will now, with the indication given to me—the government wishes to indicate that in the amending bill, to accommodate the committee's wishes, it will require that the notice of intent include the following data: the full name of applicant or applicants, the address, category, manner of use and signature of applicant. I am advised that this would assist in overcoming our desire that the system not be clogged up by unnecessary applications.

—It does require a certain degree of good faith on the part of the government to ensure that this operates, because unless this is declared by 31 December it is too late anyway. In the meantime, we accept that the government does act in good faith. I understand that, if this is passed, the government will see that this is enacted by 31 December.
—Certainly.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—The question before the chair is that amendment (2) be agreed to.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that Senator Archer's amendment (10A) be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3)Clause 5, page 3, paragraph (c), proposed paragraph 164(4D)(b), lines 31 to 35, omit the paragraph.
(5)Clause 6, page 4, lines 1 to 21, omit the clause.
(7)Clause 8, pages 5 and 6, paragraph (a), line 32 (page 5) to line 17 (page 6), omit the paragraph.
(11)Clause 17, page 13, paragraph (c), proposed paragraph 78A(4D)(b), lines 1 to 5, omit the paragraph.
(13)Clause 18, page 13, lines 11 to 31, omit the clause.
(15)Clause 20, pages 14 and 15, paragraph (a), line 38 (page 14) to line 22 (page 15), omit the paragraph.

All of these amendments involve the diesel fuel rebate administration charge. The points both for and against this matter have been adequately canvassed by the government, the opposition and the Australian Democrats. I commend the amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Archer's cooperation in order to save time. I put on record the fact that we oppose these amendments. The diesel fuel rebate administration charge, which we accept is a tax, and that is why it is here as tax legislation, is a reasonable administration charge on a program that is providing over $1 billion worth of benefit to Australia. We oppose the amendments moved by Senator Archer because they negate the bill.

—I would like to take a moment to clarify an issue with the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht). It relates to the submissions that I understand would have been made to the government by Senator Collins with regard to the fuel tax excise rebates and how they impact on the operation and viability of the Northern Territory's Wamboden Abattoir in central Australia. I understand that these tax imposts will increase the operating costs of that abattoir by some $65,000 and will affect the entire viability of this very important abattoir in central Australia. The company depends on Mereenie crude oil for the generation of its power. Unless the current Mereenie crude pricing is maintained, the prospect of the abattoir being able to operate at a viable level is doubtful.

PARA.TAB: I appreciate that this is a one-off type of operation in the Alice Springs area and that the local wholesalers and retailers rely on this service kill facility. I know that the Minister for Industries and Development in the Northern Territory, the Hon. Shane Stone, has made representations on this issue. I raised the matter personally with Senator Collins two or three weeks ago and have been pursuing the matter with him on an almost daily basis, At this stage I have not received any indication of what action the government is going to take to alleviate this impost. I request for the record any information the minister is able to provide.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct, as Senator Tambling said, that representations have been made to the government about the case of the abattoir near Alice Springs in Central Australia. The primary purpose of the legislation is to ensure that the users of fuel are taxed as the government intends. For example, where substitutes are used for diesel, they are to attract a diesel fuel duty rate. The government acknowledges that users of substitutes may therefore face an increase in prices. When a substitute is used for a purpose eligible under the diesel fuel rebate scheme, the rebate scheme will provide a rebate. Where there is no coverage of the rebate scheme, there is currently no relief from the tax.

PARA.TAB: With respect to abattoirs, I am advised by Customs that there are appeals pending before the AAT on whether diesel used in association with these abattoirs is eligible for rebate. If the AAT decision is that the rebate is payable, abattoirs which use crude as a substitute for diesel will also qualify for rebate of the excise. I note, however, that the abattoir matter has already been raised with ministers and, rather than wait for the AAT decision, the government will consider whether liability for excise for particular uses or by particular users should be qualified.

I am also advised by Customs that, in this particular case, the use of the crude oil could be as a substitute for fuel oil, which is taxed at a far lower rate than diesel. Customs will clarify this with the management of the abattoir. Taking the decision to tax crude oil condensate used as fuel, the government recognised the need to prescribe concessional treatment in certain circumstances. For example, use of crude oil or condensate as fuel for pipeline pumping and other activities related to the recovering production of crude petroleum has already been identified as being a circumstance for such concessional treatment.

I point out to Senator Tambling that, on the issue of the particular abattoir, if we gave that a concessional rate we would have to give it to every abattoir in Australia because the excise has to be provided under the constitution; we cannot discriminate. That is something we are not willing to do at the moment because there are so many abattoirs across Australia. How many would have access to the advantage of Central Australia in having the nearby suitable crude oil? However, as I say, the matter is being appealed in the AAT. They may win the case in the AAT and, if they do, they will be eligible for the diesel fuel rebate, which will be of some considerable advantage. I trust that information is of use to Senator Tambling.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that information. I appreciate the efforts that are being taken to address this particular case. Can I have an assurance from the minister that this matter will continue to receive appraisal, consideration and recognition of the very special factors that apply because of the proximity of the Wamboden Abattoir to the Mereenie crude oil facility?
—Yes.

—As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, the Democrats are opposed to the introduction of an administration charge on the diesel fuel rebate scheme. I need to indicate that there was some confusion about the way we voted in the second reading stage and it was because we had indicated that we wanted to deal with all these matters together during the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned in my speech that the idea of placing an administration charge on the claiming of income tax refunds would be decried. I am glad the minister has indicated that this is a tax. The issue here is the same and needs to be similarly defeated. Our position is that, if certain categories of users have been deemed eligible for a rebate, it is not reasonable to expect these people to pay an administration charge to claim the rebate. We need to remember that, under the diesel fuel rebate scheme, farmers, miners and others are only claiming back the money they should not have been required to pay in the first place.

In the case of our primary producers, they stand to lose around $5 million a year through this charge and, as all of us in this chamber must surely know by now, the last thing we can do, or need to do, is impose an additional tax on farmers. Rural communities are doing it tough as it is. I have mentioned several times since coming into this place that many farmers have not seen a farm profit for several years now. To impose an additional tax on them at this time would be quite unreasonable and, as such, the Democrats oppose the introduction of an administration charge on our diesel fuel rebate scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Woodley for his remarks. I think the minister is well aware that we have had a longstanding battle with regard to the imposition of an administration charge. I am aware that some time ago the Australian Democrats indicated that they would be opposing this administration charge. Senator Woodley readily admitted that, with four bills being rolled into one, it was difficult to know exactly where we were at. He had indicated at the time of the vote the other day that the Democrats would be opposing this charge. So, in effect, the intended amendment is to negate the charge. It may have been done earlier, if it had not been for these four bills being rolled into one.

PARA.TAB: I commend Senator Woodley for his comments. We recognise that he is a new senator—we have all been new to this place at one time. When taking legislation through this chamber, it is quite easy to become confused as to exactly where we are. We are opposed to this charge for all of the same reasons Senator Woodley mentioned. As I said, this has been a longstanding saga, but hopefully this is it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise simply to support the amendment. I am opposed to this administration charge. The issues have been thoroughly canvassed, and not only in here. As the minister and others in this chamber know, these issues were canvassed at length by the estimates committee. I am not going to rehearse all of the arguments that were adduced there. I will be supporting the opposition and Senator Woodley on this.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4)Clause 5, page 3, lines 36 to 40, omit the paragraph.
(6)Clause 7, line 22 (page 4) to line 29 (page 5), omit the clause.
(12)Clause 17, page 13, paragraph (d), lines 6 to 10, omit the paragraph.
(14)Clause 19, line 32 (page 13) to line 35 (page 14), omit the clause.
These amendments involve the 12-month indication provision. They can all be dealt with together. I do not need to make any further comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —For many years now the diesel fuel rebate has been indexed twice a year, in February and August, or with each new excise increase. Under the arrangement proposed by this legislation, while the excise rate will continue to be indexed six-monthly in February and August, the rebate will be indexed only once a year. As it is, the system whereby the price of fuel will go up twice a year but the rebate will go up only once sounds bad enough; but, worse still, the government is attempting a sleight of hand, the finer detail of which has been missed by many.

PARA.TAB: If honourable senators look closely at the wording of clauses 7 and 19, they will see that these clauses increase the rebate payable to a level that reflects the excise rate which applied immediately before the new rebate period. In lay terms, that means that the increases on the rebate paid to claimants will always be roughly a year behind the excise increases. The rebate will be indexed at the end of January or in early February each year, but the excise rate will be increased immediately after that and then again six months later. This indexation system is clearly unfair, and we oppose it. It is my belief that the change to the rebate scheme is one of a number of inequitable measures the government is putting up, across various portfolios, in an attempt to fund its irresponsible tax cuts.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not accept the amendments moved by Senator Archer and supported by the Australian Democrats. Although we oppose them, we will not call a division.
