Question so resolved in the negative.
Consideration resumed from 24 November.
Clause 4.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—I have been advised by the clerks that, when the committee was considering the Childcare Rebate Bill on 24 November, the question before the chair was a motion moved by Senator Harradine that further consideration of clause 4 be postponed till after consideration of the remainder of the bill. I shall put that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw that motion, Mr Temporary Chairman.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; motion withdrawn.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It may assist the committee in dealing with this matter if, at this point, I take up with clause 4, dealing with definitions, the point that was at issue when we were last meeting. I think the best way to do that is to draw attention to the amendment circulated by the government that actually amends clause 5, but goes to the point at issue of definitions in clause 4. In talking to that motion, should I be giving notice?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Childs)—That is right; go ahead, Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —When clause 5 comes before the committee, we will move the amendment. I just explain to the committee that, in drafting the child-care rebate legislation, there was a concern to ensure no children were described in a way as to disadvantage them or make them ineligible for the cash rebate received by their parents on their behalf. One of the unintended consequences of that drafting was to change the definition of `couple' and the definition of `family'. In the light of the concern raised, we have now amended clause 5 to change the definition of `family' to make it entirely consistent with the Social Security definition of `couple' and, consistent with that definition of Social Security, therefore to change the definition of `family' under this bill. I am advised that no child will be disadvantaged if we revert to the Social Security definition of a couple and, therefore, change the definition of `family' under this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I wish to place on record that that was an unintended consequence of the drafting. It was a main concern of mine that we concentrate in this legislation on the rights of children—or parents on behalf of children—for cash rebate eligibility, and not use this legislation for a major debate about the definition of `family'. That is a distraction from this bill and properly belongs in the International Year of the Family. So as not to pre-empt that debate, and in the light of assurances that no child will be disadvantaged, I am giving notice of that amendment under clause 5, which I think will help with definitions under clause 4.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that explanation very difficult to understand. If the Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Crowley) is accurately reflecting the views of the department to the Senate, surely no officer who is competent would give to the minister an indication that the children for whom she is concerned—and for whom we are all concerned—would be disadvantaged. How could that be so? I think the minister should let the committee know what advice she received about that particular aspect. What clause in the legislation could a competent officer possibly construe as disadvantaging the parent of a child in that circumstance? The nature of this legislation is such that both parents must be in the paid work force—or seeking paid work—prior to the rebate being claimed. If there is a one-sex couple, one of whom has custody and control of a child, and if that one-sex couple is not regarded as a family, clearly the parent of that child would automatically be eligible to make a claim for a child rebate.

PARA.TAB: Any competent officer would be able to tell the minister that. I ask her to get up in this chamber and let me know and let the chamber know whether she did receive that advice. She is saying that that is the reason she decided to include one-sex couples in the definition of a marriage-like relationship, the definition ultimately of a family. That is the first point. Did the department give the minister the advice that such a parent of a child would be disadvantaged unless the one-sex relationship was regarded as a marriage-like relationship?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make it clear that I do not want to cast any aspersions on officers of my department. I claim responsibility for how this legislation came in here. I am the one who, in the light of Senator Harradine's questions, has agreed that we should move an amendment. The consequences of that definition were unintended. I am assured now that no child will be disadvantaged, which is the point that Senator Harradine was making. I do not believe that there is really anything further to say on this matter. The words are clear. The unintended consequences of that drafting are now being dealt with. The advice is that no child will be disadvantaged. We do not wish to detract from the cash rebate legislation by having a debate about the family. I have properly said that I think that debate belongs in the International Year of the Family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, the Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Crowley) has not responded to the question I asked. Is the minister telling us that this legislation was prepared with the objective in mind that no child will be disadvantaged? She has to accept final responsibility, but is she seriously suggesting that the drafters of this legislation were so ignorant of the outcome of the legislation that they felt it was necessary to include in the definition of a marriage-like relationship a one-sex couple?

PARA.TAB: I refer the minister to the Hansard for Wednesday, 24 November 1993, when I made this comment:

SPEECH.PARA: I may have misunderstood the minister. I would be really interested to hear what she has to say about that. If she is saying that, now, a marriage-like relationship is to be defined as a homosexual relationship or a lesbian relationship for the purposes of this legislation, so far as I can see, that is the first time that a government minister has indicated that those relationships will be regarded as part of a definition of a family. Am I to understand that that is the case or not?
The minister said:
Yes, that is what I said and that is what this legislation means.

Had I not raised the question on the last occasion, for the first time in legislation a homosexual or lesbian relationship would be regarded officially as a marriage-like relationship or as a family. That is a very serious matter.

PARA.TAB: The minister suggests now that that was an oversight, an unintended consequence. It was clearly not an unintended consequence. It was deliberately put in there. This is what is happening in various other areas as well. Only yesterday I was advised of taxpayers' money being spent by the department of health to create a supportive environment in the general community for men having sex with men.

I am not here to question the interior dispositions of people. People are able to make their own decisions and they have to live with the consequences of those decisions. We in this chamber have a responsibility to uphold the fundamental group unit of society—the family. I ask the minister again: unless she was completely ignorant of the consequences, how can she say that this was not a deliberate measure? When I asked her the question last time, she consulted with the advisers before she made that comment.

As Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley is also on record as saying that the family is self-defining. I think it is important on the eve of the year of the family for her to say that the government is not supportive of the definition of the family or a marriage-like relationship to include a homosexual or lesbian couple. The minister has a responsibility to get up here and say that.

The attempt to include these measures in the definition of family and marriage-like relationships is being done through the back door and it was attempted in this legislation. It went through the minister's department; it knew about it and her advisers knew about it. If they did not, they are blind, deaf, dumb and incompetent. They knew about it because they advised the minister when she asked them, after I asked the question. Is the minister telling us that they did not know that this occurs in no other legislation? Is she suggesting to this chamber that that was an oversight by them or by her? It is absolutely incredible that this is the first time this has occurred in legislation. The minister is saying, `Oh, it's an oversight', just because I happened to raise it in a question. As I said on that occasion, I was flabbergasted by her response because I knew it had no basis.

It has gone through all of the measures that the minister's department adopts, it has gone through the House of Representatives and it has come to this chamber. It has only been stopped because I asked the question. That is probably because, generally speaking, people in this chamber have a great deal of respect for the competence of advisers and public servants. But on this occasion, clearly the minister's competence is in question. If she wants to do these things, she should do them out in the open and make it very clear what she, as Minister for Family Services, means. In the International Year of the Family does she intend to include one sex relationships as part of the definition of a marriage-like relationship or a family?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) will not be supporting the government amendment to exclude same-sex couples from the definition of a family for the purpose of the Childcare Rebate Bill. I understand the reluctance of the government to press this issue in a forum devoted to another human rights matter—that of the affordability and availability of child care. I am also aware of the danger of setting a precedent that may work to disadvantage lesbian and gay people. However, the Greens (WA) cannot support an amendment that specifically excludes lesbian and gay relationships from the definition of a family and ignores the reality of family life in some sections of our diverse community.

PARA.TAB: The public and legal recognition of same-sex relationships is long overdue. The lack of recognition is in breach of international human rights obligations and contrary to the government's ongoing commitment to equality for lesbian and gay people. At the World Conference on Human Rights in Vienna, Australia's United Nations Ambassador and head of the Australian delegation, Penny Wensley, highlighted sexual preference as an area of discrimination yet to receive serious and detailed attention in the United Nations. Ambassador Wensley said that she hoped the conference would mark the start of a process of discussion and dialogue aimed at ensuring that individuals are not discriminated against on the grounds of sexual preference and that Australia supported such moves.

The government has demonstrated in this speech its commitment to equal rights for lesbian and gay people, lifting the ban on lesbian and gay men in the armed forces, and its support for the Tasmanian gay law reform case currently before the United Nations Human Rights Committee. I understand there have been representations to the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, and the Minister for Justice, Mr Kerr, calling for an Australian Law Reform Commission inquiry into equality before the law for lesbian and gay people. I urge the government to take advantage of the opportunity of having this debate raised in this place to demonstrate its commitment to equality for these people by instigating measures such as the law reform inquiry. This issue requires immediate and serious attention in its own forum. It is essential to help protect lesbian and gay people from inadvertent or deliberate discrimination now and in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to follow on the question posed by Senator Harradine. The Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) clearly stated previously what her position was and what her intention was. Now she states that she did not know what the consequence of that would be. Which position are we to believe from the minister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not getting too many responses from the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley). She is silent, because she knows as well as I do what was on here: this was a try-on. It was a try-on and she knows it. It was an absolute try-on. The reason that I say that it was a try-on is that the minister knew what she was about. In her speech on 23 November at the launch of the ABS's Australian Families, she actually stated that at the time of the survey the ABS did not include same-sex families—the minister's words. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of the survey the ABS did not include same-sex families in their definition of family. I am pleased to say that the ABS has recently reviewed this policy and, in future, homosexual couples will be included in surveys.

That is what the minister said on 23 November, and it is on record that that is what her view is. Then on 24 November, the next day, she comes in here with a piece of legislation which she then says has a marriage-like relationship which includes homosexual and lesbian couples. I think the minister has a good deal to answer for in respect of that. She needs to answer the questions that I have raised and the question that Senator Herron has just raised.

PARA.TAB: The ABS had certain advice from some people about that. Some of that advice came from the Office of the Status of Women. I would like to know what the advice was from the office in respect of that particular matter. The ABS is quite entitled, for statistical purposes, to look and see who is about. I assume there is no objection, in statistical terms, to looking at who is in a household, whether they be called household units or other things. It is a different matter to define a family to include homosexual and lesbian couples.

This is not a question of sexual preference, as Senator Margetts raised. Frankly, it is probably quite the contrary in respect of this particular bill. Senator Margetts's opposition to the government's amendment would possibly mean that the parent of a child in a homosexual relationship would not be eligible for a child-care rebate. So it is not a question of discrimination on that ground at all. It is clearly a question of the definition of a family.

This minister is saying, on the eve of the International Year of the Family, that same sex couples are able to be defined as a family. That is what she is saying. That is what she said at the release of the ABS survey and that is what is being said in this bill. Is Senator Crowley suggesting to this committee that she did not do that deliberately, that that was just an unintended consequence because of her desire to ensure that there was no disadvantage to particular children? We have shown that there is no disadvantage to children in this particular respect. Senator Crowley has absolutely no argument and no excuse for what she has done, other than to declare that she was completely ignorant of the operation of this measure, as were her departmental advisers from whom she got advice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made my position quite clear. It seems that Senator Harradine is still suggesting that I am trying to use this bill as an underhanded or sneaky piece of legislation to define a family. It is precisely because I do not want to be sneaky or underhanded, or distract from the debate in the International Year of the Family, that I have brought in this amendment.

PARA.TAB: As to what the ABS survey does, or what advice the OSW gives, that is entirely irrelevant to this legislation. If that is something I can assist Senator Harradine with at another time, I certainly will. Senator Harradine is not correct in saying that this is the first time that legislation has defined families or couples in this way. I refer Senator Harradine to the migration regulations legislation, 1993. It is not as though it is without precedent.

I have also been advised that it has been proposed at other times but that it has not been proceeded with. However, they are distractions. We are dealing with cash rebate legislation. I take the point about pre-empting debate in the International Year of the Family as a very serious one. That is why this legislation has been amended to deal with the matter of cash rebate. We are not trying to use it as a carriage for the debate about the family. That is for debate in the International Year of the Family, and that is where it properly belongs. I do not have anything further to add.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are very disappointed that the government has backed down on this issue at a time when we are beginning to have this debate. I agree with the minister that we should be looking at it in the International Year of the Family, but that has already begun. We cannot keep sweeping this issue aside and hope it will just go away. As we have had some of the debate in here already, some three or four hours as part of the industrial relations legislation, we believe this would be a good opportunity to continue this debate. I also acknowledge what Senator Harradine has been saying, that by the government's amendment, which I understand is to the next clause, same-sex couples will indeed be advantaged. As Senator Harradine has reminded us, the definition in the bill is that both parents have to be working, studying or in training before that rebate can be paid. If same-sex couples are no longer going to be treated as a family, only one of them, the parent actually has to be studying or training for that rebate to be able to be claimed. The other member of the couple could indeed be staying at home.

PARA.TAB: It really does not make any sense that we are avoiding this debate again. Yes, I know we are at a very difficult time of the year, we are pressed for time and we have a lot of legislation to get through in this chamber today. With better organisation of the government's program we could have, for example, sat last Friday and dealt with some of these issues that really cannot just be continually ignored. We believe that we should be sticking with what the government originally planned, that is, the original definition. We will not be supporting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister is resiling from the position she stated previously. She is by moving this amendment and she has not answered satisfactorily the question that was put to her. Does she resile from the definition that she gave previously or does she not: yes or no?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are moving an amendment, it is quite clear that the definition of `family' has changed. I think that is beyond dispute. I am actually moving an amendment to make the definition of `family' clear.
—Are you resiling from your previous position?

—Senator, this could go on for a long time and I do not think we would be advantaged. I have said that the debate about the definition of `family' properly belongs in the year; this is not the bill to have carriage of it. To expedite matters about cash rebates, I have circulated an amendment to make clear the definition of `family'. This definition is in line with the social security definition of `couple' and therefore `family'. We will leave the debate about what the family is, or can be, in law for a later time.

—The minister has clarified it to the extent that she has stated that she is not resiling from a previous position. She could have said that instead of prolonging this toing-and-froing and yet it is contradictory. The minister will also agree it is contradicting the amendment that she is now moving.

—I think it is very important. At least the Democrats and the Greens are honest and straightforward about it, whilst the minister and the government are doing things through the back door. Senator Margetts mentioned questions were being raised with the Minister for Justice and the Attorney-General. Yes, I understand there is a task force looking into that particular matter of legal equality. One of the chief people in that operation will be Mr Bill Bowtell, whose support of the lobby group is very well known. I think the minister does owe it to the committee to respond to the question as to whether she is now resiling from what she clearly has in mind.

PARA.TAB: I quoted what she said the day before she came into this chamber and defended the definition of `marriage-like relationship' in this particular bill to include same-sex couples. On that day she described same-sex families as families; she described a homosexual relationship as a same-sex family. Does the minister resile from that? As we go into the International Year of the Family, is that the government's view? Is that the Prime Minister's view? Is that the cabinet's view? A lot of people want to know. A lot of ordinary people in this country want to know if that is the government's view, so come out and say it openly. Do not get the law changed by the backdoor method, as the minister tried to do on this occasion. Do not present us with a try-on. Be straightforward and honest about it. If, as the Minister for Family Services, she cannot get up in this chamber and say, `No, that is not my view. No, that is not the government's view', then she ought not to be the Minister for Family Services. The minister must have thought about these particular matters, or is she going to let it go by default?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much point in Senator Harradine asking again and again a question that is a distraction. The government's view, and my view, is quite clear in this legislation. We have foreshadowed an amendment. If the honourable senator wishes to have a debate about the Australian Bureau of Statistics definition and what I have said in other forums, or what I or anyone might mean by a self-defining family, let us do that in some other place during the International Year of the Family. What I did at the ABS was to read from the back of the ABS journal its definition. I do not wish to debate here what the honourable senator is ascribing to me; I think it is a matter for another place. He asks what is the cabinet's view and what is the government's view. That is the endorsed amendment in this legislation. That is beyond doubt.
—So we have it now that the cabinet's view, the government's view, is that the definition of `marriage-like relationship' and `family' will not, and does not, include same-sex couples. Is that right?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is to come up in one moment. The amendment has been provided to Senator Harradine. I believe he understand the words of that amendment. It says very clearly that a couple will be people of the opposite sex.

—The Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Crowley) said that this is a distraction. It is not. It is fundamental. As Senator Harradine says, by her moving of this amendment she accepts the definition within that amendment. The question is: does she, or does she not? If she does not, then she has to consider her position. She has stated her own view previously in a definition that she gave. Now she is moving an amendment and she says that the government is moving it; and I accept that. It clearly defines what the position is.

PARA.TAB: If she does not hold that position, if she does not believe that, she should tell us. She should have the courage of her convictions like the Greens and the Democrats. They have stated their position, and the minister should state hers. We will interpret that. I think it is a correct interpretation that that is the government's position, because it is moving the amendment, and it should rest there. Does the minister accept that position? She is moving this amendment, and I take it that she does. Therefore, the corollary of that is that she must be implicitly, if not explicitly, resiling from her present position. Is she resiling from her present position? She does not have the courage to tell us whether she will or will not resile. I think in the International Year of the Family, as the Minister for Family Services, she should state what her position is. She cannot say it is a distraction.
Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a non-contentious speech to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993, which is a non-contentious bill. Having cleared it with the government whip, I seek leave to incorporate the speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: As usual, this bill contains a number of amendments to the tariff:
many minor administrative changes.
A few more of a substantial nature, some already announced by the government.
Coalition will not be opposing the bill.
Some of the more substantive amendments merit comment.
Especially amendments to the Australian system of tariff preferences.
Developing countries (D.C.s) Have been assisted by tariff preferences for about the last 30 years.
Since 1986 this has been through tariff rates 5% lower than the general rate.
Unless general rate is 5% or less when D.C. rate will be zero.
A very valuable concession, or encouragement to these countries, many of which have experienced spectacular growth and development and today can hardly be called developing countries.
e.g., the Asian tigers.
In 1991, imports by Australia from D.C.s totalled $13 billion, or 26% of total imports.
Over 60% of this was from 6 countries: Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore, China, Hong Kong and Malaysia.
The government announced in March 1991 that the margin of preference for imports from Singapore, Taiwan, Hong Kong and the Republic of Korea would begin to be phased out from 1 July 1992.
These countries have clearly developed to a stage where they are strong world exporting countries with rates of economic growth well above that of Australia.
Under the measures in this bill their tariff preference will not suddenly be withdrawn. It will be frozen until the general rate falls to the same level.
General rates will then apply to all imports from these countries.
An associated amendment dealing with tariff preferences in this bill abolishes the preferential rates of duty on a wide range of goods imported from all countries
except forum island countries, and
42 of the least advanced countries (nominated by the United Nations).
The goods involved are textiles, clothing, footwear, chemicals, plastics, rubber and leather goods, fruit juice, canned fruit, sugar and dried fruit.
The margin of preference will likewise be phased out by freezing tariffs for specified goods from developing countries until the general rate falls to the D.C. preference rate.
This measure is overdue and will be welcomed by Australian firms involved, particularly as many restructure to meet the effects of reduced protection over the coming years.
Need for government to further assist the industries through greater micro economic reform, e.g., shipping, transport, labour.
As mentioned earlier, the coalition will not oppose these amendments dealing with developing country preference
but stresses the need to continually review these concessional arrangements.
Australian industry can point to other anomalies, especially as industries in particular countries emerge to a stage which is fully competitive in the world situation.
No longer developing.

Under the Australia-Canada trade agreement, Canadian carpets can be imported at concessional rates, currently 22%. Following discussion with Canada, this bill now provides for the eventual removal of this preference.
The Australian carpet industry is protected by a general tariff which is phasing down from 32% to 15% by the year 2000, currently 29%.
Canadian preference will be frozen until general rate phases down to the concessional level, i.e., 30 June 1997.
The Australian carpet industry is a most important australian industry:
50 manufacturers, with 4 majors supplying 60% of all carpet sold in Australia.
Employs 4500 persons.
Market sales in Australia totalled 45.5 million square metres in year to February 1992.
Wool and wool rich carpets make up approximately 29% of carpet sales.
Imports totalled approximately 5.0 million square metres and exports 1.6 million square metres in the year ending 30 June 1991.
Approximately 15% of Australian carpet manufacturer's requirements of raw carpet wool are supplied by Australian wool producers.
Most of the remainder is from New Zealand.
Another important amendment concerns the adjustment to the excise on Avgas: a reduction of just over 3 cents a litre as a result of implementation of user pays principle.
Resulting from aerodromes transferring to local ownership and control.
The direct charging of aircraft operators for firefighting services at aerodromes, and
provision of weather forecasting services by the Bureau of Meteorology on a cost recovered basis.

A further amendment recognises the establishment of the independent Czech and Slovak Republics on 1 January 1993. Now each are accorded the concessional duty treatment which was received by the former Czech and Slovak Federative Republic.
Adjustments are also made to the tariff to:
remove an anomaly in the classification of needlecraft and tapestry kits imported from New Zealand. Both are now free of duty.
Remove a further anomaly so that boxes of not fewer than five handkerchiefs, and one design and/or colour can be imported duty free.
I indicated earlier that the coalition does not oppose this bill.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests for amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: DOMESTIC MEAT PREMISES CHARGE BILL 1993EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGES LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Similar to the action just taken by Senator Archer, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a non-contentious second reading speech relating to the Domestic Meat Premises Charge Bill 1993 and a related bill. I have discussed this with the government whip.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Domestic Meat Premises Charge Bill will implement a per premises charge on domestic meat establishments where the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is responsible for domestic meat inspection.
I understand this is the first of a series of bills to restructure AQIS—the Commonwealth's meat inspection agency—as well as shed some 750 jobs.
Currently, AQIS employs about 2600 Commonwealth and State staff.
When this Bill was introduced the second reading speech referred to a three tier system of charging for inspection.
—There was to be a premises charge—which this Bill refers to;
—There was to be an inspector charge—which is the current system; and—There was to be a throughput charge of about 47 cents per beast for every animal going through the meatworks.
While the Federal Coalition supports the shedding of surplus jobs, we did not believe the proposed method would deliver adequate savings in meat inspection costs.

We also believed the throughput charge would discriminate against companies undertaking quality control measures in order to reduce inspection charges, by charging them an inspection fee per beast when in fact they did not have any AQIS inspectors on the premises.
In our view it would have been a disincentive for companies to undertake much needed increases in productivity and more responsibility for their own quality control.
At that time we said the Federal Coalition would not support this Bill unless the Federal Government withdrew its proposals for this throughput charge.
We also sent this Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs and following public hearings the Committee noted:-
. the unanimous view of industry is that there should not be a three tier structure involving a throughput charge;
. a majority of industry organisations, but not the Meat and Allied Trades Federation (MATFA), support a two tier charging arrangement;
. AQIS will continue discussions with MATFA "with the objective of accommodating specific concerns with the two tier structure";
. the charging model has been expanded from 12 to 18 categories;
. the concerns of establishments which have multiple operators in a single premises have been addressed; and
. consultative and review mechanisms will be established.
As a result of our efforts, the Government has agreed to drop the throughput charge and has been discussing a two tier system with industry.

I am advised that the Meat and Allied Trades Federation, with the exception of its Victorian Branch, and farmer organisations, with the exception of the Victorian Farmers' Federation, have now given support for a meat premises charge. However there are still some concerns that individual operators might be disadvantaged.

In view of these developments the Coalition will now support this Bill for a Domestic Meat Premises Charge but we will closely watch the regulations which the Government needs to establish the amount of this charge.
If these charges are seen to discriminate against or cause unnecessary hardship to individual operators we will seek Democrat support to move to disallow these charges.
We have to ensure that these premises charges are not just a way of hiding the real cost of inspection and that operators are not paying for anything other than the service provided.
The real value in a single per inspector charge is that industry can readily calculate the add-on costs which can be high and embarrassing, particularly to inspectors in the field.
Today a meat inspector is paid around $32,000, allowing for overtime.
Yet, they are charged out to abattoirs at a rate in excess of $70,000 which only goes to prove there are too many people and too much money is being wasted in middle and top management.

The Minister has promised to reduce the per inspector charge down to about $59,000. However there is little point to a per inspector charge being reduced if the premises charge negates all of the gains.
The Government must ensure that the total cost of inspection goes down whether it is in one or two tiers.
The Shadow Minister for Primary Industry picked up on that point when he told the other place:

". . . there is really something lacking in the morality of the situation where producers effectively have to pay the redundancy packages involved when there have been meat inspectors employed in the last few years . . . when the service must have known that it was already overstaffed.
"The Government's inability to sort out the staffing levels and work practices is at the heart of the problem. If these patterns were repeated in private enterprise the result would be bankruptcy."
For a long time, we had about 63 meat inspectors stationed in towns and other places around Australia where there were no abattoirs.
Last year the Meat Research Corporation looked at the efficacy of inspectors in Australia, Argentina and New Zealand and other countries.
It found that, in America, an inspector would get through 300 head a shift.
In Australia, 79 head. Mind you, that figure reflects erratic plant throughput, inefficiencies of work practices on the slaughter floor and the tally system.
We also have too many inspectors on the floor.
About 900 inspectors are in employment but there are another 600 on the payroll, as well as hundreds in offices, many of whom are surplus.

There must be greater progress towards quality assurance programs so that companies become more responsible for their own inspection, just as there must be a concerted effort to straighten out work practices.
By way of background, the Government promised in this year's Budget to reform AQIS. I believe this was prompted by the Federal Coalition's policy to cut AQIS by $20 million in total outlays.
Mind you, when Fightback was launched, the Government said it was not possible to reduce AQIS's costs. It has now decided that it is possible.

The Government also wants to encourage the Australian industry to take more responsibility for quality assurance. That has been long-standing Coalition policy and we are pleased to see the Government pick it up.

The Government's original plan for a three tier system did not offer sufficient encouragement or reward for processors to undertake their own quality assurance, and for this reason we are pleased that the Government has agreed to make the changes suggested by the Coalition and industry.
After all, there is no need to have inspectors in domestic works.
Inspection of these works can be conducted on a "flying squad" basis.

But the three-tier approach would have ensured that even when a meatworks met all the quality assurance requirements and no longer had inspectors in the plant, it would still have to pay an amount per beast for inspection.
The Federal Coalition supports the downsizing of AQIS because it is in the long-term interests of the meat industry.

In view of the Government's assurances that it will not introduce a throughput charge and will ensure that its premises charge will not unfairly disadvantage any particular operator the Coalition will now support this legislation.

However we give notice that we will pay close attention to the regulations when they are formulated to ensure that any charges for domestic meat premises do not add to the inspection cost burden and that the Government is indeed working to reduce the overall cost to industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in the debate on the Domestic Meat Premises Charge Bill and the Export Inspection Charges Laws Amendment Bill because the bills received a lot of attention from the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. I think the committee achieved quite a lot with the legislation. It passed through the House of Representatives with little time for consideration and certainly no time for consultation. I am not going to let it go through this place without having a few words to say about it. It is good to see that the chairman of the rural and regional affairs committee, Senator Burns, is in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Given the structure of the legislation, the coalition opposed the bills. When the bills arrived in the Senate, they were referred to the Senate rural and regional affairs committee, with an original reporting date of 22 November, which was extended until 7 December to allow due processes of consultation to occur. Modestly, I have to say that the rural and regional affairs committee continues to demonstrate how committees to which bills are referred should function. We have demonstrated repeatedly, on matters such as resource security legislation, the deer industry and now the meat processing industry, that consultation with industry very often brings about legislation with which most people become happy.

We have legislation now before the parliament that is, by and large, understood and accepted by industry to a great degree. Some reservations remain, and I will deal with those shortly, but what is in place now, I think, is going in the right direction. Additionally, we now have a federal government department that has benefited from the consultative processes and has become more understanding of the industry and more accessible to it.

In dealing with the bills, the committee invited several groups and leading processors to address it. The committee also took the opportunity, which it often does, to visit and inspect processing works around the country. In this instance we went down to Geelong to appreciate the issues relevant to the bills. During the course of those discussions, it became apparent that there was considerable disquiet within the industry. The main areas of concern were the proposed three-tier charging regime, the throughput charge, the equity of the premises charge, the effective abandoning of the three-tier principle on future charging structures, and the level of consultation by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. Overriding all of this was the stated aim of AQIS to reform its processes and become more efficient and effective.

There were considerable doubts expressed—I certainly repeated them often—as to whether this legislation would deliver the desired reforms, whether it was not better to throw away the legislation and start again or stay with the single per-inspector charge, as is the case now, and make sure that those charges come down by reforming the quantity of work done, getting a better quality assurance program and that sort of thing. We found numerous examples of a government department that was remote from the industry it was purportedly trying to serve, of correspondence never answered, of concerns never addressed. This legislation was a result of that lack of consultation.

The legislation essentially implements a premises charge on domestic meatworks where AQIS inspectors are employed. However, the system intended to operate post-passage of this bill was a three-tiered charging regime made up of a current charge per inspector per unit of time, a fixed annual charge per premises and a throughput or volume charge. Whilst these bills address only the second point—that of a fixed annual charge or a premises charge—it was not appropriate for the rural and regional affairs committee to take it in isolation of industry's other concerns about present and proposed cost structures.

The second reading speech of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) foreshadowed further legislation to cover a throughput charge, a fixed price per beast process charge. To those outside the rural industry, the principal matters dealt with in the legislation are complex. I do not believe time would be well spent in explaining the cost structure of the meat processing industry. Suffice to say that the proposed regulations were flawed and showed considerable discrimination or unintended consequences for some companies. The proposals were particularly obnoxious to the Cattle Council of Australia, which argued that the concept of a three-tier charge had already been put out to industry in 1992 and was rejected at that time. It felt that the industry did not want such an arrangement and that AQIS was merely trying to force processors into costings they did not need to make.

The Cattle Council was of a view that charges should accurately reflect costings but that the proposed legislation was inflated to allow fat in the present AQIS administration. The Cattle Council executive took their concerns to a full Cattle Council meeting at Wagga during the AMLC annual general meeting and at that meeting resolved to support a two-tiered charging system conditional upon the capping of the per meat inspector charge at a level that reflects the actual cost associated with the inspector's time and service, and the broadening of the categories applying for the establishment charge such that effort by innovative operators to adopt quality assurance programs and various cutting edge technologies were accommodated.

Subsequent to that meeting, AQIS convened a meeting with the Cattle Council, various meat processing groups and industry representatives at which several options were canvassed. In effect, the result was a choice of a two-tiered charging regime with 12 categories or the adoption of a two-tiered regime involving 18 categories with varying timetables. The increase in category option provided a more accurate assessment of costs. For example, an abattoir with an export licence but low-volume exports would pay something like $6,190 in registration charges this year, moving to $10,000-odd in 1997-98, while one licensed for export with US and EC listing would pay $49,516 in 1994 and $82,527 by 1997-98. This has by and large been accepted as a more equitable cost carve-up. Under the original proposed charging regime there were only eight categories and numerous abattoirs would have been unfairly charged.

The minister had argued in his second reading speech that he was seeking a system that had the objectives of efficiency, equity, consistency, transparency and simplicity. The Cattle Council, amongst others, argued that the legislation was not based on equity, it was not transparent, and it would not produce the desired efficiencies.

One processor particularly disadvantaged was one close to my home—Gunnedah abattoir. Gunnedah abattoir would have been hard hit by the new rules and yet, prior to the committee hearings, had been denied any opportunity to put its case. Ray Grout, the abattoir manager, appeared before the committee and argued that the new charges would cost his abattoir dearly. He outlined a frightening scenario where his works would be charged on a multiple of levels simply because no-one had thought about consulting him. It would have possibly put his works out of business.

Gunnedah abattoir has separately registered lease portions within a single premises. Its situation was one completely overlooked by AQIS when drafting the charging models. By appearing before the committee and in subsequent discussions with AQIS, Gunnedah abattoir was able to have the charging levels more accurately reflect the true position in the market. That would not have happened had the legislation been processed through this chamber as so many other pieces of legislation are. This government is poor at consultation. AQIS has a very poor track record in communication with industry. That is an appalling—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—That is correct, Senator Panizza. That is an appalling situation when one considers that it has just increased its consultancy cost by over 100 per cent in the last 12 months. Nevertheless, in drafting this legislation, the draftsman failed to take into consideration the myriad of Gunnedah abattoirs. The department has not done its homework properly and, while the committee endorsed the legislation and recommended no amendment to it, it did so in the knowledge that there had already been considerable change by the department in its fee structures.

PARA.TAB: There are two other areas which need to be canvassed. The first is the move within the industry to a quality assurance scheme. Under the original arrangement there would have been little incentive for works to have moved towards quality assurance. The preferred 18-level option now supported will preserve the incentive for quality assurance inspection arrangements.

Another benefit to come from the industry consultations was an undertaking by AQIS to reconvene a charging review committee to act as a forum between industry and AQIS to assess the progress of the two-tiered charging mechanism and to review AQIS cost structures and operations in the period up to 30 June 1995. After 1995, new charges will be applied based on what the review committee determines. The review committee will also review arrangements for establishments with separately leased portions during the next two years transition period. That wants to be qualified, and we might have to have a talk about that later.
However—and I make this a clear warning to AQIS—the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs in its report said:

SPEECH.PARA: It places on record its intention to monitor the reforms of AQIS and, if necessary, seek a specific reference on this matter from the Senate if it does not go ahead with its cost saving structures.
I can assure AQIS that I will be monitoring very closely its costings and efforts to reform and the timetable for those efficiencies to which it aspires.

PARA.TAB: I still have some residual reservations about this legislation. Whilst sound in intent, it is still perhaps only tinkering at the edges of reform. Certainly not everyone in the industry is happy. Let us look at what the reforms really are. In the year 1992-93, the actual revenue coming in to AQIS is $80-odd million; by 1997-98, it is going to be about $70-odd million—a saving of $10 million. There are people who are in category 15, for example, which is export boning, European Community listed and export slaughter, no US or EC listing, and in that category their charges per premises go from $38,000-odd to $60,000-odd. So there is a bit of an extra charge for some of those people.

Last week the Victorian Farmers Federation contacted my office, claiming there had not been the formal consultation process required and the Victorian domestic meat industry was opposed to the bills even with the changes. The Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia echoed those objections. Both groups want a single per inspector charge to remain, claiming it would encourage the industry to move towards quality assurance.

The committee took evidence on the issue. Clearly there is an argument to be made that, under the present cost structure, smaller, non-continuous works are not paying their fair share of inspection costs. That needed to change if that were the case. However, the VFF says that it should be possible for AQIS to incorporate as many charges in the per inspectorate rate as are necessary for AQIS fully to recover the cost of providing the service.
Domestic meat processors are also opposed to a premises charge, arguing it will be another deterrent to the domestic industry embracing quality assurance programs. A letter from the VFF said:

SPEECH.PARA: Domestic meat processors . . . believe the introduction of a premises or registration charge as a component of AQIS's fee-for-service charging will be a deterrent to widespread uptake of domestic quality assurance . . .
It continued:
Industry has been planning quality assurance process for at least two years in the belief that efficient users of AQIS's services were to be fully rewarded.
The Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia said:

Industry has been planning quality assurance approaches for at least two years in the belief that efficient users of AQIS' services were to be fully rewarded. The Government has openly encouraged industry to give priority to quality assurance to offset increased inspection costs, and the industry has responded by seeking to install quality systems which improve . . .
It continues:
Two major domestic quality assurance ventures have commenced on the basis that the Government will safeguard industry's large investment through its incentive policy of single per-inspector charging.

The Refrigerated Warehouses and Transport Association of Australia remains opposed, arguing that the new charges will result in the deregistration of approximately eight export cold store establishments, or 50 per cent of those currently registered. It argues that, if cold stores are to be categorised, there should be only two categories: those with and those without quality assurance programs in place.

PARA.TAB: I have reservations about how committed the department is to adherence to a true user-pays system. However, I am prepared to give the department the benefit of the doubt. It has made genuine attempts to accommodate the concerns of industry and has listened, admittedly belatedly and perhaps a little unwillingly at times, to industry and politicians. The legislation, while not technically amended, is better structured. Its implications and its outcomes have been improved because of the Senate committee's process.

As I have already outlined, not all sectors of the industry are happy. There is an argument to suggest that these fees will have the net effect of forcing the smaller operators out of the market. If it is because in the past they have not carried the fair share of the cost of inspection, then so be it. If they are forced out—and maybe a lot will be in your state of Victoria, Mr Acting Deputy President, because they have been in contact with me a lot about this matter—because of unfair, inflated costings by government inspection services, then this parliament has a duty to intervene. I have already flagged my interest in ensuring that AQIS delivers quality at an affordable price. It is a challenge for AQIS, but one I am confident that AQIS is capable of meeting provided it has the appropriate cost consciousness. It needs to establish that and this legislation provides an opportunity for it to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with many of the things that Senator Brownhill said in speaking to the Domestic Meat Premises Charge Bill and the Export Inspection Charges Laws Amendment Bill. One of the things that was very positive and a plus was the fact that the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs on this occasion had some time in which to hold the inquiry, and it was helpful to talk with the people who could make known to us an objective and collective point of view. Also, the minister, his advisers and the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service were still in a fluid position in relation to discussions and consultations with the processors, so there was nothing so concrete that it could not be altered.

PARA.TAB: Even though it had been flagged that the three-tier system was a possibility, it became obvious very quickly to the members of the committee, and it was certainly the view of many of the witnesses that talked to us, that the third tier was not a goer but that two tiers were. The two-tier system was put into place because many of the processors wanted that to occur. The bigger processors particularly felt that the amount of money they were paying into the system was greater than it should have been and that there were smaller processors and medium processors who really were not making the correct contribution. So they themselves wanted the two-tier system to sort out that question.

It is true that in the process there seemed not to be sufficient flexibility and people could be somewhat discriminated against. But again the discussions went on and we were able to get a number of further categories that certainly satisfied that problem. It is clear that AQIS has got an attitude to reducing the number of inspectors. It talks about 25 per cent. In my view, in the long term that will reduce quite considerably the cost to processors.

I believe that the long-term solution is the quality assurance program. I was pleased, as the chairman of the committee, along with other members, to look at at least one domestic shed, Herds, which had gone a long way along that path. It must be said that AQIS has played a fairly important role in this regard by setting up the sorts of programs and training that are required and also, as an organisation, to carry out the necessary auditing work. So I really believe that it was a good inquiry. I believe that the outcome was fair and reasonable in the circumstances although, as I always say about any legislation, not perfect. I think that we are now on the right track and I, with Senator Brownhill and other people, will make certain that that track is a straight one, that it goes down the line and that it will deliver benefits not only to the meat processors but to the community generally.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION (SEA DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1993ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION (ALLIGATOR RIVERS REGION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing two bills today, and I turn my attention, firstly, to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill 1993. Because of the international nature of the shipping industry, it is obvious that pollution of the marine environment is an important international matter. Marine pollution is a current issue, as there is an amount of community concern that unseaworthy ships may discharge pollutants into the marine environment, especially as they pass the Great Barrier Reef.

PARA.TAB: The federal government is responsible for pollution from ships in Australia's high seas, and it passed legislation in 1960 to minimise the incidence of oil tanker accidents. Since then, Australia has ratified a number of conventions relating to accidental sea pollution and dumping, and this bill is ratifying the latest convention.

The coalition will not oppose the bill, which amends the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 in line with the Protocol for the Prevention of Pollution of the South Pacific Region by Dumping. This is one of two protocols to the South Pacific region environment protection convention. Australia has already ratified the other protocol.

The protocol is a regional agreement, consistent with the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, known as the London Convention 1972, which Australia accepted in its sea dumping act of 1972. The bill needs to be changed minimally to comply with the protocol.

One amendment extends geographical coverage of the sea dumping act to cover both the Australian fishing zone and the continental shelf where the two do not coincide. The other adds the dumping of organophosphorous compounds to the existing list of banned substances.

The financial impact is minimal. The practical effect of applying the SPREP dumping protocol to all Australian waters and the continental shelf is that it will be an offence to dump organophosphorous compounds in the Indian and Southern oceans as well as the SPREP convention area. As Tasmania is the only state with a separate sea dumping act, it has agreed to bring it into line with the federal act.

I turn to the second piece of legislation that we are considering and refer some comments specifically to the Environment Protection (Alligators Rivers Region) Amendment Bill, which incorporates the Office of the Supervising Scientist into the Commonwealth protection agency. The Office of the Supervising Scientist was established in 1978 to research the effect of uranium mining on the Alligator Rivers Region in the Northern Territory. Naturally, I would take a very close and personal interest in this agency.

The Alligator Rivers Region is centred some 220 kilometres east of Darwin in the Northern Territory. The Kakadu National Park, which is managed by the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, lies within the Alligator Rivers Region and includes the entire catchments of the East, West and South Alligator Rivers.

In 1977, following consideration of the recommendations of the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry, or what is commonly known as the Fox commission, the Commonwealth decided to allow uranium mining operations in the Alligator Rivers Region. As a prerequisite, the Fox commission recommended the establishment of the Office of the Supervising Scientist and envisaged it to be a small research unit which would establish a base from which conclusions in respect of environmental damage can later be drawn.

The Ranger uranium mine has been operating since 1980 and is regarded as one of the most tightly regulated and heavily scrutinised mines in the world. Even with such close monitoring, no significant environmental detriment has been detected outside the lease area. Over the past 13 years, the Office of Supervising Scientist operations have cost more than $100 million in 1993 dollars. There is certainly considerable scope for achieving economies, both of scale and of improved efficiency.

This amendment bill aims for more efficient operations of the Office of the Supervising Scientist and for improved working relationships with the relevant organisations. However, the operators of the mine, Energy Resources of Australia Ltd, naturally have a number of concerns with regard to the legislation. They have, in their normal and routine contact with me, advised me of some of the issues that have arisen and of their consideration and their concerns with these particular proposals—certainly, the requirement by ERA to pay the equivalent of the export levy but under a different name. This would ensure the ongoing financial support for the OSS.

The focus for research would be lost if the senior scientific review panel, as originally proposed, was made subservient to a pseudo-coordinating committee which would simply reintroduce the political agenda in the setting of research priorities, direction and appropriate research, and a lack of acceptance that ERA needs the relief of removing the export levy to allow it to compete fairly in the international uranium market. ERA is prepared to commit a fair-shared annual research budget of about $5 million per year to achieve well directed and timely environmental research work.

I believe the company is opposed to any executive role for the consultative committee, and the technical committee should provide advice directly to the Commonwealth and supervising authorities and should have a membership made up of only the relevant government authorities and mining companies. ERA is supportive of the existing proposals to revise the working arrangements between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory to effectively use the existing regulatory powers and is strongly opposed to any amendments providing regulatory powers to the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

The Commonwealth government has initiated a formal review of research requirements in the Alligator Rivers region, and the issue of the uranium export levy and more efficient funding arrangements should be determined following that review. I also point to the important involvement of the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy in this particular process. As many honourable senators are aware, a number of us feel that the relationship between the Northern Territory government agencies, the Northern Territory University, the Department of Mines and Energy and the conservation commission of the Northern Territory should be embraced in this important matter.

What the bill fails to address is the reduction of unnecessary cost and duplication. Certainly, the bill does not reduce OSS staff and operations to the levels proposed initially by Fox. Ranger will continue to be one of the most tightly regulated and heavily scrutinised mines in the world. The Office of the Supervising Scientist will continue to cost one hundred times more than Fox ever envisaged. It will be interesting also to watch any change in roles that the OSS has had exclusively with regard to the operation in the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory and to see whether other mines that may well be developed in the future, particularly at Roxby Downs in South Australia, are also embraced in these proposals. They will need careful monitoring, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on both the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill 1993 and the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Amendment Bill 1993. Firstly, the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill 1993 is supported by the Greens, although we would strongly urge that the Australian government make representations to the other members of the South Pacific regional environment program to upgrade the SPREP protocol for the prevention of pollution of the South Pacific region by dumping.

PARA.TAB: The upgrade should be to bring it into line with recent changes to the London convention. At the most recent meeting of the consultative meeting to the London convention, the contracting parties agreed to ban all forms of nuclear waste and industrial waste. We hope that a similar ban will be negotiated with the South Pacific regional environment program protocol as soon as possible. One important implication of this bill is that it should give the Australian government the power and, hopefully, the will to ban Pasminco Metals-EZ from dumping jarosite waste at sea off the coast of Tasmania. The operation of Pasminco's zinc smelter and the disposal of the waste from its smelter has been a longstanding blight on Australia's commitment to environmental protection within the South Pacific. It certainly makes a mockery of our participation in the regional environment program.

Every 18 hours a ship dumps 400 tonnes of jarosite off the continental shelf of Tasmania with the approval of the Labor government. This has got to stop. But the problem of Pasminco smelter does not just relate to the dumping of jarosite. The Resource Assessment Commission's final report on the coastal zone introduced into the Senate last week makes specific reference to the heavy metal contamination of the Derwent River as a result of the Pasminco smelter. It refers to the significant levels of heavy metals including cadmium, lead, mercury, copper and zinc. The level of these heavy metals is above ANZECC guidelines for aquatic protection. In summary, we hope that the government will take serious note of this bill and take immediate action to stop all forms of waste dumping at sea, in particular to stop the internationally embarrassing actions of Pasminco as a matter of urgency.

I turn to the second bill, the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Amendment Bill 1993. The purpose of this bill is to restructure the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute and to incorporate them into the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. At the outset, we would like to express our concerns about the lack of consultation on this matter with the environment groups in particular. The OSS is, after all, required to monitor the environmental impact of mining in the Alligator Rivers region and it would seem logical to have consulted widely with national and state environment groups.

In principle, inclusion of the OSS under the control of the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency is not of great concern. The administrative streamlining that results from such a change is obviously a cost-effective solution. Our concerns relate to the basis of the committees that will provide advice to this office. There is currently one coordinated committee and it is proposed that it be split into two separate committees. Our concern is that the environment and Aboriginal groups that are represented on the consultative committee will effectively be marginalised by this split. I trust that the government will ensure that this does not occur.

The issue of broadening the scope of work carried out by the OSS is laudable, given the need for the monitoring of the environmental impact of mining operations, especially uranium mining, everywhere in Australia. Our concern is that this increase in workload will be carried out at the expense of the current work being done in the Alligator Rivers region. I trust that the government will consider an increase in funding for the OSS in the 1994 Budget. I also wish to note in closing that the Greens (WA) will be supporting all the amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats as we feel that they address some of our main concerns in relation to this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate my speech on the second reading in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is debating the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Amendment Bill 1993 and the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill 1993.
I will deal with the Alligator Rivers Region Bill first. This Bill is designed to achieve a number of goals:

PARA.TAB: to abolish the Co-ordinating Committee for the Alligator Rivers Region and replace it with two committees—a Technical Committee and a Consultative Committee;
to allow the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region to advise the Minister for Environment on matters outside the Alligator Rivers Region;
to integrate the Office of the Supervising Scientist into the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency; and
to allow the Alligator Rivers Research Institute to undertake contract work.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have been involved in negotiations with the Minister's office for some time over this Bill. We are pleased with the amendment to allow the Supervising Scientist to report to the Minister on matters outside the Region. This will include the Roxby Downs mine in South Australia. However, I made a request of the Minister that Roxby Downs should be subject to monitoring by the OSS or CEPA. The Minister informed me that the South Australian Government is particularly unwilling to co-operate in this matter. I then put to the Minister that the Commonwealth had powers it could use to impose monitoring upon the Roxby Downs mine. That this was again refused is symptomatic of the fact that this Government refuses to use its Federal powers to protect the environment, whilst being prepared to use those same powers in relation to other matters.

The main section of the Bill deals with the replacement of the Co-ordinating Committee with the Technical and Consultative Committees. The Bills Digest noted that the reason for the change is to refine mechanisms for consulting with key stakeholders. I believe this is a sanitised explanation for the reasons for the abolition of the Co-ordinating Committee. The real reason is that the mining industry, notably Energy Resources Australia, has never been happy with an environment representative being included in the Co-ordinating Committee.

It is interesting to note that a former Federal Minister for the Environment wrote to the Managing Director of Koongarra Mines on 26 February 1986. In that telex he referred to a former environment representative Ms Lyn Allen. He said:
`Your comments regarding Ms Allen' appointment as denigrating the Committee [. . . ] could be misconstrued as the banker not wishing the auditor to look closely in his books.'
The Minister went on to say that the contributions of the environment representatives have been valuable and constructive.

It is clear from these comments that the mining industry has never approved of community representation on the Co-ordinating Committee. The mining industry has acted in a belligerent and obstructionist manner on the Co-ordinating Committee. I understand that the industry would refuse to co-operate if an environment representative was included on the Technical Committee. It seems as if the mining industry is holding the Government to ransom on this matter.

The Democrats remain opposed to the splitting of the Co-ordinating Committee. I proposed to the Minister that the Committee be retained but that the Chair of the Committee should be made an independent decision. I believe this would be an appropriate response to a Committee that all agree is not functioning optimally.

This reform proposal was put forward in the Review of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, known as the Taylor Report. However, Cabinet decided against this course of action. I have therefore proposed a number of amendments which accept the two committee system but attempt to improve the functioning and information flow between the committees.

Several of these amendments relate to the membership of the committees. It is entirely appropriate that community representatives be included on both the Consultative Committee and the Technical Committee. Obviously community representatives on the Technical Committee would need scientific or technical qualifications, but these are not hard to find in the environment movement. Opposition to environment representation on the Technical Committee by the mining industry is nothing but pure obstructionism.

The Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill 1993 implements the Protocol for the Prevention of Pollution of the South Pacific Region by Dumping, usually referred to as the SPREP Dumping Protocol.

The Australian Democrats strongly support this legislation which will outlaw the dumping of certain environmentally noxious substances listed in Annex One of the Protocol. These include such substances as organohalogen compounds, mercury and cadmium, persistent plastics, crude oil and its waste, materials produced for biological and chemical warfare and organophosphorous compounds.

I understand that the provisions within the SPREP Dumping Protocol are consistent with those of the international Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, known as the London Dumping Convention of 1972.

I noticed that the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill states that because the provisions are consistent, Australia would have little difficulty in meeting the obligations under this Protocol. I find that statement rather perplexing given the recent decision by the parties to the London Dumping Convention not to approve an Australian application for an exemption to the 1995 phase out date for dumping at sea.

The AustraLian Government had succumbed to the cries of Pasminco-EZ—a company which operates a zinc refinery near Hobart. Pasminco has been dumping jarosite into the ocean, about 130 nautical miles south of Tasmania, over the edge of the continental shelf where the water is about 1,000 fathoms deep. Jarosite is a toxic mixture of iron, sulphur, ammonia and smaller amounts of heavy metals including zinc, cadmium, lead mercury, arsenic and copper.

Every 18 hours Pasminco sends out a ship called the Anson and dumps about 400 tonnes of this toxic cocktail into the ocean. The company has been doing this since 1973. The licence allows Pasminco to dump up to 250,000 tonnes of jarosite a year. At a constant rate over 20 years since 1973, that would make a total of five million tonnes of dumped jarosite. Yet the company claims that it is not causing any environmental damage.
And the licence costs the company only $5,000 per year.
I understand that the dumping of jarosite at sea by Pasminco is one of the last remaining instances of major jarosite ocean dumping in the world.

Another factor in the equation is that the area where Pasminco dumps jarosite is fished for orange roughy and trevally. Yet there is insufficient information available to know what the impacts of the dumping are on marine life.

Under the London Dumping Convention, signatory countries are required to stop ocean dumping of scheduled wastes. It was recently reported in the media that the Australian Government had applied for an exemption to the 1995 phase out date, but the parties to the Convention refused to grant the exemption. This was acutely embarrassing to the Australian Government. It was the only time a country had sought an exemption.

The Government should never have agreed to seek the exemption in the first place. Pasminco refused to comment to the media, although I understand that the company is working with the Commonwealth EPA to develop alternatives to sea dumping that will be in place by 1995. This is what the Australian Government should have required of Pasminco in the first place. It took the international community to tell Pasminco to stop dumping, something the Australian Government could not bring itself to do.

That is why I find it somewhat perplexing when the Government says it will have no difficulty in meeting the obligations under the SPREP Dumping Protocol. Is the Government saying that it is confident that solutions to Pasminco's dumping off the Tasmanian continental shelf can be found in the near future. If so, why did the Government seek an exemption? Or is the Government misleading the public in relation to its assurance that the 1995 phase out date can be met. I would hope that the Minister can provide some clarification on this point.

The other issue I want to raise in the remaining time is the problem of sea dumping of ballast water. As the Senate would be aware, the dumping of ballast water prior to taking on cargo poses a major threat to the health of our costal waters, to marine life, the fishing industry and to human health as well.

I stress the human health aspects because it was revealed at an International Maritime Association meeting last year that cholera had been found in the ballast water of five ships that had visited South American ports. This prompted Australian officials to test ballast water for any evidence of cholera. I have been informed by AQIS that testing of ballast water for cholera is still being carried out, however, no sign of cholera has been found. The AQIS official told me that a research project is likely to get underway in the new year which will examine whether the cholera organism can survive on the long voyage to Australia, the chances of it surviving in a marine environment, and the chances of it being transferred to humans. Depending on the results of the research, a response strategy may be put in place.

Although we are lucky that cholera has not found its way to Australia via ballast water, nevertheless ballast water has been responsible for a number of severe environmental impacts along Australia's coastline. Tasmanian Senators would be aware of the problem of the Japanese seastar around south-eastern Tasmania and the exotic undaria seaweed which has blanketed the ocean floor in an area 16 kilometres long and two kilometres wide off the Tasmanian coast. AQIS has deemed the seaweed impossible to eradicate.

The Federal Government developed guidelines for the control of ballast water in 1991. However, I note that in the recently tabled final report by the Resource Assessment Commission on the Coastal Zone, the Commissioners note that not all state government have adopted those guidelines and that this is impeding the implementation of effective arrangements for handling ballast water. The report recommends that guidelines for handling ballast water by AQIS be adopted by all Australian governments having responsibility for shipping and ports administration.
I note that the Federal Government has recently released a discussion paper on tougher new guidelines on the discharge of ballast water.

In conclusion, I hope that the Australian Government gives serious consideration to the development of an international protocol dealing with the dumping of ballast water. I envisage that the appropriate mechanism is through the IMO rather than through the London Dumping Convention.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
