TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to Mr Keating's description of the government's green paper on employment in which he said, `. . . is not a job creation thing. It is a labour market efficiency flexibility thing, it is principally a social thing . . . it is a jobs ready thing'. Particularly in the light of the recently passed Industrial Relations Reform Bill which actually decreases the flexibility thing and the market efficiency thing for businesses, can the minister inform the Senate what effect he envisages the white paper will have in the end on the real goal of this exercise to permanently decrease the number of long-term unemployed?

—Whatever effect a white paper has will depend on what particular policy strategies are implemented after the options canvassed in that paper have been given full and due consideration by the government after a full consultative process with the whole community. It is not a matter of making any assumptions at all at this stage as to what the particular strategy will be emerging from that white paper. Obviously, the key to job growth in this country, as the white paper makes clear, is continued economic growth overall associated with a continued program of structural adjustment and micro-economic change, including labour market flexibility. We fully acknowledge that. That has always been part of the approach and the strategy.

PARA.TAB: To suggest that the industrial relations legislation we have just passed in any way inhibits that is to profoundly misunderstand the nature of the industrial relations system in this country and the contribution that that legislation will be making to giving further institutional confidence in that system and, at the same time, generating a greater degree of flexibility so far as productivity bargaining and all the rest in the workplace are concerned.

The difficulty we have with members of this opposition, as I said the other day, is that they have only about one idea a decade. They take forever to formulate strategies to go with that idea and they find it very difficult to move beyond that to cope with emerging, evolving, changing circumstances. What the government has done over the course of the last decade is to introduce many ideas simultaneously into our economic reform and our approach to the economic system. We have done an enormous amount to generate structural change, greater flexibility, growth and movement forward in the workplace.

The opposition is mired in an approach to industrial relations which was born and which failed in the 1960s and the 1970s. It is mired in an approach to micro-economic reform and taxation reform which has demonstrably failed and which is demonstrably irrelevant to the needs of this country. The government does not need any lectures from the opposition. It failed in government; it has failed in opposition; and it has failed to produce any kind of coherent alternative that could possibly be attractive or useful to this Australian society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is amazing that the minister can come in here and boast about a record that has resulted in one million Australians being out of work. On the question of the labour market, when will the government recognise that, in the words of the Australian Financial Review, the proposals in yesterday's green paper are `second best substitutes for more thorough reform of the labour market'?

—The government's approach to labour market reform has been one of fully acknowledging and appreciating the virtues of institutional safety nets underlying a basic environment of freer industrial relations bargaining, freer productivity bargaining and generally much more flexibility than we have been used to in previous decades. The difficulty that those opposite confront here, as elsewhere, is that they simply do not understand what is going on out there in the marketplace; they do not understand the institutional pressures that are at work; and they do not understand the needs of the great mass of Australians, including those who have benefited in the past from the operation of that industrial relations system safety net and will continue to do so in the future.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Media reporting of the green paper on restoring full employment seems to have simplified, at the urging of the opposition, the key issue as being whether or not there should be a tax levy to fund certain measures to reduce unemployment. Does this miss the key point of both the green paper and the government's approach? Is the real challenge facing Australia a question of whether or not to impose a tax levy, or does the government perceive a more fundamental challenge?

—This question follows well from the first one because it does raise the proper priorities that we should be considering in dealing with the issue of unemployment. There is an obsession broadly in Australia, and certainly amongst the opposition, with the issue of taxation. Taxation, while an important measure, is a second order issue in what we are talking about here.

PARA.TAB: The green paper's purpose is both social and economic. Its purpose is to inform us all about the dimensions of the social and economic problem of unemployment—and we have to remember that it is both those things. If we seek to have a purely economic solution, we will fail to deal with the social consequences of what is taking place.

There is a simple way to make that point clear. I used one example yesterday for Senator Boswell; let me try another today. Even if we achieve what the green paper says is possible and necessary, which is growth in the order of 4.5 per cent to 5 per cent per year, further measures would still be necessary to ensure that the long-term unemployed have a fair go in sharing in the benefits of this growth.

So there are at least two things that we have to deal with—and I am sorry if dealing with two things at the same time is too hard for some people. We have to have policies to get the rate of growth that will generate the jobs; that is a necessary condition to deal with the problem of unemployment. In 1983 to 1990, Australia had the highest rate of jobs growth in the OECD, but it was not sufficient to get down the long-term unemployed as much as we would have wished. It went down, but not as much as we would wish. It is necessary, as we recover from this recession and go for more growth, to ensure that those people do not become marginalised and excluded from our society and the economic processes within it.

That is why the key proposal in the green paper, in my view—and I think in the government's view overall—is the job compact. We have to look at the merits of it. I am not saying that everything in it is right or whatever. I am saying that that is the key concept, not some second order tax question about how we fund it. The job compact proposed in the green paper is a fundamental element in achieving this.

What we need to do and what those concerned with constructive contribution to the public policy debate should be doing—and what many citizens are doing, but not the opposition—is say, `What are the merits of the job compact proposal, the proposal to ensure that the long-term unemployed get at least some work for six or nine months and the opportunity to do more?'. If it is our view that this is something that needs to be done, then of course the questions of how it is funded become central. But we have to get to the first step first. Let us deal with this profound social and economic question at its core first and get to the tax question, if it ever arises, when we get to the issue of what it is that we want to do.

The second flaw has been the view that there has been no benefit from the labour market programs already pursued by the government. It is quite clear that all of them—jobstart, job clubs, jobtrain—have all substantially improved the chances of the long-term unemployed securing and holding employment. So there is a basis there of labour market programs that have had successes of between 33 per cent and 50 per cent and in some instances, with jobstart, doubling the chances of the long-term unemployed securing and holding employment. So there is a base of successful labour market programs there on the existing policy.

The jobs compact is a very interesting proposal to build on that basis. I would urge citizens who want to make a positive contribution to this debate, instead of just going off on a tax tangent, to focus on that to see if that is the appropriate priority. We then will have a public policy debate about whether something needs to be done to fund it and, if so, what.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the minister aware that the Labor leader in New South Wales, Mr Bob Carr, has said that a jobs levy would `kill the goose that lays the golden egg', and that the `last thing households and businesses need, especially when economic recovery is under way, is another tax slug'? Will the minister take his Labor colleague's advice and `kill it off'?

—Mr Carr is thoroughly entitled to his own view of this matter. There are many views in the community on the likely utility of the jobs levy. It is not a matter about which the government has made any decision. It is a matter of weighing the pros and cons, as Senator McMullan said, of how this job compact approach is, in fact, to be financed—whether out of existing revenues or out of additional revenues—if, indeed, we choose to go down that particular path. All these matters are up for discussion and Mr Carr's contribution will no doubt be taken into account.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the comments of the Queensland Labor Premier, Mr Wayne Goss, also be taken into account? He said, `I don't think a jobs levy is the way to go'. Or, perhaps, the comments of members of the Northern Territory Labor opposition who said that they thought that a jobs levy was impractical? Will the minister take those comments into account? Will the minister also confirm that this levy would wipe out the government's much touted tax cuts and, in fact, cause an increase in taxes for most taxpayers?

—Of course we will take those varying views into account. Unlike the opposition parties, we do not operate on the Fuhrer principle on the Labor side of politics. We do welcome differing viewpoints into these complex policy debates. It is a judgment that we will be making in the new year based on full consideration of all different viewpoints.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As the Prime Minister announced yesterday, the Uruguay Round has now been brought to a successful conclusion in Geneva. How does Australia benefit from the completion of the Uruguay Round negotiations?

—The Prime Minister said yesterday that there is no doubt that this is really outstanding news for Australia with the Uruguay Round representing the largest ever world trade deal and a much needed shot in the arm for the world economy. Australia will be a major beneficiary of the round with recent analysis indicating that exports could increase by as much as $5 billion annually when the round fully takes effect, and Australia's GDP could increase by up to $3.7 billion annually. All sectors of the Australian economy—agriculture, manufacturing and services—will benefit.

PARA.TAB: The conclusion of the round does represent, in particular, a turning point for world agricultural trade and for Australian agriculture. After years of increasing exports of heavily subsidised agricultural products by the United States and the European Community, we will now see a steady reduction in export subsidies for the rest of this decade.

Senator Cook set as his main task while he was in Geneva obtaining the best possible market access deal for Australia; this he has done. Among those receiving major improvements in market access is the beef industry where the access level into the US market of 380,000 tonnes negotiated by Senator Cook will be over 25 per cent higher than the likely restraint level applicable in 1994. Importantly, Australian exporters of beef will, from 1995 onwards, no longer be subject to the vagaries of the meat import law formula, which has seen our access into the US market decline over the last four years. On top of this, beef exporters will also gain from greatly improved access into the Korean beef market and, while there are already rapidly expanding exports to Japan, they will benefit from a further reduction in the Japanese beef tariff. Beef, however, is not the only winner; other agricultural commodities such as rice, dairy and horticulture will all register major gains.

In the manufacturing sector the GATT round has delivered the largest result ever. Indeed, the Uruguay Round outcome is 30 times larger than that obtained from previous rounds. As a result, Australia's exporters of manufactured goods will see a cut in tariffs of more than 50 per cent on average, while our exporters of coal will also see an improvement in market access, particularly into Europe.

The agreement on services provides for the first time international trade rules, which will enable Australian exporters of services, already worth some $15 billion, to compete on the same basis as other services exporters. There will be major benefits to Australian exporters, particularly of intellectual property. For smaller and medium sized economies, such as Australia's, an effective rules based international trading system does provide the best opportunities for increasingly liberalised trading conditions. The strengthening of GATT and its institutional structure through the establishment of what I now understand is to be called the World Trade Organisation, WTO, is of itself a major benefit.

Senator Cook, despite the agreement having been reached in Geneva and most negotiators having now packed their bags, is nonetheless continuing to press for even further concessions on a bilateral basis in a number of our key markets. The outcome of any additional deals that might be produced from this process is not yet available, but we will certainly be announcing that as soon as results are known.

My colleagues—Senator Cook and his predecessors going back to the beginning of the round: Mr Kerin, Dr Blewett, Mr Duffy and Mr Dawkins—have all done an absolutely outstanding job on behalf of Australia. I simply add that the great many officials past and present, too numerous to name individually, both in Canberra and in the delegation in Geneva, have contributed through their professionalism, dedication and sheer persistence to an outcome for Australia which would not otherwise have been achieved.

I mention just two officials in particular because I think their contribution deserves particular acknowledgment on this occasion. One is the former deputy secretary of my department, Peter Field; the other is his successor in that job, David Hawes, who played a particular role as chairman of the services negotiations in Geneva in recent days. Between them they have made a contribution, not only for Australia but for the round as a whole, which has been universally and internationally applauded. I think on occasions we ought to give the public servants that those opposite spend so much time bollocking the recognition they deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the figures from this morning's paper in relation to GATT and ask: does the minister accept these figures, given in today's press, which claim that the First World, containing one billion people, will benefit by $206 billion; the Second World, with half a billion people, by $55 billion; while the Third World, with the remaining 4 1/2 billion people, by only $24 billion—in other words, $224, $122 and $5 per head respectively? Do these figures not represent a massive and accelerated shift of resources from the have-nots to the haves? If it does not, can the minister reconcile these figures, which are reported in such glowing and uncritical terms in today's press?

—Nothing could be further from the truth that there has been some shift from the have-nots to the haves. It is rather a situation of a much bigger cake for everybody with everyone benefiting. What Senator Coulter should appreciate is that the trade liberalisation and increase in global growth which will stem from the round will result in a very major net increase in world income. While the benefits will vary between countries—whether or not they are developed or developing will be one of the relevant considerations—all countries will gain. There is no question of countries gaining at the expense of others. That is just not the way the arithmetic of this works out.

PARA.TAB: I assume that the figures quoted by Senator Coulter on the benefits from the round stem from a recent World Bank-OECD report. That report, which is, as I understand, the source of those figures, makes it very clear that the benefits to the global economy of trade liberalisation are overwhelmingly positive, with the successful round outcome providing a boost to global economic activity of the order of, in Australian dollar terms, over $400 billion annually by the year 2002.

Moreover, that same World Bank report makes clear that developing countries will benefit from the Uruguay Round outcome. Indeed, many of these countries, many of whom are members of the Cairns Group along with Australia, when it comes to agricultural negotiations have been actively pressing the major OECD countries to bring the round to a quick and successful conclusion. As the World Bank report stresses, it is developing countries that would have suffered most from a continuation, or worse still an intensification, of protectionism. They know that; they have been among the most active boosters of all for the round.

The special needs of the developing countries have been recognised since the outset of the round and these are reflected in the outcome. Generally, the developing countries have been required to undertake fewer commitments and have been provided with longer time frames in which to meet those commitments.

One of the many great achievements of the round has been that, in contrast to previous rounds, developing countries have been not only beneficiaries of it but also an integral part of the negotiations and of the resulting agreements and commitments. I repeat that the kind of analysis Senator Coulter has given, implying as it does some sort of shift from one to the other, is simply a fundamental misreading and failure of analysis of the truth of the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it that the minister is not contesting the figures in this morning's paper but simply redistributing the benefits. Given those figures, which show that Australia will benefit by as much as $157 per head while people in the Third World will benefit by only $5 per head, will the government ensure that in next year's budget there is a substantial increase in Australia's foreign aid?

—Australia's foreign aid is already generous by international standards, although not as generous as I personally would like and as I have argued for over a number of years. But one has to accept the constraints within which this country and the other developed economies are presently operating. One of those constraints at the moment is, obviously, a very high level of unemployment, which means that within our own country the benefits of the wealth that we have are being, to that extent, unevenly distributed.

PARA.TAB: We do have a responsibility to tackle this economic and social problem. There are budgetary implications associated with that, which I believe would make it very difficult for us to be dramatically more generous in our aid budget next year. The obligation, morally and otherwise, of the developed world to assist as best we can the developing countries is certainly being made no less as a result of the outcome of the round. To that extent, I certainly agree with Senator Coulter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Can the minister advise parliament of the situation concerning the patient-to-patient transmission of HIV announced by the New South Wales Department of Health yesterday? Can the minister assure parliament and the community that the necessary steps are being taken to make sure that this tragic situation does not occur again?

—I can inform the Senate that late yesterday afternoon the New South Wales health minister rang my office to advise that a New South Wales health report had established that of nine patients who had minor surgical procedures in a private clinic in Sydney on a day in November 1989, five were subsequently reported as HIV positive. Four of those were women with no known risk factors for HIV. The fifth was a man who was later diagnosed as HIV positive and has since died of AIDS. There was no record of that person having tested HIV positive before November 1989 either. The surgeon involved in the case is not HIV positive. Those are the facts that are available. I am confident, having looked at them, that this is a rare but tragic event.

PARA.TAB: As Professor Penny said last night, there have been some 66 million medical, surgical and dental procedures carried out in Australia since infection control guidelines were introduced, and this is the first reported case of its kind. It highlights the importance of that nationally agreed approach of adhering to universal infection control guidelines in all procedures which involve contact with blood and body fluids. That includes not only hospitals involved in major procedures but also medical practitioners who are having day-to-day involvement in that kind of activity in their own surgeries. I have asked the Australian National Council on AIDS, which is due to meet tomorrow, and also the National Health and Medical Research Council to review the current guidelines and advise me whether or not any alterations are necessary.

Concern has been expressed in a number of quarters about how this matter has been handled, and in particular about denials that any investigation was under way by the New South Wales health department even as late as yesterday morning. Since our whole national HIV-AIDS strategy relies on cooperation and partnership between the Commonwealth, the states, the medical profession and affected community groups, I have also asked the two bodies to which I just referred for their advice on how a similar problem might be handled in the future. I obviously will be raising with my state colleagues their role and responsibilities and the role of state medical boards in monitoring standards and adherence to infection control procedures.

I thank the President of the AMA, Brendan Nelson, who today pledged the support of the organisation in ensuring that all doctors are reminded of the absolute need to adhere to infection control protocols on each and every occasion. He has assured me of the AMA's readiness to participate in any review of the guidelines. I share his view that now is not the time to take the easy way out that some call for, which is the idea of universal screening. It does not help very much because of the window period before people who are positive can be identified. It means that, often, health authorities are given a false sense of security about a person's status.

Given the relatively low prevalence of HIV in Australia, universal testing will impose an unnecessary and high cost to an over-burdened health budget without any effective results. Our current policy has served us well. There has been one tragic incident as a break in that continued control. I think that all of us ought to work very hard to make sure that that one isolated, tragic incident is never repeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Now that the entire health package will be subject to veto by the ACTU-caucus working party, will the minister finally concede that he has now lost control of his changes?
—These questions are amusing. I have to at least concede that.
—I thought they were quite boring actually.

—`Boring' is one word. I still find some amusement. As a matter of procedure, Senator Herron ought to understand a couple of things because it is pretty clear that he does not. All that is being suggested is that a body will work through a whole range of what are detailed and complex proposals over the course of months and come up with recommendations that it would see as fitting in the light of its investigations.

PARA.TAB: As would happen on many other occasions, the government then examines whatever those bodies might find and reacts accordingly. I would present a submission to government for legislation, which may or may not be in accord with what had been recommended. It will be up to the government then to reach a decision that may or may not be in accord with what I want. That is all predicated on the basis that the government agrees to any of it at all.

So, when Senator Herron says that I have lost control of the changes, I do not really believe that there is ever total, utter and absolute control, in any event, because these things are subject to cabinet and party procedures. That is the same for every cabinet minister. We do not all just run out and do what we want; we have to do what governments agree to. That is what we shall do, as is normally the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the working party rejects all or any changes of the minister's plans, what alternatives does he have to address the massive decline in private health insurance?

—What we ought to be doing is allowing me to answer that question if and when any of the eventualities that Senator Herron is talking about ever occur. Some parts of the proposals that I am putting forward meet with everybody's support, so there is no possibility that they will reject the lot. Who knows how much they will reject? What I will do, what the cabinet will do and, eventually, what the caucus will do, is examine what they say and make decisions accordingly, in the light of that advice and other advice—as we always do. I do not see that it is any great change.

PARA.TAB: Some people in my party do not think that a decline in private health insurance is a bad thing. I do not share their view. I have sought to put forward this package. We will have to see how it is reacted to over the next six months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given the admission by federal Treasury to Estimates Committee D that it had not studied the impact on families of monopoly pricing by public utilities, does the government endorse the view expressed by the Industry Commission in its annual report that `public utility dividend payments to governments are too low'?

—I was not aware that the Industry Commission had made that report, so I cannot deal with it in context. But as to whether dividend payments by those utilities are too low overall, I think that some of them are and that some of them are not—both at the federal level and in some of the states. It varies from state to state.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine would understand that the Industry Commission approaches this matter from a particular philosophical point of view about the role of prices in making markets operate and a belief in the distributive capacity and power of the price driven market system. One would therefore expect it to come up with that recommendation. Government is a bit more complex than that. So I do not think—as a universal statement—that all dividend payments are too low. I for one would accept that the government, overall, does not have a view. We deal with the dividend payments of our instrumentalities on a case by case basis. But I suspect that some of them probably are too low.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am a little surprised that the minister has not focused on this very important matter, which has become more and more important and which affects many family lives. The annual report of the Industry Commission also stated that public utility monopoly pricing above marginal costs `is simply another form of indirect taxation'. Does the government consider that higher charges for water and other necessities of life are any fairer as taxes on families than taxes on food and clothing, which were rejected by the public at the last poll?
—As a matter of general principle, I do not think that public utilities should be used as taxing mechanisms.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. I am sure that the minister is aware of the Buy Australian campaign which he launched on 12 October this year and which cost about $1 million, and of criticism from the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology about the policy mayhem in Australian purchasing. Will the minister inform the Senate whether the Christmas cards that are being posted out by DAAS to its clients at the moment are, as indicated on the back of the cards, printed in the United States of America?
—I realise it is the biggest issue in the world, but I have not got a clue.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Mrs Kelly has provided advice to the Minister for Resources concerning his imminent decision to grant woodchip export licences. The letter from the environment minister contains a list of forestry coupes which should be protected from logging. Firstly, of the thousands of coupes across the country, is it the case that about 500 are worthy of protection from logging? Secondly, is it the case that, after great difficulty, the department of the environment reduced this figure to between 80 and 90 coupes? Thirdly, did the minister then reject the advice of her department and not send this number to Mr Lee but further cut the number to be protected? Is it the case that, in the letter which the minister has sent to Mr Lee, only about half the number—in other words, 40 or 50 coupes—will be protected? Will the minister table the original advice submitted by the department to Mrs Kelly.

—Senator Lees gave a number of figures; I cannot respond to all of them, but I will take them on notice. I do have the following information from Mrs Kelly on this general issue: no, the minister sought advice from her portfolio on those forest coupes that are likely to have a high conservation value which have been considered by the Minister for Resources in the renewal of export woodchip licences. That advice was forwarded to the Minister for Resources. The minister has not taken a more conservative position than her department. Both generic and specific advice on conditions to be attached to export woodchip licences was provided to the Minister for Resources. Due to time constraints and the lack of the necessary data, the list of coupes was not seen as exhaustive.

PARA.TAB: The last part of the question is central to the correspondence between the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and the Minister for Resources debated earlier today in the Senate. Senator Gareth Evans, on behalf of the government, made it clear that the government believes it is inappropriate to table that correspondence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister. As this is the last day of sitting, can the minister provide—
—Is it?

—We hope that it is the last day of sitting officially. Can we please have advice answering my specific questions tabled tonight before we rise. In particular, I would like the original advice from the department. That was not what was discussed this morning; we looked at the letter from Mrs Kelly to Mr Lee, which we asked for. I am now asking for something quite different, and that is the departmental advice that Mrs Kelly received. Is that possible?

—Like all honourable senators, I hope that this is the last day of sitting for the Senate. I hope that this is the last question time—not that we do not enjoy question time. It has been a very useful year for the government because we have been able to use question time to expose the opposition as being weak and ineffectual. That aside—and I am not anticipating that we will be back here tomorrow or the day after because I am always an optimist—I will attempt to get that information for Senator Lees some time today and give it to her by leave of the Senate before we rise tonight.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Tonga led by the Speaker, the Hon. Fusitu'a. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take pleasure in welcoming the delegation to the Senate and trust that their visit is both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Mr Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TAB.EMPHASIS: Hon. Fusitu'a was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the minister to the threatened closure of the Palm Beach Post Office which is of considerable interest to the people of the electorate of Mackellar. Is it true that the decision has been taken to preserve the services of the Palm Beach Post Office but that an announcement of the subject will be delayed until the new year, at a time closer to the Mackellar by-election? If so, why is the minister playing party politics with the legitimate concerns of the residents in delaying this announcement?
—What have you got to say for yourself?

—What have I got to say for myself? You have got me, Senator Bishop—I do not know the answer to that question. I have never been to the Palm Beach Post Office. Has Senator Bishop been to the Palm Beach Post Office?

PARA.TAB: I have no advice on that matter in my brief. I did not expect to find anything. I will seek an answer for Senator Bishop and hope to get it to her before she leaves the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably not the role of the Chair to intervene, but I thought I announced in the Manly Daily last week that it was not going to close. Perhaps I am wrong, so I will check it at the same time!
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I did not know that you were the minister. If not, how did you get the advice?
—I will let you know that later.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the recent report by the Shipping Industry Reform Authority on progress in implementing the latest shipping reform program. Can the minister advise the Senate of any independent evidence that shows the impact of these reforms on shipping services and benefits to the Australian trading community?
—I am pleased to advise the Senate that the Australian shipping industry continues to make great progress in the area of micro-economic reform.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the interjections from opposite, I recall only too well the policies on maritime reform that the opposition took to the last election. Those policies would have had the effect of destroying the Australian shipping industry. On maritime reform, as on industrial relations, as on Mabo and as on every single issue affecting this country, the opposition continues to occupy the place it has always occupied—at the cutting edge of irrelevancy.

PARA.TAB: The last report by the Shipping Industry Reform Authority confirms that the cooperative reform culture which has been built up over the last decade continues—
Senator Ian Macdonald interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish Senator Ian Macdonald were the member for Mackellar. The initial round of crewing reductions is now ahead of target with average crewing levels across the Australian fleet being reduced to fewer than 18 compared with the figure of 18.5 which was the government's original target.

PARA.TAB: However, the second round of this program aims to reduce crews to an average of 16.25 before the end of 1995. When these reductions are complete, crew levels on Australian ships will have reduced on average by 45 per cent from an average crew level of 33 that applied 10 years ago. Training initiatives will also see the major trading fleet operating under the new multiskilled crewing arrangements.

The Australian fleet continues to be, along with our aviation fleet, one of the youngest in the world with an average ship age of nine years, compared with a world fleet average of 17 years and rising. The Australian fleet has been revitalised through the introduction of 34 modern, high technology vessels. Those vessels would never have been provided without the government's shipping reform program and its success.

As part of this program, the Prices Surveillance Authority is continuing to monitor coastal shipping freight rates until mid-1996 to ensure that benefits will flow through to the users. Earlier this month the PSA released its second monitoring report, which concluded that shipping reform has been successful in providing lower cost structures for coastal ship operators. Shippers have benefited from continued stability and freight rates in 1991 and 1992. The PSA finds that shipping companies are not receiving returns significantly exceeding their costs.

Considerable benefits are found in the report from the encouragement given to investment in new, more efficient ships and more flexible and multi-skilled crews. While the PSA, not surprisingly, concludes that shippers can obtain lower freight rates on the spot market, this reflects the differing market conditions and operating environments between the spot market and long-term contracts.

Some observations are also made in the report about evidence that one-off voyages by foreign flagships may offer lower prices than dedicated Australian flag carriers. As the PSA pointed out in its first report, the value of such comparisons is limited. It is a pity that there is not greater recognition of the considerable efforts of the industry in raising shipping efficiency while maintaining a high quality service against what is now a worldwide trend towards older ships and cheap and untrained crews.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Land Transport Development Act: Annual Reports

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. The minister would be aware of the Australian Land Transport Development Act that states clearly that the ALTD annual report is to be presented to parliament on an annual basis. Can the minister therefore explain why he has not tabled the ALTD program's annual reports for the 1991-92 years and the 1992-93 years and why he tabled the 1989-91 report only earlier this session? Given that one of the functions of the annual report is to provide a detailed list of projects undertaken under the program, can the minister assure the Senate that the delay in tabling is not to avoid a similar controversy to that surrounding the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and her sports rorts difficulties?

—I certainly can provide that assurance, and Senator Brownhill knows perfectly well that I can. Senator Brownhill knows perfectly well that the arrangements in respect of funding between the Commonwealth and the states and territories are made on a totally cooperative basis between the Commonwealth and state and territory governments. A very good working relationship is enjoyed by the Commonwealth and state and territory transport ministers.

PARA.TAB: The projects—and I made this point in the Senate only a week or two ago—that are selected for the application of the Commonwealth funds, which are significant, are not only chosen by the state authorities but also administered and managed by the state authorities. The Commonwealth—and I am sure Senator Brownhill will be pleased to hear this—has no intention of duplicating those services that are provided by the state road authorities.

We try to give the lead in making those services more efficient. We insist that, for example, pavement management systems are introduced by state authorities. I notice that the Morris committee's report, which has either just been tabled or is about to be tabled, on road maintenance makes the point that these systems do effectively provide a saving to taxpayers. The Commonwealth continues to give the lead by insisting on that kind of thing.

The Commonwealth has a significant concern, considering it is now paying out some $700 million a year in untied grants to state and local governments for road construction, that this money has been diverted to projects other than road building. It has been a matter of some aggravation to the operators of road transport that, in the continual period of complaint we get from state governments about insufficient funding from the Commonwealth for roads, state governments are continuing to divert significant amounts of this untied grant money from the Commonwealth, designed for roads, to things other than roads.

The Commonwealth is extremely concerned by that. The decision to provide these untied grants was made at the Special Premiers Conference in 1991—it was not an initiative of the Commonwealth government—and it is directly relevant to the ALTD Act. As honourable senators know, that is coming to an end at the end of this year and these new arrangements will be put in place progressively from 1 January next year. I wish to take the opportunity to express the concern of the Commonwealth that, while we are paying out $700 million per annum in untied grants, significant amounts of this money are being diverted to projects other than road building.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—Significant amounts. Senator Ian Macdonald should look at the New South Wales government to see what his colleagues are doing.
—Have you got a figure?

—I will give Senator Ian Macdonald one example: $50 million, which was formerly allocated to roads—and should have been allocated to roads—was diverted to rail systems in New South Wales. I should be grateful that at least it went into the transport system. Senator Ian Macdonald might like to know that it is a matter of concern not only to me but also to my colleagues the state transport ministers as well.

PARA.TAB: The reports that Senator Brownhill is seeking will be tabled as soon as they are available. I can assure him that they will show the facts, and that is that the spending of this money is a totally cooperative effort—we provide it and the states spend it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Section 41 of the Australian Land Transport Development Act says that the minister shall, as soon as practical after 30 June each year, cause a report to be laid before the parliament. The minister has obviously flunked on that in the last couple of years. Is it because the Auditor-General's report on the department confirms industry claims that road construction programs have been poorly administered and that the taxpayer is not getting the best value for his dollar? Senator Collins has not really answered the question.

—I have specifically answered the question. In respect of the last point, we are continually looking for further efficiencies in road funding. We give the lead to this by ensuring that quality management systems are provided by state governments as a condition of Commonwealth grants. We will continue to insist on these efficiencies.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Of what benefit would any of these spurious benefits of the Uruguay Round of GATT be to the world if we destroy the world's ecosystem in the process, that is, if the growth imperative created by trade deregulation brings the living planet to the point of extinction?

—I think it is a world first to suggest that the GATT round is going to contribute to bringing the world to a speedier extinction than might otherwise be the case, just as I think it was also a world first for the Greens to suggest that we and other countries ought to engage in an environmental impact statement on the effect of the GATT round before accepting it. With something like 10,000 or more different goods and services in issue across 116 countries over a number of years, it would have been a rather fascinating environmental impact exercise to set in train.

PARA.TAB: The biggest problems confronting the world these days—certainly the developed world—are those of sustaining economic growth and generating jobs and incomes, and the social security that is associated with that. There is no way that that will be anything other than enormously encouraged, for all the reasons I mentioned before, by a successful outcome of the Uruguay Round.

Equally, so far as the developing world is concerned, the overwhelming necessity is for economic growth in order to enable a greater income to be generated and in order to enable, over time, greater equity in the distribution of that income. Of course it is necessary that growth, whether it is in the developed or the developing world, be accompanied by environmental sensitivity. I think the world as a whole has become a lot more sensitive to these issues over the last decade than was the case previously. That is wholly to be welcomed. But to believe the notion that this objective is somehow inconsistent with the objective of greater trade and greater economic growth associated with that trade is, I think, to fundamentally misconceive the nature of the processes that are at work here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The question has not been answered so I will ask it again, perhaps in more simple language. There is ample evidence that in developing countries trade deregulation and financial deregulation has led to a greater requirement to produce cash crops in recent years. In Australia, our standards will be lowered by the Codex Alimentaire. I repeat: of what use is increased growth and money if we destroy the world's environment in the process?

—I repeat: if there were any necessary connection between the two, if more economic growth meant more environmental destruction ipso facto, then there would be a legitimate policy concern. But it is simply not the case that there is that kind of causal relationship. There does not have to be, and there is not.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to an article in today's Australian entitled, `Employers shun mentally ill', which states;

QUESTION.PARA: . . . federal Cabinet would consider in February a national plan of action to implement the Burdekin report on mental illness and human rights.

Given the inconsistencies and the confusion in the answers provided by Mr Howe on Tuesday and the minister yesterday, can the minister explain how this fits in with Mr Howe's intention to respond in 12 months time? Has Minister Howe reconsidered the importance of the issue overnight under pressure from the Minister for Health or the Minister for Employment, Education and Training?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the opportunity, in answering Senator Tambling's question, to answer the question that Senator Patterson asked yesterday that I said I would take on notice and answer today. The honourable senator says there is confusion about answers given by Mr Howe and me. I pointed out yesterday that I had not spoken to Mr Howe about it, that I therefore was not aware of what his timetable was, but that I would check it and come forward today. Having said that, I am not aware that I have contributed to confusion. Nonetheless, I have an answer. The Deputy Prime Minister and the Attorney-General have convened a task force to develop a plan of action in response to Burdekin and all the matters that were raised in his report. The intention is to table that report in federal parliament early in 1994.

PARA.TAB: Work is already beginning on new policy proposals within the portfolio. While it is too early at this stage to make any specific announcements about what might be in the budget, key areas such as the supported accommodation assistance program, disability programs and the aged and community care areas are looking at what initiatives might be progressed in response to the report. Better use of and targeting existing resources will also assist in addressing these issues.

The Special Minister of State, Frank Walker, on behalf of the Prime Minister, has written to premiers and chief ministers asking that they also consider developing an action plan for their respective states. It is intended that the Commonwealth and state plans be discussed as a major agenda item at the ministerial council meeting in March 1994, at which all Commonwealth and state health and community service ministers will be represented. This will ensure a broad, all-encompassing approach necessary to deal effectively with these problems. Mr Howe and I will both be attending to present the Commonwealth plan at that meeting in March.
As to whether that means that there will be a budget proposal, that remains difficult to say, but it is quite possible there will be. If not, it will be dealt with, in any event, shortly thereafter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Again I am confused. The article today quoting Mr Howe states that `federal cabinet will consider this matter in February'. The minister has just acknowledged that the matter will go to a Commonwealth-state housing ministers conference in March. Can the minister please advise what differences will be addressed by federal cabinet in February? That means Mr Howe is bringing forward his agenda by about six months. Just what is going on here? Or is it just another package of weasel words?

—I worry about Senator Tambling. I said that Mr Howe and I were going to attend that meeting of the Commonwealth and the states to present the Commonwealth plan of action. I would have thought that if one were going to have a plan of action, one would probably have to put it to a cabinet to have one in the first place. Therefore, I assume that when Brian Howe said he is going to put it to a cabinet meeting in February, it is to get those instructions so that we have a plan to put in March.

—My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and refers to the work of the Australia Abroad Council. Following on the success of the Celebrate Australia promotion in Japan, what progress has been made with the Australia Today: Indonesia '94 promotion planned for next June and July in Indonesia?

—The Australia Today: Indonesia '94 promotion, which we will be running in Indonesia in June-July next year, will be the largest trade and cultural promotion ever undertaken by Australia in that country. It will be a major trade and cultural showcase for Australia in Indonesia highlighting achievements in trade and industry, science and technology, the arts, education, sport, media, film and tourism. The program will include a major science and technology exhibition; a business and trade exhibition; business conferences and seminars; performances by the Western Australian Ballet, Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra and other performing and visual arts groups; and a sports program between Australian and Indonesian associations.

PARA.TAB: The Australian government is very pleased with the Indonesian government's positive response to the promotion. This is evidenced by the acceptance by Coordinating Minister for Trade and Industry Hartarto to be patron of the occasion. Indonesia is a country of over 180 million people, with an economy which continues to grow at over six per cent a year. I take this opportunity to urge Australian companies to seize the moment to join with the Australian government in making this promotion, Australia Today: Indonesia '94, even more successful than the promotion which has just ended in Japan. It will help them and this country to generate new business links with Indonesia. It will also help to build the image of a sophisticated, technologically advanced country, which is exactly what we do want to promote in the region. It will generally be of enormous benefit to the national interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Following widespread evidence and additional allegations of roster rorting which led to a bashing and further threats in the Western Australian Seamen's Union, did the minister have a meeting with union officials? If so, did he find substance to any, part or all of the evidence and allegations? Has there been a formal investigation into the issue? How many people have been interviewed?

—No, Mr President, I did not, and I see no need to do so. If any criminal actions have taken place in respect of this incident, I have no doubt that they will be taken care of by the appropriate police authorities.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why then has the secretary of the union said that he came to see the minister about fixing it up?
—I meet continually with officials of relevant unions in my portfolio. I had a meeting—

PARA.TAB: Senator Richardson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do, Senator Richardson. In fact, I had a detailed meeting only this week with Mr Papaconstuntinos, the Federal Secretary of the Maritime Union. That meeting was on issues entirely unrelated to this incident. I say again that I have not had a meeting with union officials regarding that particular incident. If assaults have occurred and if criminal action has taken place at this incident, I have no doubt that the police authorities will take care of the matter, as they should.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GATT: Impact on Manufacturing and Service Industries

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I refer to the successful outcome of the GATT negotiations and the impact that could have on Australia's manufacturing and service industries. Is the minister able to provide any information on the implications for Australia's manufacturing and service sector?

—Just as earlier today in question time Senator Gareth Evans outlined the significant achievements of GATT overall for Australia and gave detailed evidence about the achievement for agriculture—agriculture has been a major feature of our work in the GATT because of the work done by the Cairns Group—it is often not understood that GATT will have major benefits to Australia for both our manufacturing and service industries. Our exports in manufacturing are growing rapidly. Only a month or so ago, figures for October of this year revealed that exports grew by 11.3 per cent in the manufacturing area. Clearly, Australia is on the right track in the growth of manufacturing exports. That is why the GATT outcome announced last night from Geneva is very important for manufacturing. Benefits will flow to a range of companies from large raw material processors to niche manufacturers of sophisticated, high technology products.

PARA.TAB: For example, BHP's steel export strategy will receive a significant boost because tariffs on steel products in a number of major countries, including the US, Canada and Japan, will be eliminated. In high-tech, the outcome of pharmaceuticals, for example, provides for the immediate elimination of tariffs, including those in Europe, the US, Japan and Canada. Of course, the government's policies for pharmaceuticals mean that Australian based companies are well placed to become regional manufacturing centres.

For Australia's service sector, GATT means greater access through transparent and fair regulations. For example, when bidding for overseas contracts, Australian construction companies will now have a quality of status with other bidding countries and access to clearer bidding guidelines; our internationally competitive telecommunications sector will now have access to previously denied markets; and our banks and legal firms will also benefit from newly opened markets.

Our firms are well placed to reap the benefits from this liberalised trading environment. This all fits in with the theme of the Australian Manufacturing Council report, done by the McKinsey group earlier this year, which outlined how 700 high growth manufacturing exporters were helping Australia's exports and showing us the way. In manufactures, what the GATT round will do is give us every opportunity to turn that 700 into 7,000 exporting firms, particularly in the small to medium sized enterprise area. Just as the farming sector will welcome the GATT round decisions as being of big benefit to that sector, long overdue, the policies of this government which encouraged the expansion of manufacturing exporters during the 1980s and the early 1990s will get major benefit from the GATT round.

I, like Senator Evans, congratulate the Australian trade ministers from the mid-1980s onwards for the formation of the Cairns Group. The work that they have carried out has meant that we have an outstanding outcome for manufacturing and the service sector that will increase exports and, above all else, create jobs in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr President, I have a number of pieces of information in respect of questions that have been asked. Senator Brownhill asked a question about ALTDA reports. The 1989-91 report has been tabled in parliament; the 1991-92 report was tabled two days ago, and I have a copy of that report; and the 1992-93 report has been compiled and should be tabled in the autumn sittings next year. I have been advised that one of the reasons for the delay with these reports is that, of course, they contain a compilation of data from all of the state and territory governments. This takes some time to compile. The report that Senator Brownhill is seeking is being compiled at the moment and will be tabled in the autumn sittings.

—Senator Bishop asked a question about the Palm Beach post office. I am indebted to you, Mr President, for advice on that matter. I might add that this advice indicates the very effective role you play as a representative for the people who live in that electorate.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, you have provided me with a copy of a letter you received from the minister on 18 November, advising you that Australia Post does not have any plans to close the Palm Beach post office agency. I table a press statement issued by you announcing that the Palm Beach post office will remain open. I also table an item from the local newspaper, the Manly Daily of Friday 10 December, which announced that the post office will be staying open. Perhaps Senator Bishop could pay more attention to the local newspapers in her electorate if she wants to keep on top of these issues. If she lived in the electorate, she probably would know.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I gave an undertaking to Senator Calvert that I would provide him with additional information on the question of Mabo as it affects Norfolk Island. I have a very detailed answer. I note that the final paragraph of the answer is actually the key one—and, having been to Norfolk Island, I can confirm it. We are told that at the time of European settlement Norfolk Island was completely uninhabited and does not have any indigenous people there to this day. So I think the chances of Mabo being a significant issue on Norfolk Island are extremely small. I seek leave to incorporate the entire document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: On 14 December 1993 Senator Calvert asked a Question without Notice of Senator Richardson, representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, about the following issues:

PARA.TAB: (a) Has the government received representations from the Norfolk Island Government that it strongly protests against the extension of the Native Title Bill to Norfolk Island?
(b) Do these representations include the fact that absolutely no consultation has taken place with the Norfolk Island Government over the bill?
(c) Does this failure by the federal government to consult with Norfolk Island contravene cabinet handbook guidelines?
(d) Is the government's failure to consult with Norfolk Island also at odds with the commitments given by the territory minister in March 1992 and the Attorney-General in April 1992?
(e) Given that the Native Title Bill is based on the notion of terra nullius, which has no relevance to Norfolk Island, will the government amend the Bill to delete its extension to Norfolk Island?

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly, has advised me as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) Yes. The Norfolk Island Government has written to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories raising concerns about the extension of the Native Title Bill to Norfolk Island. I understand that those concerns were the subject of discussions on Norfolk Island between Commonwealth and Norfolk Island officials earlier this month.
(b) Yes. The Norfolk Island Government's letter expresses concern at the lack of consultation prior to introduction of the Native Title Bill.

(c) Since the grant of internal self-government to Norfolk Island in 1979 it has been the policy of successive Governments to consult with the Norfolk Island Government where practicable, on the proposed extension of Commonwealth legislation to the Territory. This policy is reflected in both the Cabinet and legislation handbooks. However, it is recognised that, on occasion, it is not practicable to consult for reasons of urgency or where, by convention, consultation normally does not occur (for example, budget legislation).

(d) I understand that the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories periodically writes to other Departments to remind them of the need to consult on the application of Commonwealth legislation. In March 1992 the then Minister for the Arts and Territories wrote to the Attorney-General seeking his co-operation, and that of the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, in reminding departments of the need to consult on all legislative proposals which may have implications for Norfolk Island. In his response of 21 April 1992 the Attorney-General agreed that it was important that the Norfolk Island Government be kept aware of Commonwealth legislative proposals which may affect the Island and undertook to circulate the Minister's letter with a reminder of the importance of consultation.

(e) Given that Norfolk Island was uninhabited at the time of European settlement and that it has no indigenous population, the Mabo decision and the Commonwealth related legislation will have no practical effect. However, the legislation is a national response to a national issue and, in recognition of the primacy of the Commonwealth response, the Government's intention is that the legislation will apply to the whole of Australia, including the external Territories.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today Senator Campbell asked me a question about Christmas cards, which I suppose is appropriate at this time of year. The first thing I want to make absolutely clear is that the Christmas card which I distributed was an Australian artwork from the Australian gallery—
—I didn't ask you that question.

—I thank Senator Patterson for her help. It was printed not only in Australia, but in Canberra. DAAS is a very diverse organisation. There are a large number of businesses and agencies within it, many of whom sent out their own Christmas cards. To the extent that I have been able to check with them, all of them were printed in Australia. The only one with any international connection is the Overseas Property Group, which put out a Christmas card which was a product of the American Greeting Card Corporation but which was printed in Australia.

—On Monday of this week Senator Boswell asked me a question about a TPC decision regarding the amalgamation of sugar companies in Queensland specifically for a new sugar factory at Mackay. I indicated to him then that the government's response was that the TPC is an independent body and though submissions were made to its review, including submissions from my department pointing out a number of benefits which would accrue by allowing the merger to take place, the government stated that the TPC is an independent body.

PARA.TAB: I did indicate, in view of Senator Boswell's keen interest in this issue, that I would have further discussions with my colleagues, specifically the Assistant Treasurer, who is responsible for the TPC. Again, I report to Senator Boswell and to the Senate that the view of the government is unchanged. The TPC is an independent body and it makes its decisions. If people do not accept them, there are proper and appropriate procedures that they can take to appeal to the courts of the land. That is where the situation lies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time yesterday, Senator Crane asked me as Minister representing the Prime Minister a question without notice about the secondary boycott provisions of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. I undertook to provide further advice on that matter. I seek leave to have that reply incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In his question Senator Crane expressed concern that it would be possible, in some circumstances, for a secondary boycott on the export of live sheep to come within an exemption under proposed section 162 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988.
The Senator suggested that this would "force farmers to go back to the wharves and load live sheep to protect their livelihood and their markets."

If a secondary boycott on the export of live sheep were to occur for industrial purposes, it could be prohibited by proposed section 162. This would apply if the boycott had, as an immediate and substantial purpose, the causing of substantial loss or damage to the business of the target of the boycott and if the boycott had, or was likely to have, that effect.

While section 162 prohibits secondary boycott action, certain exemptions from the prohibition are provided for under section 162. This does not, however, affect the application of common law actions in tort. Accordingly, a secondary boycott which obstructed the export of live sheep and which came within an exemption could still be the subject of such a common law action.

If the boycott involved a federally registered trade union, and such a common law action was proposed, then, under proposed section 166A, there would be up to 72 hours of pre-litigation conciliation by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission before the action could be brought. This is the maximum period of pre-litigation conciliation. The period ceases immediately if the Commission is satisfied that it cannot stop the relevant conduct promptly or if the Commission decides that it would cause substantial injustice not to permit the legal action to be brought before the expiry of the pre-litigation period.

Section 166A does not apply where the relevant conduct involves personal injury or wilful or reckless harm to property or its unlawful use. Similarly, section 166A does not apply to a demarcation dispute or a claim for strike pay.

There is no reason why, in the example given by Senator Crane, farmers would need to resort to any action apart from following proper processes before an industrial tribunal or, if it were necessary, before a court for a legal remedy. It would be regrettable if farmers or anyone else in the community were given the impression that any other steps were necessary or appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to GATT.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans and many other ministers on the government side, together with many people on the opposition side, do not seem to understand that economic growth does not equate with benefit. Senator Evans evidently does not understand that when one pollutes the environment one spends dollars on cleaning up the environment and those dollars go down as an addition to GDP. Apparently one can become better off by destroying the environment and spending money on cleaning it up.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans also apparently does not understand that, as the environment is destroyed and one amortises the capital value of the natural environment by taking trees out of forests, for instance, because we keep no national capital account, that money appears in our gross domestic product and we can appear to be growing even while we are destroying the environment. So, first of all, I think it needs to be understood that growth does not equate with benefit.

Secondly, I think the figures in this morning's paper quite clearly show—and Senator Evans did not contest these figures—that the benefit to the well-off countries from this negotiated GATT agreement far and away exceeds the benefit to Third World countries. If one accepts these figures for the moment, which I do not, and accepts that, as Senator Evans has said, there will be some small benefit flowing to Third World countries, nonetheless, one is totally ignoring the fact that, if $228 per head goes to the countries in Europe, $215 per head goes to the USA, $336 per head goes to Japan, and only $5 per head goes to people in Third World countries, that gives the people in the rich world an enormous advantage which allows them to then further exploit Third World countries.
I seek leave to incorporate a graph which shows both the benefit for each area of the world in billions of dollars, the population in billions and the per capita gains.
Leave granted.
[GRAPHS OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 4839]

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gareth Evans then went on and quoted the World Bank. Senator Evans evidently has not seen the excellent article in the November issue of the Scientific American by Herman Daly, a former professor of economics at Louisiana State University, called `The perils of free trade: economists routinely ignore its hidden costs to the environment and to the community'. Among other things, Herman Daly states:

SPEECH.PARA: The domestic economy should be the dog and international trade its tail. GATT seeks to tie all the dogs' tails together so tightly that the international knot would wag the separate national dogs.

For an alternative view from somebody who is actually working in the environment department of the World Bank, I would strongly suggest that the minister and other ministers on his side have a look at Herman Daly's excellent paper.

PARA.TAB: I think GATT has clearly ignored the environmental, social and occupational health consequences of so-called free trade. It totally ignores the fact that there are many countries in the world which quite deliberately have very low standards of environmental protection, low standards of occupational health and low standards of pay and work conditions for workers.

What GATT means is that there is no possibility for a country like Australia to maintain its standards against the import of goods and services made under those appalling conditions. There is no ability whatsoever under GATT for a nation like Australia to look behind the point at which the goods and services actually land on our doorstep. For that reason, GATT means an adoption of the lowest possible standards globally in terms of environmental protection, occupational health and general working conditions.

Also GATT will mean that, because of the fluid movement of capital that now exists, capital will move from first world countries into third world countries to exploit those conditions of very low environmental standards and very low occupational health and worker conditions. What one will see in first world countries—countries like Australia—is in fact a loss of jobs, not an increase in jobs. One will see a decline in the range of industries which this country will be able to support because capital will simply flow into those markets. That process has already started. We have seen it in the textile, clothing and footwear industry in Australia and we will see it in many other industries. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) to a question asked by Senator Campbell this day, relating to Christmas cards.

SPEECH.PARA: I genuinely wanted to seek information from the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services Senator McMullan) regarding the production of a Christmas card which I know has been sent out to at least Victorian and Tasmanian clients of the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is heavy stuff.

—It is not heavy stuff but it is an important issue. Arch Bevis, a colleague of Senator Collins in the other place, has just put down an interim report on the purchasing policies of the Australian government and described the policy as being in mayhem. Senator McMullan has admitted that there needs to be a review of purchasing policy and that we need to find ways of ensuring that Australians get a fair shake when the government buys things.

PARA.TAB: On the back of the Christmas card appear the words, `Printed in the United States of America'. I would like the minister to find out whether it was printed in the United States of America. The front of the card contains a very attractive piece of Aboriginal art. It is a UNICEF card which, as I say, was printed in the United States of America. I make the point that UNICEF is a very worthwhile cause. But I also suggest to the minister that there are probably many other equally worthy charities in Australia which print their cards in Australia and use Aboriginal art or any other sort of art.

I ask the minister kindly whether he will come back to the Senate later today or tomorrow and inform us whether there was a mistake made or whether indeed this card was printed in the United States of America. One thing that the department and the government could do about encouraging the purchase of Australian products would certainly be to purchase Christmas cards printed in Australia. I am sure we produce them at least as efficiently and effectively as does the United States as America. We have artists and community groups all over the place producing beautiful Christmas cards. It just shocked me that we have one that is printed in the United States of America. I seek leave to table the Christmas card.
Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In normal circumstances I would be very concerned if any agency of my department were ordering something of this sort that was printed in America, but I will not criticise any agency for buying UNICEF cards. It seems to me to be a perfectly reasonable, socially responsible thing to do, and I will not criticise the agency for it.
—What about the Buy Australia campaign?
—Those opposite can go around kicking UNICEF; I will not.

—I simply make the point that no-one, least of all Senator Campbell, is having a go at UNICEF. The fact of the matter is that it is Senator McMullan's inefficiency that has created this situation. There are many unemployed people in Australia who are of greater value in a charitable sense who he should give jobs to—get them to do the cards, and not have them done in the United States. Surely the minister has a responsibility to the unemployed people of this country, yet he wanders out of this chamber, totally disregarding them. Why does he not give the jobs to Australians? If the minister is going to walk out of this chamber—as he has now done—and not care less about the unemployed people of Australia, all I can say is that it is typical of this Labor government.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I seek your great knowledge on this matter. There has been a gross discourtesy by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan). There was a debate occurring and he picked up his papers and walked out. I wonder whether there is any standing order which requires a modicum of courtesy to senators on the part of the minister.
—I do not preside over etiquette; I preside over standing orders. That is not one, as you would know, Senator Kemp.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop this day, relating to the Palm Beach Post Office.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry that the President is not still in the chair because Senator Collins purported to answer my question at the end of question time by relying upon the advice given to him by Senator Sibraa.
