SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Brownhill this day, relating to road funding.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very interested to hear what Senator Collins had to say on the subject of untied road funding. It has always been my belief that, if we wait long enough, the pigeons will come home to roost. Some 18 months ago—correct me if I am wrong—when road grants to the states were untied I expressed my grave fears, not only to the government when the legislation was going through, but also to my own party. I did not convince my own party, let alone the government, that that was the wrong way to go. So it was very interesting to hear Senator Collins say today—I forget the figure that he cited—that so much of road funding allocated to states finished up being spent on anything but roads.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just gave one example, Senator.
—Senator Collins picked New South Wales, but I can refer him to other places that have Labor governments, especially WA when it had a Labor government.
—Not WA. WA has spent all its untied grants on roads.

—Except for $8 million. The government should look at that situation. Because of my experience in local government, I expressed fears at the time that that could happen. The point is that, although Senator Collins has told us it is a great tragedy that the funds are getting away from roads, the federal government has been guilty of doing much the same thing—or helping someone else to do much the same thing. I refer to the $8 million of WA road funding that was allocated or directed by the Treasurer—
—It is not road funding, Senator.
—It was road funding. It is not road funding now, if you have diverted it, of course. Your former Premier, Carmen Lawrence, has said that. She wrote to Mr Dawkins.
—Senator Panizza, would you direct your remarks through the chair, please.
—What have you got against Subiaco oval?

—I have got nothing against Subiaco oval. I happen to be a member of the WA football members league, so I would like a lot to be done at Subiaco oval, but with the right sort of funds. There was $8 million taken away from road funding by Mr Dawkins and directed—
—There was not.
—I have a letter here from the former Premier of Western Australia, Carmen Lawrence, to Mr Dawkins which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear John
I refer to your letter of 2 June 1992 proposing that $8 million of road funding made available for Western Australia under the `One Nation' statement be reallocated to the Subiaco Oval. . .
I cannot not agree to this proposal, as Western Australia has very substantial needs for road funding which are not being met from existing resources.

There is other correspondence around to show that that $8 million disappeared from the road funding of Western Australia. I have asked Senator Collins before to find out where it is and to redirect it, then we will all be happy. Until he does that, he has no right to stand up in this Senate criticising the government of New South Wales—or any other government, for that matter—for not spending road funding on roads. Senator Collins is the one who can fix up two things: firstly, get back to tied road funding; and secondly, find the $8 million that Mr Dawkins lost for Western Australia. Then Senator Collins can really say that he has done his job right.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Collins to indicate in his response whether he has actual figures of money that has been identified for road purposes but which has gone to non-road functions, particularly relating to state governments and local governments. He may not have that information at the moment—although he may be trying to get it—if not, perhaps he could supply it to us later on. I also ask Senator Collins whether the government is going to do anything about it. Is it looking at retying the identified but untied portion of road grants to local authorities and state governments?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have addressed this issue on a number of occasions. The fact is that the money that was allocated to the Subiaco oval did not take one dollar away from the Western Australian roads program. My understanding—I will confirm this later today—is that there has been a communication between the now Premier of Western Australia, Mr Court, and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). I think an agreement has been reached between them that the money will be spent on Subiaco oval. I know that the allocation of these funds is an ongoing matter. I think the Premier of Western Australia has agreed—I might be wrong—that the money should be spent on the oval. I will try to confirm that this afternoon and get a response to Senator Panizza as soon as I can.

PARA.TAB: In response to Senator Ian Macdonald's concern, I want to make it clear that I do not criticise—I think it is too early to do so—the decision that was taken at the special premiers conference by the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the then premiers and chief ministers to provide for that clear demarcation of responsibility. The decision has much to commend it. It was intended to clearly demarcate the responsibilities of the various authorities—state, local and federal—for road funding.

The arrangement was that the federal government would be responsible for the defined national highway system. We are spending about $820 million a year directly on that system. State and local government authorities would be responsible for their own roads other than the 18,500 kilometres of the national highway. In order to fund those roads, they would receive untied grants from the federal government.

As I said during question time, we provide around $700 million per annum of those grants. I might also add—this is an important point to make in response to Senator Macdonald's question—that this represents only a fraction of the total amount of money spent on roads in Australia, which is in the order of $6 billion per year and which is spent by federal, state and local authorities.

The performance of state governments generally in spending those untied grants on roads has been good. For example—I just happen to know this personally—the WA government has spent every cent of its untied grants directly on roads. I know about the $50 million that was diverted to urban rail in New South Wales because of the protests made by trucking organisations that comprise the Road Transport Industry Forum—and I know Senator Macdonald would be familiar with Bruce McIver from that organisation.

What I said in my answer is the truth. I am glad that the money was spent within the transport system. But it is a general concern—it was raised at the last transport ministers meeting and is a concern that is shared by state transport ministers—that the untied grants that the Commonwealth provides, which are significant, are spent at least in the transport areas of state governments.

As I said before in answer to Senator Macdonald's question, I cannot provide off the top of my head the kind of detail for which he asks, but I will seek it. From my understanding, the state governments have been very responsible in spending under this new system of untied grants, which has only just come in. That was one prime example that got some publicity because road users complained about it. The general spending of these untied grants by state governments has been responsibly spent on roads. But I will seek that further information for Senator Macdonald and provide it to him.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron this day, relating to the government health package.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators may not be aware of the significance of my question. The significance of my question to Senator Richardson was that the entire health package will be subject to veto by the ACTU caucus working party. He did not deny the fact that the whole of his health package will be sent to an ACTU caucus working party. Senator Richardson's proposals are now in total disarray. The Senate will recall that his first proposal was for a higher Medicare levy. When the heat was too much, he sent it off to the ACTU caucus working party. The significance of an ACTU working party is beyond me. This is another clear demonstration that everything this government does is subject to the imprimatur of the ACTU. There is a total alliance. In fact, the minister is almost proud of it.

PARA.TAB: The minister's second point was that there should be an unholy alliance between the insurance associations and the private hospitals of Australia to contract procedural people attending those hospitals so that they could cap fees. That has been opposed by practically every organisation around the place. The only ones in favour of that action are some of the insurance associations because they see bigger money in it for them. Of course there is political capital in it for the government because then the private hospitals and the insurance associations would be able to attempt to control costs.

I have heard it said that this would create a two tier health system. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) should be aware that it would create a three tier health system. People of any ability would not work in that system and they would continue as they do now, contracting their services on a one to one basis with their patients. The second tier would be those who could not get patients to go to them and they would perhaps enter into those contracts. The third tier would be the public hospital system as it exists today. That proposal is to be considered by an ACTU caucus working party.

The minister's proposed third tier is designed to limit the number of insurance associations that are controlling the private insurance industry. Why that is occurring is again beyond me because 83 per cent of people who are insured in Australia are under the aegis of seven insurance companies. The minister wishes to reduce that number. The other 17 per cent of people are controlled by two groups of organisations—11 of which are regionally based and the remainder are industry based. There is nothing to be achieved by this system.

What was more significant in the minister's answer to me today was that he had no alternatives. As I said yesterday, if one comes down on both sides of the fence it can be very painful. That is what the minister is about to do. On the one hand, if his proposals go ahead he is effectively dismantling Medicare. That is significant and is recognised by the Left and the Centre Left of the Labor Party. If, on the other hand, his proposals do not go ahead, he is totally discredited because he has no alternatives.

He has no answer to the rapidly declining number of people who are able to afford private health insurance in this nation. The number is decreasing at a rate of two per cent per annum. It is now less than 39 per cent. In my own state of Queensland it is down to 30 per cent and declining. The minister has no answer to that.

The only chance for the survival of Medicare in this country is if people are accommodated by the private hospital industry and the private health associations. People who are unable to afford private health insurance, or do not wish to afford it, can stay under the umbrella of Medicare. Unless something drastic is done to rapidly improve the opportunities for lower and middle income earners to take out private insurance, the health system will not survive. The minister knows that, I know that and anybody with any knowledge in this field knows that. It must be done as a matter of urgency. However, it will not be done.

The minister will have to consider his position if he is rolled on the proposal he is putting before cabinet tonight. This is crisis point; he knows it and I know it. The opposition has alternative proposals which we put forward to encourage people into private insurance so that Medicare can survive.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given today by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Calvert on Tuesday, relating to Norfolk Island.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins said that it was a detailed answer. It is a detailed answer, but it is not his answer. It comes from Mrs Kelly's office and it is typical of the doublespeak that comes out of her office. My concern and the concern of the Norfolk Island government is that it was not consulted about the Mabo bill. All the answer says is that that government was not consulted. The office has tried to cover it up by saying that it is the policy of successive governments to consult. Mrs Kelly's office said that the Norfolk Island government had sent a letter expressing concern about the bill, but it did not say that it had consulted the Norfolk Island government. The government obviously did not consult the Norfolk Island government.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins said that it was all summed up by the fact that the Mabo decision and the Commonwealth related legislation will have no practical effect, but he did not mention the last part of the answer. Part (e) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the legislation is a national response to a national issue and, in recognition of the primacy of the Commonwealth response, the Government's intention is that the legislation will apply to the whole of Australia, including the external Territories.

In other words, bad luck! Even though the legislation will have no practical effect in Norfolk Island, Norfolk Island will have it whether it likes it or not. I think the Norfolk Island government had every reason to be concerned about this matter and every reason to be disgusted with Mrs Kelly's office for not consulting with it. This so-called detailed answer—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Because, under the cabinet guidelines—and it is pointed out in the answer—the policy of successive governments, presumably previous Liberal governments and the current government, is to consult with the Norfolk Island government about any matters where Commonwealth legislation affects its territories.
—It is not going to affect them.

—The point is that the government did not consult with the Norfolk Island government—whether it affects Norfolk Island or not—and under the cabinet guidelines it is supposed to. The answer that has been given today points that out. I just hope that the people of Australia realise what contempt the government holds for its external territories.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion of censure of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) in relation to an order for the production of a document.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:
That a motion to censure the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That the Senate censures the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) for his contempt of the Senate in failing to answer its order that he lay on the table of the Senate a copy of the letter sent on 14 December 1993 by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to the Minister for Resources (Mr Lee) detailing the conditions which should be attached to woodchip export licences and indicating the forest coupes to be excluded from the relevant forest area.
(2)That Senator Evans purge his contempt by tabling the relevant document before 5 p.m. this day.

My colleagues are aware that the Senate passed a motion this morning that Senator Gareth Evans should table immediately after question time today the letter that has been referred to in the censure motion. The reasons for the request being given today and the urgency are that the particular letter specified in the motion is crucial for a decision regarding the decision of the Minister for Resources (Mr Lee) to renew woodchip export licences either today or tomorrow and making reference to environmental conditions that are to be imposed on those licences.

PARA.TAB: The advice given to the Minister for Resources on which areas of forests should be excluded from the export licences will seal the fate of priceless areas of natural heritage throughout Australia. Communities across Australia are extremely concerned about the fate of the forests in their areas and they have the right to know which areas are being protected by the minister for the environment and by this government, and which will be excluded. Such vital issues cannot be settled behind closed doors and without the opportunity for public input. My understanding is that Mrs Kelly had advice from her department—and I take Senator Coulter's correction of my earlier figure of 81—that 83 forest coupes were to be excluded from the licences and that this number was considerably reduced by Mrs Kelly herself prior to taking the matter to cabinet on Monday.

Mrs Kelly led the environment movement and the wider community to believe that she would force the government to adhere to the spirit and the letter of the moratorium clause in the national forest policy statement signed by the federal government more than a year ago. When I asked Senator Gareth Evans a question earlier this week, he assured me that the government would adhere to the spirit of the moratorium clause and he had no evidence to the contrary. He is now in contempt of the Senate for not tabling evidence that may well be to the contrary.

The clause relating to protection of those old-growth areas—called the moratorium clause—states that activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that may have high conservation value should be avoided in these areas. If clear-felling for woodchips does not significantly affect these areas, I do not know what does.

By reducing the number of coupes to be protected, by not forcing the immediate implementation of the national forest policy statement and by allowing the 1990 New South Wales forest logging agreement to override the national forest policy statement, the environment minister has failed in her duty to protect the environment. By these actions, Mrs Kelly has let down not only the environment movement but also the wider community. She has paved the way for wanton destruction of unique forests of immense ecological importance and has effectively disinherited all future generations.

There is an even more disturbing suggestion regarding the content of Mrs Kelly's letter. Most of the coupes that were successful in gaining Mrs Kelly's protection are in the vicinity of Batemans Bay, within and very close to Mrs Kelly's own electorate. Mrs Kelly has refused several requests to reveal the contents of this letter. As environment minister, she is accountable to parliament and the people of Australia and, in this chamber, she is accountable via the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

The minister's actions—or lack of actions—indicate that she cannot be trusted to act in the best interests of the environment. This chamber is not being allowed to properly fulfil its role and that is why earlier in the day we requested the suspension of standing orders for the Leader of the Government to table that letter. By his failure to table this letter, Senator Gareth Evans and the government are in need of censure for their lack of transparency and accountability and their failure to accord to the environment the priority it deserves.

The minister for the environment is obviously causing grave concern throughout the environment movement in Australia at the moment. But I must also add that the government has a responsibility to allow the minister for the environment to be able to give correct and proper advice to other ministers, for example, the Minister for Resources.

Since European colonisation, less than five per cent of Australia's original native forests have survived and only 13 per cent of these are protected in reserves and national parks. Despite signing the national forest policy more than a year ago, states are still allowing old-growth forests to be logged. In many areas, logging for woodchips is intensified, with trees aged between 300 and 500 years being chipped for paper that will end up on the garbage dumps of the world.

It is unconscionable that before we have even adequately identified the diversity of species, existing wilderness and old-growth forests, these areas are being wiped out. Whole ecosystems are destroyed by clear-felling and with them goes the habitat of vulnerable and endangered species. In Western Australia alone, there are 11 plant species, four bird species and seven mammal species under threat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. When we supported this censure motion—and the minister is sitting here to take his punishment—I thought it was going to be a censure motion. I have heard nothing from Senator Chamarette to date that is in the nature of a censure motion. All I can hear is somewhat of a second reading speech. Mr Deputy President, I think you should get her to address the point of the motion, and that is to censure the minister. She can make any sort of second reading speech in an adjournment debate some other time. We have given her our help to get this motion up and I wish she would address it.
—Senator Chamarette, Senator Panizza raises a valid point. It would be helpful if in some way you could connect what you are saying to a censure of the minister.

—Thank you for that advice. I am sure that Senator Panizza will be able to assist me in directing some of that censure to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. From my point of view, the major contempt of the Senate is that there is a failure of the government to respond to the widespread concerns of the community about the government's failure to support the role of the minister for the environment in protecting our environment. Instead, the government is covering up for her and preventing the community from seeing whether she is doing her job. We do not know whether this government is being portrayed correctly or whether it is actually responsible for our failure to protect old-growth forests.

PARA.TAB: There are protests in every forest area around Australia at the moment. Those protests are the most ardent form of censure one could possibly have of an environment minister and of a government that protects that environment minister when she fails to defend those areas of forest that it is her responsibility to defend.

Senator Evans and the government, by their failure to table the letter of the minister for environment to the Minister for Resources, have demonstrated to the community a contempt for the Senate and a contempt for the community about the areas that are being wantonly destroyed. So I censure the government and the Leader of the Government in the Senate for their lack of transparency and accountability, for their failure to accord to the environment the priority it deserves and for their failure to respect the order of the Senate when it reasonably demands that the letter that the minister for the environment has given as her advice be tabled.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can just explain my position on this: I indicated in the debate this morning that I declined to produce the document in question on the grounds of confidentiality and the absence of compelling public interest. I stand by that position. It is no joke to be the subject of a censure in this place, and I certainly understand the reaction of the Greens and their concern that this particular issue be dealt with in this way. I am not seeking to suggest that there are no public interest dimensions to final decisions on export licences. There are, and the government will be quite willing to make public the relevant considerations taken into account when those decisions are made, when those decisions are finalised.

PARA.TAB: However, there is no overriding public interest to be served in tabling this document, particularly as it is clear that, in seeking it, the main objective is not to obtain the information itself but rather to put pressure upon the government and upon the government's decision-making process. By seeking disclosure at this stage of Mrs Kelly's letter, the honourable senator is in effect seeking to have the Senate attack and replace with its own views the manner in which executive decisions are reached.

This matter has been the subject of debate on a number of previous occasions in this place. When I launched a stinging attack on the then government in 1982 for its failure to produce certain documents relating to tax avoidance and evasion, I was confronted with exactly the argument that I now put—that these are matters for executive government consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were you satisfied at the time?

—I was not satisfied at the time but circumstances change. It is called situation ethics. I suppose Senator Chamarette would be familiar with that concept. The truth of the matter is that executive governments from time immemorial have claimed some degree—not a complete degree—of immunity from scrutiny of their internal processes in order to enable decision making to take place in an orderly way, and allow communications to pass between ministers and policy issues to be addressed in a way that is not necessarily the subject of intense public scrutiny at the time that that decision making process is still under way.

PARA.TAB: I recall the view of the coalition government at that time against me and my motion—it is all spelt out in Odgers where this ranks as one of the great precedents in attempts by the Senate to impose its will, and resistance by the government of the day. The view was that under the constitution it is ministers of state who are appointed to make the sorts of decisions that we were talking about then, and which we are talking now. While ministers may be responsible to parliament for those decisions—I guess this is the key point—it is not for parliament to supplant the role of ministers in reaching those decisions.

We will have to explain ourselves. We will have to be accountable. Minister Lee will have to be accountable for the decision he makes. No doubt he will wish to put on the public record the reasons for the decision, whatever it is, that he does make in the exercise of his discretion and statutory responsibility. But he ought, as a matter of good governance, to be allowed to get on with the business of making that decision and taking such advice as he thinks is legally appropriate to make it, without this subjection of every bit of paper—or the bit of paper that Senator Chamarette wants on this occasion—to being called up and scrutinised in the public domain.

In addition to these questions of executive privilege, public interest immunity or public interest claims of the kind that I am making, there is in this instance—as I said this morning—a possible question of commercial confidentiality. Nobody has ever doubted that commercial confidentiality can be a perfectly appropriate ground for declining to produce the information in question.

I make the point that it would undermine the proper functioning of government, and the proper functioning of the processes of ministerial accountability as they have been developed over many centuries, for such a working document to be made public. What we are talking about here is a working document which may be used by a minister in the process of reaching a decision under his statutory responsibility, but which does not itself govern, let alone dictate, the decision in question. This is simply another piece of information that is relevant to the decision making process in which the minister will engage and he is entitled to make his decision without having to make these sorts of disclosures. The government and individual ministers should not have to worry about the Senate trying to second-guess every step of the decision making process before it is complete.

These arguments are well-founded in the precedents of this place. There have been many instances of documents being sought to be disclosed, and a number of instances of governments accepting that the balance of public interest is in favour of disclosure; but there have equally been many instances over the years where governments—ministers—have taken a different view. The latter situation is the view that is being taken on this occasion. So if Senator Chamarette censures me as a result of that, I guess I will just have to bear that fate with such fortitude as I can command.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) is quite correct in saying that there are essentially two issues involved in this censure motion. There are long and extensive precedents in relation to the revelation of detailed advice to ministers on which they finally make decisions. The other issue is the substantive issue of the forests and what is actually happening there. It is a matter of what sort of priority one gives to those two issues. I would have to disagree very sharply with the minister when he gives priority to the procedural secrecy over the destruction of Australia's forests. It seems to me that this is clearly an instance where the public interest should override the precedent of parliamentary process by which ministers are not accountable for those actions.

PARA.TAB: We now know that we have a wealth of documentation from New South Wales in relation to the way in which ministers there have been consistently ignoring very sound advice in relation to the protection of those forests, going totally against the advice and giving no explanation as to why they are going against the advice. Given that, it becomes even more urgent that we understand exactly why and how it is that Minister Kelly, in this instance, has gone against what we understand to be extremely sound advice—conservative advice, as Senator Chamarette has pointed out, because the 83 coupes which we understand were mentioned are only a fraction of the coupes that could well fit within the national forest policy statement which talks about the protection of areas of high conservation value.

Minister Kelly has evidently received extremely conservative advice and yet has been even more conservative in her advice to Minister Lee. Given the history which many of us now have in documentation in relation to New South Wales, that is indeed extremely worrying. When one puts that together with the information that Senator Chamarette has just given us—that it may well be that those coupes that are to be protected are in the Bateman's Bay area—it raises very serious questions as to whether the minister is not being guided by some motivation other than the proper protection of the forests.

The Australian Democrats can only add their voice to that of censure. We believe that in this instance the public interest far and away exceeds the precedential arguments which the minister has used. It is absolutely appropriate for the Leader of the Government in the Senate to be censured. If and when we see the results of the decision—I understand that decision on the renewal of the licence is imminent; it may be as near as tomorrow—I foreshadow that it is very likely that we will proceed to censure the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) in the very next session. If our presumptions are correct in relation to the sort of advice that she has given to her fellow minister, then I think she has certainly not served her portfolio in the way in which she should.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be supporting this motion of censure of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans).
—That is not very gentlemanly of you.

—Or ladylike. To be honest, the whole issue at the moment concerns the letter from Mrs Kelly to Mr Lee. It really does seem a particularly harmless letter and for the minister to try to claim commercial confidentiality is quite outrageous. Surely the details of conditions about an export licence should be on the public record. The minister has had an opportunity to put it on the record. Commercial or government confidentiality is so often used as an excuse for not tabling documents in this place. Only this week, you yourself, Mr Deputy President, had no joy in getting Minister Bolkus to table documents pertaining to his wild allegations about the Western Australian Attorney-General, Mrs Edwardes.

PARA.TAB: Quite frankly, we have seen enough of this government over the last almost 11 years totally ignoring requests made by the Senate. Senators Cook and Collins have been censured in this place many times in the last few years and absolutely nothing has happened. So I say to Senator Chamarette that even though this motion may be passed, she should not hold her breath that it will actually mean anything. Sadly, the response by this government has not been to uphold the traditions of the Westminster system of government whereby a minister who is censured resigns or is dismissed. This government just completely and utterly ignores a censure in the same way in which it is ignoring this request that has been made by Senator Chamarette today. It is on that basis that we will be supporting the motion.

Obviously, we understand that this issue is very near and dear to Senator Chamarette's heart. We might differ on that subject but, from the opposition's point of view, the issue in question here is whether or not this government will be accountable in respect of an order of the Senate which was made this morning. Sadly, I do not believe that it will be. For the government to continue to ignore such orders made by the Senate is an absolute and utter contempt of the Senate. It has become commonplace for this government to act in such a manner. Senators from all parties in this place cannot continue to condone this type of action and let the government off the hook. If a request has been made by the Senate, the government should be made to deliver on that request, and on time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are seeking to censure because requested information has not been tabled. It is my belief that the tabling of that information is not insignificant; that the information reveals or contributes to a story about a conflict in cabinet—not that that is unusual. Cabinet is an appropriate place to resolve conflicts and to look at alternative positions. We are told almost daily of differing ministerial agendas which are resolved in cabinet.

PARA.TAB: It seems that this conflict has arisen because the government is trying to promise to be all things to all people in this debate about our forests and resources. It seems that there is an irreconcilable conflict. The resources minister and Minister Kelly are on opposing sides of a conflict which cannot be resolved by promises being met. Although this is the impression we have, we do not know whether this is the case. The question is: is this so? It seems to me that a great step could be taken towards answering this question if the letter were tabled. This would reveal the degree of the conflict.

Senator Gareth Evans has described this letter as a working document which might be used by a minister in the process of reaching a decision. In fact, without knowing precisely, we suspect that this paper relates to Minister Kelly's decision—that it is a finite point of her decision making process and, therefore, deserves public scrutiny in its own right.

Without that letter, the public has little capacity to evaluate Minister Kelly's performance in this regard—and the public deserves to have all that is necessary to evaluate Minister Kelly's performance. As has been mentioned by my colleague Senator Coulter, it seems very likely that, without sufficient documentation, Minister Kelly's performance, on any sort of scrutiny, is starting to look very sick indeed.

As far as I am concerned, the one thing this letter could reveal is a little more information about coupes. One of the problems with debates in this place is that we encounter words which are not used in the public arena. Although `coupe' only recently has been placed into our vocabulary, it is a word which has existed for some time in the terminology of foresters and those who would wish to govern the actions of loggers. But in the public arena, the word `coupe' has only recently emerged. I think this word is very important because it seems to be at the centre of what might be in this letter—whether there are 41, 39 or 83 coupes being recommended for protection against the activities of resource extractors during this coming forest resource extraction season.

Coupes in this context are small zones of forest—very small, indeed, really. They are zones accessed by road for the removal of resources. Trees that are resourced are turned into logs and taken away during the season. The coupes may vary in size from a couple of hectares to a couple of dozen hectares. But I would point out that saving or putting aside 40, 50, 83 or even 200 coupes—it is a question of the quantity and even perhaps the quality—is not really a great step.

We really need to look at the letter or the document that we are seeking to be able to evaluate the quality of the areas which may have been recommended. The exploitation of one coupe in a forest compromises the scenic, tourist and wilderness values of that forest. The exploitation of several coupes can actually threaten species—the variety, the ecology and the very balance upon which, eventually, our own livelihoods depend.

This letter will not answer those questions for us, but it will reveal the particular coupes, what consideration has been given, how they interrelate with each other and whether there are, in fact, worthwhile recommendations. I do not think it is at all a matter of commercial confidentiality, as has been hinted by the minister. It seems to me that the letter may very well reveal a lack of systematic approach to which coupes are being recommended, why, and what relationship they have with each other; or whether there is a political relationship which is independent of any of those considerations. It may well reveal a great deal of ignorance in the decision making process by the minister. If I were trying to defend this position as Leader of the Government in the Senate, I would be very careful about revealing or tabling such a document which has the capacity to reveal the ignorance of the minister in the decision making process.

This letter is at the fulcrum of the conflict in cabinet. This letter is also at the fulcrum of the debate between the so-called need, which some people recognise, to grab a little quick cash from the community's resources and the belief, which other people have, that it is the duty of government to protect, in a long-term guardianship role, the incredible and undetermined values of the community's resources. As Senator Coulter pointed out at question time today, these values as represented by the forests are not measured properly in this world. Because this letter is at the fulcrum of that debate, it is absolutely crucial that it be tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. This is more than just a piece of paper that we are talking about, and I refute the comments made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) that this is not an area of high public concern. In fact, there is much greater public interest and concern for the plight of our forests than there will ever be for teak tables or Gould prints. We are not just talking about those issues which excite the press gallery.

PARA.TAB: The government must be transparent in its decision making process. One cannot use commercial confidentiality as an excuse when there are public resources at risk. Minister Kelly is accountable to the parliament; Senator Evans is accountable to the Senate. Given that the majority of the Senate has requested that this information be made available, I ask the minister what action will he be taking to provide the information which the Senate is requesting?
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report deals with the people who generally supervise the running of the Public Service. I think it is proper at this stage to acknowledge the work that the people in the Public Service do. They come in for a lot of criticism from us at estimates and other committees, so it is proper at this time of the year that we acknowledge the great work they do and the very necessary function they perform so well for Australia. Having praised the Public Service generally, I come to those who give us public service in parliament and, in particular, the Senate. They include the attendants, people in transport and, indeed, the whole of the Senate staff under the very able direction and care of our Clerk, Mr Harry Evans and his colleagues.

PARA.TAB: I note the great help that we get from the people in transport, in particular, Comcar, which unfortunately is going through some difficulties at the moment which I hope are soon settled. Comcar drivers provide a great service and we owe them a great debt. I also thank the staff of Hansard who so patiently correct the words that we speak. I thank them for making a lot of magic out of some fairly poor material at times.

I note and give thanks to the advisers and those secretariats that so graciously, patiently, willingly and brilliantly look after the committees. And, finally, I come to the personal staff. I think I would be speaking on behalf of every member of parliament and everybody here now when I thank the people who help us in our offices. Those people who are attached to us as staff really make us what we are and I think it is proper to acknowledge that, without them, the quite brilliant work that is often done in these chambers would certainly not be done. I mention my own personal staff as an example: Marcia O'Hara, Lidia Argondizzo, Kevin Watt and, when one of those is taking time off, Karen Clark and Leanne Schulz.

I hope I have mentioned all parts of the Public Service that help us so well. I will, for example, be attending this afternoon the sports centre and all those people there that help us. May I recommend to the people here—

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't been there.
—You have not been there? Neither Senator McKiernan nor Senator Kemp—I will start naming others—have been to the gymnasium and it is about time they did.
—And it shows.
—Not on you, Senator Campbell. Speaking directly to this report as I have, I acknowledge on behalf of us all the debts we owe to those who give us service.

—I take the opportunity of joining with Senator Cooney in thanking the general bulk of public servants around Australia who do support us and support the Australian public. Most of them do their jobs efficiently and well. Unfortunately, public servants have a bad reputation, but it is one that 99 per cent of the time is not warranted.

PARA.TAB: People confuse the worst actions and decisions of this atrocious government that we have with the messengers who carry out the work of this government. It is a pity that Australians do not understand that it is not the public servants who should be criticised but the people who make the decisions. It is an absolute shame that Australia is in such a mess because of the actions of the Labor Party and its inability to properly manage the country, but that mismanagement and the anxiety a lot of people feel should not be taken out on public servants, most of whom do an excellent job. There are one or two political appointments and one or two who do act in a partisan way, but they will be noted. Certainly, by far the majority of them are very hardworking, diligent Australians.

A lot of them live in this town. I know that my colleague Senator Reid has a lot of very close friends in the Public Service and she appreciates the work they do as well. In the town in which I have my principal electoral office, Townsville, another town where there is a great number of public servants—federal, state and local—they do a magnificent job.

I often feel for public servants, having to administer the policies of this government, having to be at the front line of all these decisions and to having to bear the brunt of the anger that this government's decisions bring upon them, but they do it in a very professional way. They carry out their duties very well and I join with Senator Cooney in thanking them for the work they do for us over the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not plan to make a comment on this issue, but after having been named by Senator Cooney and having my cover blown, I feel that I should say something. I would like to join—
—But you are going down to the gym this afternoon.
—No, I am not going down to the gym this afternoon.
—I don't think I have ever seen you down there.

—That is right. I join with the sentiments so well expressed, as usual, by Senator Ian Macdonald. I would like to draw particular attention to the enormous help I have received over the last year from a number of public servants, particularly those in the office of the Clerk, who have been of great help to me and a source of very sound and moderate advice. I have appreciated that assistance greatly.

PARA.TAB: I have appreciated the help I have received from quite a number of people in the Parliamentary Library. I will not name them for fear that it might damage their reputations, but there are a number of people in the library who have been able to assist me with quite a number of projects and I would like to record my appreciation for that. I would like to associate myself with the sentiments that Senator Cooney and Senator Ian Macdonald expressed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is another body I would like to acknowledge. It does great work, particularly in the fields of privacy, equal opportunity and in instances where there may be racist overtones. It is a body that I think we owe a lot to and I hope it continues in the vigorous way it has of protecting our rights and the rights of those who are in a weaker position than most of us in the community.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to speak for five minutes on this report—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's good.

—Senator Knowles is drawing attention to a fact that I want to draw attention to; that is, yet again, as was the case last year, 33 documents were tabled today, a large number yesterday and I think a reasonable number over the whole week. With half an hour to consider documents, people who might like to say anything of substance have two chances of doing so—Buckley's and none. The reason is that if there is a wide range of documents being tabled—any one senator may have four, five or six on any one day that they want to look at—and they are not available until tabling, some not even then, that gives a very limited opportunity for a senator to have a look at the documents and pick out what they could possibly want to say.

PARA.TAB: Just as an example, I have here the Attorney-General's report, which I will speak to if we get to No. 19. I think I have two chances of that—Buckley's and none—but the prospect of my reading that between when it was available and now is just laughable. So the notion of parliamentary accountability, of our having a chance to have something of significance to say, has been totally ruined by the fact that we have a huge number of these tabled documents to look at in half of hour.

I have a particular interest in the Copyright Agency Ltd. That is the agency that is authorised by the Commonwealth to collect copyright fees from a wide range of people. There is a view in the community that bodies such as the CAL are a law unto themselves. People would like to know where the money comes from, to whom it is disbursed and what happens with the remainder of the money that is not disbursed in any one year. The annual report might be of some assistance to us in ascertaining the facts as to those matters: who pays to the agency, how much it collects, how it pays out, how much it pays out and what it does with what is left. That is a matter of vital interest.

It is of particular interest because, as you may know, Mr Acting Deputy President, there are moves to make the Commonwealth and others pay copyright of a set fee per page for any newspaper article that is photocopied because print media journalists, as distinct from others, retain some sort of copyright over what they have written, over and above the copyright owned by the producer of the paper. They, if you like, forgo copyright for the purposes of their article being published in the paper but they do not forgo copyright for any further reproductions of that paper. That is quite unusual.

This means a huge boon to people who are successful enough to get a by-line but not too much at all for people who write stories and do not get their name on them. We might ask: where does that go to? It goes to the union—that is where it goes. So I would be particularly interested in sitting down and having a really good look through the Copyright Agency Ltd's report. I am only sorry that there are so many documents to be tabled today and so many other things that we all have to do that I am unable to do it.

There are serious questions as to whether the Copyright Agency is the appropriate collecting body for a variety of people. In particular, the matter of journalists is one of very special interest. I personally believe that the case can be made that there is no problem with people so successful as journalists that they want to say to the Age, or the Canberra Times, or whoever employs them, `Yes, I will come and work for you for $40,000, $50,000, $60,000, $70,000 or $170,000 a year'—or whatever—`but I want the right to retain my copyright. I'll give you my journalistic articles for your paper, but I retain the copyright if they are reproduced'. A good journalist will be able to negotiate that.

It seems ludicrous to maintain the present situation in which all print journalists have that as of right. The consequence is that we will have somebody trying to collect across the board and around the nation, and then there are questions of whether it is being distributed fairly. The overriding bottom line is that the money that it cannot see that it can distribute fairly—because there is no by-line on the article—in the end goes to the union. The question of whether the right to collect has been properly passed over to CAL by the union is a serious matter. It is a question of whether joining the union and signing the documents in fact gives the union the right to deal with the copyright rights. It is not a simple matter and not one that can be dealt with now.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I had three chances—a good chance, Buckley's and none—to be able to speak on the Attorney-General's report, and a good chance arrived. This is a two-volume report which is not easy for anyone to get across in a short space of time. I do not pretend to have done that. What I do want to raise is a practice the Attorney-General's Department has engaged in for a number of years, for which it is to be congratulated but which I would now like it to take one step further. The practice I refer to is that of listing in its annual report payments made to counsel by the legal practice of the department.

PARA.TAB: We can turn to this alphabetical list of QCs and senior counsel who have been briefed on matters by the legal practice and we can see how much these people have been paid over the entire year. This is a matter of particular interest because the Commonwealth is a big user of legal services and, in that respect, has enormous power to affect the market, to affect the rates that are paid and to make a contribution to decreasing the cost of justice and increasing access.

In this list we have a kernel of a problem that parliament faces time and time again from people who want to keep things hidden. If we ask at an estimates committee how much was paid on a daily rate to Mr So-and-so, we are told, `I'm sorry, the Attorney-General's Department does not reveal the daily rate paid to barristers, but if you would like to look in the annual report you can see the total amount paid'. It is not a lot of help. I do not know whether someone who received $250,000 was working for 25 days or 10 days or 20 days. I have no idea of the genuine rates being paid. I have no idea of the extent to which the Commonwealth is using its market power to try to reduce the cost of justice. I do not know whether largess is being distributed willy-nilly or not. This list does not help me in that respect.

Another matter in which the list does not help me, and a matter of importance, is in indicating which states get the money. In the federal jurisdiction, in commercial matters, for example, there are some states in which it is possible to get a matter up and through much more quickly than in another division. There are some states which would like to market themselves as being specialists in a particular area so that, if there is a choice of a registry in which to lodge on a federal matter, one might as a matter of costings choose, for example, my state, in a commercial matter, rather than Sydney, because of the delays in New South Wales. Being able to see how much the Commonwealth pays to counsel in different states would be of assistance in those comparisons and in drawing attention to the states which perhaps are not getting not so much their share of Commonwealth money but the recognition for the good job that they do.

I see from the list on page 169 of the report that one person got a payment of $650 and one got $125. I am amazed. It sounds to me like the legal practice sent someone out to do half a guilty plea. A payment of $125 would be about that. Equally, we have people getting $292,000 and $205,000. There are quite a lot of people getting over $200,000 from the Attorney-General's Department.

The question that I want to raise above the questions that I have raised thus far is the following. If we have a small business—a carpentry firm, for example—that does some work for any other Commonwealth agency, we can pick it up in estimates committees and pursue the matter of whether that work was done properly, how much was paid and whether a fair price was paid. But somehow the senior members of the legal profession have hoodwinked the Attorney-General's Department into thinking that these matters should be kept secret. I think it is a load of rubbish. It is about time it stopped.

The Attorney-General's Department should be congratulated on publishing this list, which I notice the DPP does not—I am hoping to remedy that over the next year—but now it is time to take another step and go a bit further. With taxpayers' money going out at rates of over $200,000 a year to quite a sizeable number of barristers, it is about time we started to look at what they are getting as a daily rate and what they are doing for that money.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I endorse some of the comments that have been made by Senator Vanstone about the excessive number of reports today and about how difficult it is to get across them before we are given the opportunity to comment on them. On this occasion, dealing with report No.23, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Equal employment opportunity report 1992-93, dealing with the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Act 1987, we cannot even get a copy of the report. I think Senator Ian Macdonald has the only copy that is available to senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm not going to give it up.

—I do not blame Senator Macdonald for not giving it up. From my investigations this morning in trying to obtain a copy of this report, the answer was, `We have only had a few printed and, so what, the senators don't deserve them'. I think that is absolutely and utterly outrageous. I would like to know why that is so, why the Senate cannot scrutinise the report of the ABC. If ever anything needs to be scrutinised, quite frankly, I think it is the ABC.

PARA.TAB: Coming from the Liberal Party, I can assure honourable senators that I want to scrutinise the ABC's annual report this year, particularly the equal employment opportunity aspect of it. This government is doing very little in real terms about equal employment opportunity. It mouths long and hard about it, yet the net result at the end of the day is quite appalling. Therefore, I would like to know why it is that I cannot get a copy of that report for consideration today.

TALK.START.PARA: —We finish this session at 4.47 p.m., having been given half an hour to deal with all these reports. This situation is a scandal and another example—if any more are needed—of the way this government cannot even manage the business of the chamber, let alone itself. I intend to speak for only a little time so that Senator Kemp can also have an opportunity to speak on this matter.

PARA.TAB: I do reinforce what Senator Knowles has said. It is appalling that we cannot even get copies of this report. I have one that belongs to the Table Office and that has to be returned. My staff sought copies of it earlier in the day and they were told that not many had been made available. When they inquired as to why they were given an explanation like, `The ABC doesn't think that any of the senators want to read it. It is a waste of money. Why should we bother getting it printed for them?'

TALK.START.PARA: —Were they the actual words used?

—I am telling the Parliamentary Secretary what my staff have told me was the response. I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to see whether that is correct and, if it is correct, to do something about it. It would not surprise me if it were correct.

PARA.TAB: The ABC states in this report that in programming and in staffing mix it wants to, in all areas and at all levels, accurately reflect the cultural diversity and composition of Australian society. Senator Kemp raised an incident in relation to that at the estimates hearings—and I hope he might raise it again later. If the ABC wants to reflect the values, the beliefs and the composition of the Australian society, it ought to be a little bit more careful about the very left wing journalists it always seems to engage to do its national news broadcasts. I hasten to add that in Queensland, particularly in the rural areas, many ABC journalists—some of whom I suspect are not of my political persuasion—always give me and every politician a very fair go. They go out of their way to give us a very fair go.

The ABC news broadcasts, which used to report facts, now report the opinions of journalists who are often un-named. One can see a bias coming through in many of the ABC's national news reports and in many of its current affairs reports, from the things not reported, the prominence given to certain matter, the headlines given to different items, and the different slant given to stories.

I am not saying that all ABC staff should be of Liberal persuasion; I am not even saying that they should be asked about their politics. I certainly do not think that they should be. It is very clear—even to a lot of the ABC people—that the ABC's presentation of national news is not always as balanced as it should be. The ABC really ought to address its aim of having a diversity in composition of its staffing mix similar to that of Australian society. I will conclude now and rush over and hand Senator Kemp my copy of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly endorse the remarks of Senator Knowles and Senator Macdonald. It is appalling that copies of this report are not available. I certainly would like Senator Sherry to take some action to find out—
—Have you read it yet?

—I tried to read it; I had to borrow it. The issue of equal opportunity employment was discussed at a recent Senate estimates committee hearing. The discussions resulted from a number of newspaper advertisements that were run by the ABC which sought people of a particular background. One ad sought someone who had to be from a non-English speaking background to work in the sports and rural area.

PARA.TAB: When I raised this question with Mr David Hill at the Senate estimates hearings, he said that—I give him credit for this—he had looked at the ads; that he did not feel the ads were appropriate; and, that whereas the ABC would set targets, it did not set quotas. As far as he was concerned, the ads would be withdrawn and the positions reopened for advertisement and applications.

A week ago I received a letter from Mr David Hill and I have to say that it was one of the great backflips that we have seen. At the end of my remarks, I would like to table his letter. Mr Hill said in the letter that, on reconsideration of the evidence, he had decided that the ads would continue. He did not feel that it was appropriate that the advertisements should be readvertised because he felt that, among other things, it would be unfair to the people who had already applied and that it may be in breach of the Racial Discrimination Act and the Sex Discrimination Act. In other words, the ABC had to employ someone from a non-English speaking background and, if it withdraw the ad, it may well find itself in breach of the Racial Discrimination Act. If that is the case, I have to say that Australia has indeed reached a pretty pass.

This matter raises one of the dilemmas we face when we try to specify rights with people. If my daughter wished to have a job in the media—like Senator Bishop's daughter—why should she not be able to apply for a job because she happens to come from a family where English is spoken? When we pose the problem in that way, this situation seems absurd. I make it very clear that my daughter had not seen the ads and was not thinking of applying. But there would be many young people in a similar position who may well have wished to apply for these jobs but, because they happen to have parents of an English speaking background, they are discriminated against.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—The time for consideration of government documents has concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I seek leave to incorporate the letter from Mr Hill in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Rod Kemp
Parliamentary Secretary to Leader of the Opposition in the Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Kemp,
At the Senate Estimates Committee "E" hearing held on 15 November, I said that the ABC would re-advertise the ABC Radio trainee positions to which you referred during questioning.
As you know, these positions had been advertised on a basis that restricted the range of applicants.

However, now I have since fully considered the implications of withdrawing the advertisements and re-advertising the positions. In my consideration I have taken into account the ABC's statutory duties under the provisions of the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Act, 1987, and the Special Measures provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act (1975) and the Sex Discrimination Act (1984).

As you are no doubt aware, as a Commonwealth Statutory Authority employer, the ABC is bound by the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Act, 1987, which requires the Corporation to develop and implement an equal opportunity program to ensure that it reflects Australia's cultural diversity in its programming and staffing mix.

The aim of these traineeships is to increase the representation of EEO designated groups in ABC Radio's staffing mix in specific areas where target groups are very under-represented. This is in line with both the Corporation's Charter obligation to "reflect the cultural diversity of Australia", and with EEO targets and strategies as set out in the "1993-1996 ABC Equal Employment Opportunity Management Plan".

Endorsement to specifically target and advertise these traineeships to designated groups as an affirmative action strategy was sought from, and granted by, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, under the Special Measures provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act (1975) and the Sex Discrimination Act (1984).

The Special Measures provisions of the Acts apply when an organisation can demonstrate that it is targeting positions in order to redress an existing imbalance of EEO designated groups in its staffing mix .

To withdraw and re-advertise the positions at such a crucial stage of the selection process may disadvantage current applicants to such an extent that the ABC could be in breach of the Racial Discrimination Act and the Sex Discrimination Act.
It is also relevant that the advertisements have already attracted a large field, with several positions in excess of 200 applicants.
In these circumstances, it would not be appropriate to abandon the selection process and, in light of the above, re-advertise the trainee positions.

As I said at the Senate Estimates Committee "E" hearing: "Over the last 10 years, the ABC has tried to devise equal employment opportunity plans to try to get its work force to more fairly reflect the community as a whole. The ABC is there to reflect and project what Australia is all about. To be quite honest, that will not happen until 50 per cent of all positions in the ABC are female, until about a third of them are people from non-English speaking backgrounds and until there is a representation of people who are disabled. The one area that we have targeted successfully is a fair representation of Aboriginal people. They are targets but the ABC is still a long way short of them in fairness or equal opportunity: it is probably ahead of other institutions—certainly public institutions—in Australia".

However, the ABC is reviewing its EEO policies to ensure that other than in exceptional circumstances strategies for recruitment are inclusive of all employment categories. References in advertisements will be monitored to reflect this commitment.
Yours sincerely,
DAVID HILL
Managing Director

TALK.START.PARA: —I urge people to read carefully Mr Hill's letter because it shows the very great dilemmas that we are entering into in this period. All of us would want people—regardless of their background, regardless of their race—to have an opportunity to apply for a job in the ABC. No-one would maintain that there should be any discrimination against such people. It seems to me that, when we read this letter, and we read the original comments from Mr Hill in the Hansard, we are reaching an odd position in this society where we are starting to say that certain jobs must be open to people, not because of their talent, but because of their gender or because of their race. This is a very worrying development.

PARA.TAB: Those who are interested in these questions, and who are interested in how we balance people's rights, should look very carefully at what has occurred in relation to the ABC and its ads. It is quite appropriate that all the positions at the ABC—and, indeed, in all jobs—should be open to women if they wish to apply for them and, if they have the capacities for those jobs, there should be no discrimination against them. We are reaching the stage where we are starting to discriminate in favour of particular people. As a result of that action, we may well discriminate against others. That causes me great concern. I urge people who are interested in this topic to read very carefully the letter from Mr Hill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 25 of 1993-94—project audit—Australian Customs Service—interdepartmental committee on Midford Paramount case compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I believe that the Auditor-General has done a great service by highlighting the lack of response by the Australian Customs Service to the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the Midford Paramount case. The concerns of the committee really fell into two parts at the end of that long inquiry. The first was the concern for the individuals who, as I have said on previous occasions, had their lives, reputations and businesses destroyed by the actions of the Australian Customs Service, and, to a degree, some officers in DITAC. The second was the concern that there needed to be a fundamental cultural change in the Australian Customs Service.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the question of compensation after 11 months and much prodding by the committee and individual members and senators, compensation of $25 million has been paid to those people who lost businesses, reputations and their health. But the other side of the coin—that is, the changes that need to take place in the Australian Customs Service itself—are dealt with at some length by the Auditor-General in report No. 25.

The Midford Paramount case has become very widely known. It has become the benchmark for saying that this sort of behaviour in public administration by public servants is just not acceptable. It was very disappointing, even after the report was brought down, to still find the Customs Service taking the attitude that everybody else was wrong and it was the only one that was right.

The reluctance and tardiness with which the Australian Customs Service has attempted to implement any of the recommendations of the public accounts committee are highlighted in this report. After further prodding by the Auditor-General, there seems to be some acceptance by the Australian Customs Service that the recommendations we made, and that others have considered to be as important as we did, must be paid heed to. If you like, it has been dragged, kicking and screaming, into implementing some of them.

The questions I am asked time and again are: are the people who were responsible for the taxpayer having to find $25 million to pay compensation for the wrongs that were done still in their jobs? What penalty have any of them paid? What changes have been made? The answer is a most unsatisfactory one. There has been very little change or penalty suffered by the people who are busy penalising others.

Mr John Richardson, whose health perhaps suffered more than most to the extent that he was regularly hospitalised and has lost an enormous amount of weight and suffered enormous mental pressure, right at the beginning in evidence to the committee informed the Comptroller-General of Customs, Mr Kelly, that the original prosecutions would fail. He was put on notice that to proceed in the way in which the Australian Customs Service was intending to proceed would fail and that what it was doing was wrong. Mr Kelly had the option of stopping those proceedings, but he chose not to do so.

The Australian Customs Service has been subject to another inquiry after the public accounts committee, which is known as the Conroy inquiry. We expect to hear the results of that inquiry in the not-too-distant future. All taxpayers need to see that a fundamental shake-up and change has taken place. At the moment, there is anger that wrong was done but that no personal penalties were paid and business seems to have gone on as usual.

The Auditor-General's report is very useful in that it highlights the sorts of matters that the Customs Service must pay immediate attention to. As I said, 11 or 12 months after the initial report, the Customs Service is being dragged, kicking and screaming, to comply with it. I commend a good read of this report to members of the Senate. We expect to see the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) and the government taking action to satisfy the feelings of people in the electorate that they are not being run by the bureaucracy but are on top of it.

I told Senator Schacht at the time he set up the Conroy inquiry that I would be delighted to cooperate with it in any way, shape or form that will mean that the recommendations of the public accounts committee and, indeed, any further recommendations that the Conroy committee might think are also necessary can be brought about speedily and expeditiously.

I still have good hopes of that inquiry. I have good hopes that action will be taken and that people will see that, after the years of work that went into disclosing the ineptitude, the obfuscation and the complete need for a culture change, compensation has been paid. Now we must take action to show that change will take place in the Australian Customs Service.
