DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Devereux, I present the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on water resources and toxic algae, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This report finalises an inquiry begun in the last Parliament under my predecessor as Chair of the Committee, Senator the Hon Rosemary Crowley, now Minister for Family Services.
I would like to thank my colleagues on the Committee, and former members, for their efforts in bringing the inquiry to a successful conclusion.
I would also like to thank the staff of the Committee for their work.
The main focus of the report is the impact of toxic algae blooms on Australia's water resources.

The blue-green algae which bloom so spectacularly in Australian rivers, lakes, reservoirs and other water bodies produce as part of their life cycle toxins which, if ingested by humans, can cause ailments such as gastroenteritis, hepatitis and hepatoenteritis, as well as other ill effects on which research is still proceeding.

Naturally, the effects of those toxins on the animal life which is dependent on water infected by excessive levels of blue-green algae are also harmful. In the case of livestock and fisheries these harmful effects have a direct economic result.

The economic costs of blooms of blue-green algae are somewhat difficult to measure. The Committee has found that a comprehensive cost benefit analysis is urgently needed to provide an indication of the type of data required on the social, environmental and economic costs of algal blooms.
The cost of blue-green algal blooms in Australia in 1992/93 was estimated to be about $10 million by the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand.

The direct cost to the New South Wales Government of the large-scale algal blooms in the Darling River in 1991 was estimated at $1.3 million. Indirectly, it is estimated that the tourist industry in New South Wales lost $10 million in 1991 as a result of the algal blooms.
Blue-green algal blooms should be considered as a symptom of degraded water quality which has origins in the management of both water catchments and effluent.

The key to minimising the incidence and magnitude of blue-green algal blooms is to improve water quality through better management of catchments and effluent. This involves changes to land use planning, agricultural practices, drainage systems, effluent treatments and water management.
There will be a cost to be paid by the community for secure supplies of safe, clean water.

The Committee's report looks at the problem of the impact of blue-green algal blooms on Australia's water resources in the broader context of national management of water, water use and water quality.

The report provides a summary of the physical and chemical factors instrumental in causing outbreaks of algal blooms. It looks at the implications in terms of the health effects, the public concern generated and the economic and environmental issues. It covers the techniques for prediction, monitoring, management and control of algal blooms. It looks at the roles of the three levels of government and the community in a national approach to management of algal blooms, and with respect to integrated catchment management.
Total and integrated ecosystem management is essential, so that the ecological health of our waterways is maintained.
The management of the toxic algae problem is part of land and water management in general.

As blue-green algal blooms have considerable complexity in their cause and effects, an integrated management approach having a range of short, medium and longer term mitigation measures will be needed to minimise bloom development and associated problems.
Single management measures are less likely to achieve beneficial results than a combination of measures, dealing with both water quantity and water quality management.
Implementation of prioritised management measures must be on the basis of identified benefits and costs—economic, social and environmental—where benefits equal or outweigh costs.
The Committee has identified 42 issues upon which to make recommendations. We regard all the recommendations as important, but there are several to which I would like to draw particular attention.

Of the nutrient elements required for algal growth, phosphorus is the key element for control. Phosphorus in sewage is a major source of excess phosphorus going into waterways, and a significant proportion of phosphorus in sewage comes from laundry detergents.

The Committee was told that other countries had achieved lower phosphate levels in detergents through marketing strategies which applied public pressure on the manufacturing companies. The report recommends that existing and proposed campaigns to achieve lower phosphate levels in detergents through marketing strategies be continued.

Several countries have legislated for low phosphate levels in detergents. As a result of such legislation in Canada and the United States limiting phosphorus in detergents to 2 per cent, algal blooms in Lake Erie have been significantly reduced. Lake Erie was declared `dead' a few years ago as a result of excessive levels of algae.

The report therefore recommends that if a significant reduction in levels of phosphorus in detergents has not been achieved within two years then legislation should be enacted to reduce levels or ban phosphorus in detergents altogether.
If legislation is required to reduce the levels of phosphorus in detergents, then the report recommends that manufacturers be given reasonable time to develop new or improve existing products.
The report also recommends that a national approach be adopted in relation to truth in labelling for detergent manufacturers in relation to phosphate levels.

Getting rid of toxic algae blooms requires more than reducing levels of phosphates in detergents. The Committee was told that the flow of water in rivers was the critical issue in managing the blue-green algae problem, and that the over-allocation of water to irrigation in the upstream areas of the Murray-Darling Basin had been the major factor which led to the 1000 kilometre-long bloom which took place there in 1991.

Up to 85 per cent of the average yearly volume of water in the Murray-Darling Basin may be diverted for irrigation. The committee was told that the over-allocation of water in the Dumaresq, Barwon and MacIntyre rivers was so great that existing allocations were realised in only 35 per cent of years.

The report therefore recommends that, as part of the development of the National Water Quality Management Strategy, no further irrigation water entitlements be issued in any area until it has been established that there is water available to meet the environmental requirements of the downstream sections of the waterway after existing allocations have been used.

The National Water Quality Management Strategy is a most significant initiative. It is being formulated jointly by the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC) and the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ). It is the first attempt to get integration between the environment and resource interests at a Commonwealth and State/Territory level.

The Committee believes that the national guidelines on water quality should be sufficiently flexible to be able to be applied to specific locations, and should have an ecological quality requirement rather than a purely physio-chemical basis.

The report therefore recommends that the guidelines for the National Water Quality Management Strategy be sufficiently flexible to accommodate the natural variability in Australian freshwater ecosystems.

The Committee noted that in 1982 the Australian Water Resources Council had observed that Australia's water research effort was `inadequate, fragmented and poorly balanced', and had substantial gaps. Immediate national needs were identified by the Council as being `sound management, leadership and substantially increased funding.'
These research issues are now being addressed in the development of the Algal Bloom Research Framework, an ARMCANZ initiative.
The Committee was told that about $10.5 million per year was now being spent on algal bloom research, much of it in relation to other water-related issues and general water improvement.
Governments must provide a consistent approach to funding to enable long-term research and investigation underpinning effective management.

The Committee was of the view that a balance must be struck between rushing into doing some research merely to be seen to be doing something and the tendency to continue research indefinitely to justify a preconceived view or delay making hard decisions.
Much of the research conducted into overcoming the blue-green algae problem has a larger application to the health of waterways generally.

The report recommends that the current levels of Commonwealth Government funding for research be maintained if not increased, and that consideration be given to long-term funding security for approved research projects.

The States/Territories which have had significant problems with blue-green algal blooms have formed blue-green algal task forces, and have State/Territory contingency plans and regional bodies to develop local contingency plans. This focus has enabled better communications, assessment of priorities, research coordination, data collection and the implementation of more streamlined arrangements for algal identification, cell counts and toxicity testing.

The Committee was told that lack of communication between some departments was causing confusion and that agency culture can be a problem. These situations can only be overcome if there is a clear definition of institutional responsibilities and accountabilities, where responsibility is shared, and there is timely communication and consultation.

One of the major roles of State/Territory governments is to provide the regulatory framework which sets standards to be achieved by upstream communities. Single issues managed by separate government authorities have led to a plethora of regulations. Governments are now working at overcoming this type of regulatory fragmentation, and any new legislation should link natural resource industries and the environment.

The report recommends that the development of new legislation or other regulatory measures be required to demonstrate that due consideration has been given to the link between the natural resource industries and the environment.

The regulatory mechanisms need to clarify the responsibilities and roles of various government agencies. The Committee was told that even when there were acts of parliament which specified the responsibilities of particular government agencies, there was scope for them to deny that issues and responsibilities fell within their charter.

The report therefore recommends that as part of the National Water Quality Management Strategy, regulatory mechanisms be reviewed to ensure that the respective responsibilities and roles of various government agencies are clearly defined.
Subsequent to the 1991 algal bloom in the Murray-Darling Basin, there has been a great deal of publicity given to the blue-green algae problem. The public is now more aware of its extent.
Community involvement is an expensive and slow process, and the community must be well informed to be an active participant in the process.

It is the community who pays the increased cost of improved treatments and the willingness to pay determines the water quality. This may create a difficulty in that everyone is involved but the authorities are still responsible, and majority decisions are not always correct in relation to technical and efficiency considerations.

Substantial progress has been made in communicating the concept of ecologically sustainable water resources in some jurisdictions where successful initiatives have been based on individual approaches to each member of the community. The New South Wales State Algal Coordinating Committee has reported that the State Algal Contingency Plan is operating successfully and that the communities are now in a much better position to deal with algal blooms.
There must be a balance between providing sufficient information to enable national and State/ Territory-wide consistency, and the import

ance of avoiding a bureaucratic takeover of the community process. It should be a process of the government assisting the local community to manage its own affairs while ensuring a clear decision making process which outlines the ground rules, and clear responsibility and authority for decisions.

If government views are imposed on the community, then participation will cease when the funds are no longer forthcoming. If authorities do not have a genuine commitment to take on board community views then the community will become disinterested. Integrated catchment groups should be a partnership which has equal say for all parties.

Across Australia there has been a strong move towards integrated catchment management involving the community, industry and all levels of government. This movement has enormous potential to address the environmental problems involved in the management of our waterways, but there are still some matters to be resolved.

It is not clear to what extent the current catchment groups are representative of the community as a whole. It is important that all potential contributors be given the opportunity to participate in the development of local policy and be kept informed. All residents within the area covered by an integrated catchment management body should be eligible for and vote for election to these bodies.
The report recommends that community representatives be elected by their communities to positions on integrated catchment management committees.

It is essential that adequate resources be supplied to assist with the enormous tasks expected of these groups. The question is what proportion of the total spending on resource management is allocated and controlled by the ICM groups responsible for the catchment.
The report recommends that adequate funding of integrated catchment management bodies be ensured, possibly as a proportion of the total expenditure on resource management.

Community education in relation to algal blooms has largely involved the symptoms and causes, but now the emphasis is shifting to management strategies and action plans and is becoming achievement oriented.

There should be more publicity given to successful models so that others can build on successes of those groups. The Committee was told that in some areas community education was still needed as to what the real issues were. The extent to which the community now understands the true situation and the necessary measures is uncertain in many areas, and even the level of community concern is not known.

Little information is available on the extent of the community's awareness and knowledge, and this information would be beneficial in developing new policy approaches. It is necessary that this be assessed to enable adequate planning of future educational programs.

The report recommends that, as part the National Water Quality Management Strategy, the state of community awareness in relation to algal blooms be assessed so that specific problem areas can be identified.

Progress has been made towards long term solutions to the algal blooms problem through a cooperative effort between the community, industrial consumers, land holders, government and local authorities within the catchment in consultation at the policy formulation stage. Long term strategies can be developed and refined as a much better understanding of the causes, extent and implications of the situation is gained.

No one set of measures will solve a problem of the complexity of the sustainability of Australia's water resources. Economic instruments such as pollution taxes, water entitlements, increased costs of water, strategies to reduce pollution sources and the possible reallocation of water licences will only partly address the problem and may only be appropriate in certain circumstances.
Levies collected from irrigators, farmers and other water users should be spent on water resources.

There is a challenge to researchers to provide the urgently needed information on causes and cost effective treatment of algal blooms, on toxicology, the role of nutrients, riverine ecology and the effects of flow rates, the environmental value of water and the realistic appraisal of the impact of algal blooms.
There is also a challenge to the community, industry and governments to provide adequate funding and to use this information.
Accessible data bases for information are being developed which will assist researchers as well as inform the communities.
There should not be research for its own sake. There may be a tendency to keep researching in order to obtain the desired answers, rather than accepting obvious, though unpalatable results.
The emphasis must be on finding solutions, not apportioning blame, and communities may need to take hard decisions in the light of research findings.

Although not all of the answers are known and there are still a number of areas which need to be addressed, basically the problems and the solutions are known. Most States/Territories now have the mechanisms in place, and only the political will is needed to provide the funding to carry them out.
The only reason for hesitation should be the importance of directing funding priorities to give the most impact to the problem.
Plans and strategies are only the first step and their effective implementation will depend on the extent of government and community support.

There needs to be coordination and clarification of roles between the many natural resource management and economic development programs currently in place. Confusion stems from the conflicting objectives, different administration channels and time frames of these programs.
The Committee was concerned that the proliferation of small programs may result in insufficient funds being available for each to be effective.

There was little support for the formation of a new national agency to coordinate a national program. It was suggested that it would be preferable to extend the role of proposed or existing bodies, such as the National Environment Protection Authority (NEPA), the Murray-Darling Basin Commission or ARMCANZ.

Resources may be better spent strengthening the existing system than in creating a new body. The tendency to create a new agency every time there is a new problem has contributed to the existing lack of coordination in some areas.

The Committee was concerned at the lack of coordination of the current monitoring programs. As a matter of priority, monitoring programs should be implemented which are adequate to provide an early warning of the development of algal blooms and to provide information on the factors favouring their development.

There should be a balance between the need for consistent State/Territory-wide and national policies and the social, economic and environmental factors in each catchment. This may vary depending on the social structure and financial constraints of each community. For example, if an algal bloom develops in a community that relies heavily on tourism there may be a tendency not to report it to the authorities to avoid the adverse publicity. There will not be evidence of the problem if it is not looked for.
These situations can be particularly important in areas where algal blooms produce hepatotoxins, which have cumulative effects.

The Committee was told that there was already a plethora of legislation and regulations, but there was still some confusion as to who was responsible for various activities, and even for some of the water bodies.

It is also important that the rules do not keep changing. Water users make commercial decisions on the basis of their water allocations and the rules at the time. Additional allocations should not be made until more is known about the water available to meet existing allocations, plus sufficient for environmental flows.

The Commonwealth Government has provided funding for healthy rivers, but there is a need to know if it is to be ongoing funding to continue projects already started under these initiatives. Commitment is needed to longer term funding to enable longer term projects.
There is a need for an environmentally safe method of treating algal blooms until long term strategies for prevention can be implemented and become effective.

Treatment of algae requires further research into the safer alternatives to copper sulfate, the early detection of blooms, use of increased flow and the use of booms to prevent the seeding of the main water channels from wetlands and small tributaries, the possible use of harvesters, and biological controls.
There is a need to determine safe levels of algae to ensure that the available information is provided to the water managers.

The areas needing research are: the identification of sources of nutrients/pollutants; the critical levels for algal bloom development; what factors influence the potential to form toxins; the priorities for reduction of levels of fertilisers; the effects of intensive animal production; phosphates in detergents; control of sewage effluent; riparian strip maintenance; stormwater control; and septic tanks.
The community must be convinced that there is a problem in order to develop a sense of collective ownership, particularly in small to medium sized communities.

The integrated catchment management concept serves as a focus for action, and must be adequately resourced and supported by government agencies to maximise the potential benefit to be derived from enthusiastic communities.

The integrated catchment management movement cannot be expected to solve problems of this dimension without adequate resources, and support in the form of acknowledgment of their effort and technical advice when needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: These regulations essentially relate to the workings of the parallel runway construction site at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith airport and the dredging sites in Botany Bay to ensure that environmental standards are complied with. The regulations also ensure that specific classes of state laws relating to environmental assessment and development approval processes do not apply to the parallel runway project.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that those provisions could provide meat for sufficient argument to occupy the Senate for some time. I will not address the subject matter of the regulations. I merely state that it is my opinion—and I hope my opinion is shared by honourable senators—that the provision of runways, airport facilities for the landing of aircraft and for aviation exercises are precisely the sorts of issues that the Federal Airports Corporation should concern itself with. The thing that concerns me most—and I have consistently made this point—is that the Federal Airports Corporation has been required to address all manner of issues other than the safe passage of aircraft through our airports and the provision of infrastructure to allow this to occur.

The regulations that have been tabled are suitable concerns for the FAC to have. But since the government's change of attitude to the FAC and what it should be concerned with—that is, that it should be profit making venture conducted in the style of a corporation—the corporation now has to consider a number of other issues. In one annual report that I saw and commented on, the FAC thought that the management style of McDonald's, the take away food outlet, was an appropriate model for it to follow. I have never heard anything so ludicrous.

The attention of the FAC has been transferred from the provision of infrastructure to provide for the safe passage of aircraft to such questions as the licensed access of small off-airport car rental operators. For goodness sake, the amount of attention that the FAC has been required to give to that matter in negotiating with such bodies has distracted its attention from matters which are more appropriately within its purview.

This issue of off-airport car rental operators should occupy the attention of other senators in this place. It is an issue which reveals the ineptitude of the FAC in pursuing commercial matters. It is a matter which has drawn the attention of the Prices Surveillance Authority. I think it should also have the attention of the Trade Practices Commission. What is revealed, after even a cursory examination of the FAC's activities in this area, is that the FAC is presuming to intervene in a commercial process of which it has very little understanding.

The FAC contends—and public statements have been made by officers of the Federal Airports Corporation—that somehow it is required to safeguard the commercial interests of those companies which have paid money to have virtual offices—desks, telephones and staff—within the airport terminals. The FAC contends that those companies, having invested in that way, should have their commercial interests protected by the actions of the FAC.

To me that smacks of protectionism. Today we have had great celebrations about free trade, GATT and goodness knows what else, and yet we have here a government instrumentality acting—supposedly at arm's length—under the guidance of the government's suggestion that a commercial, user-pays and profit seeking corporate attitude should be adopted by the FAC. In doing that, this body, which I think should rightly be concerned with provision of infrastructure, has become a negotiator for access to terminal space. Public statements have been made that it is the FAC's role to protect those who have paid considerable money to have office space at airport terminals.

The manner in which the FAC has chosen to protect such people or enterprises is to charge anybody else who has anything to do with car rental an exorbitant amount of money for access to the airport. People who have a legitimate enterprise in cities or elsewhere, who are located off airports, are charged to stand at the luggage area of the airport terminal. Anyone who has travelled by air anywhere in Australia would have seen in the luggage zone of airport terminals representatives of companies holding a sheet of paper with their pre-arranged client's name written on it, ready to meet the client. There is nothing offensive about that. Those people do not wear out a lot of carpet while they are standing there. When they meet their clients, they then conclude the business which has already been pre-arranged; in other words, they are shown to their cars.

Sometimes other business is conducted at airport terminals, and I am sure we all can imagine the sort of business that is conducted. One of those businesses impinges greatly upon us as members of parliament. Quite often a journalist or somebody wishing to ask for a comment on something will meet us. There are other styles of business. Overseas visitors may come to meet staff of Australian based corporations. We may see a public relations manager at the airport terminal holding up the name of the visitor. These meetings are conducted as a natural result of the airport being a place of transport intercourse. It is quite predictable that one would want to meet somebody at such a place.

For the so-called privilege of meeting the clients with whom they have already organised a contract, off-airport car rental operators are being charged a considerable amount of money by the Federal Airports Corporation in a manner which is not applied to any other business which meets clients at airports. We do not see taxi operators, chauffeurs of limousines, or bus operators being charged in such a way. We do not see any of the other businesses where persons meet persons being charged in such a way. I believe that this Senate ought to take time to notice that and to follow through the formal motion which was passed in this place only a few days ago. That motion required the minister to investigate this. Minister Collins has a duty to see that Australian citizens are not discriminated against in such a way—

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on. You are not getting paid by the word, you know.

—I was waiting for somebody such as Senator O'Chee to suggest that this was not a matter of great concern. It is a matter of great concern, and I will persist with it to illustrate the point that a considerable number of small businesses in Australia, about to enter the most active period of their operations, are being required by this government instrumentality to enter an unprofitable arrangement which could well ruin the businesses of a large number of Australian families. This is something that ought to be considered in great detail. I have attempted through notices of motion, questions, questions on notice and a formal motion in this place to bring this to the attention of the Australian people to illustrate how the Federal Airports Corporation is embarked on the wrong course at the direction of the government.

PARA.TAB: The Federal Airports Corporation has thumbed its nose at the instructions, the beliefs and the impressions of the minister. A year ago Minister Collins received a delegation from the off-airport car rental operators. After receiving that delegation, the minister was able to agree with its point of view. He expressed support for the operators to be allowed access to Federal Airport Corporation terminals, as does every other person in Australia.

In conclusion, the Prices Surveillance Authority agrees with the point of view of the off-airport car rental operators. The Prices Surveillance Authority found that the Federal Airports Corporation does not provide any tangible service to operators, and yet the operators are being asked to pay money. No tangible service is being provided. We know the extent of the service provided: one square foot of carpet to stand on for half an hour at the most. Yet the operators are being charged an exorbitant amount. I have taken the time of the Senate to point this out. I am not asking that anything else be done about it, but I have drawn attention to it by suggesting that these regulations that we have before us today are the appropriate direction of concern that the Federal Airports Corporation should be following—not this other area that it has ignorantly moved into.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the action by the Federal Airports Corporation in this regard is demeaning and dictatorial. I agree with Senator Bell. The government should take the matter up not only as a matter of justice and fairness but in the interests of the travelling public, including tourists.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliamentary Delegation to the European Institutions and Belgium

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of Senator Crichton-Browne, I table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the European institutions and Belgium between 12 September and 1 October 1993.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.
Clause 4.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendment to be moved to clause 5 of this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for luncheon, Senator Crowley said a couple of things that I do not want to leave unchallenged. One is a fairly minor assertion, which was that the words I quoted from her statement at the launch of the ABS document Australian families—selected findings were on the back of the ABS document. In fact, I quoted what Senator Crowley said. I requote it. On page 3 of her speech at that time she said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of the survey the ABS did not include same sex families in their definition of the family.
They are her words—`same sex families'. She goes on:
I am pleased to say that the ABS has recently reviewed this policy, and in future homosexual couples will be included in surveys.

She is pleased about that. She is talking about same sex families. But a more important aspect is that prior to lunch she misled the parliament. I pointed out the try-on—the attempt to include in legislation for the first time in the definition of `marriage-like relationship' or `families' a homosexual couple. She denied that it amounted to a precedent.. She got up and said, `No, the migration act, the migration amendment act, includes homosexual couples in that definition'.

PARA.TAB: She has misled the parliament. Homosexual couples are not included in that definition. I now invite her to point out to the chamber where it does. This is a vital matter. There was some question about it being included, but it was dealt with, and dealt with rather summarily. It is not included as a part of the definition of a family. I ask the minister to respond to that and, if she has misled the parliament, to make it clear to the parliament that that misleading was based on further inaccurate advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly not my intention to mislead this place. I do not believe I said `migration regulations act' or `migration amendment act'; I believe I read `migration regulations 1993', which is the document that has been given to me and which has a definition that reads, in terms of applicants seeking to migrate to this country:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an applicant has a relationship with a person—

It does not specify the gender of that person. I am certainly happy to provide a copy of this to Senator Harradine. If I alluded to the act that was not my intention. I would apologise to the Senate if that was the case. I would be surprised if I did, because I was reading from the document in my hand, which refers to `migration regulations 1993'.It was because of the matters raised by Senator Harradine that I sought from parliamentary counsel any examples that suggested that it was not the first time that there had been a reference of this sort in legislation. The advice given to me was to refer to these regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the regulation number?
—Part 305, class 305, `interdependency temporary visa and entry permit'. What I certainly can do is provide a copy of this for Senator Harradine as soon as possible.
—I would like to have it now.
—Okay.

—The minister has just referred to a regulation under the Migration Act which was, in fact, a regulation that was a substitute for what had been proposed by the government some years ago as a homosexual visa. I happened to be on the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations at that time. We were consulted about that draft proposal. Not only did I oppose that draft proposal for a regulation, but so did a majority of the Joint Committee on Migration Regulations. Very wisely, the minister at the time, Senator Ray, and the government of the day withdrew that draft regulation.

PARA.TAB: It would have been quite intolerable for the parliament and for the Australian community to have allowed under the Migration Act a homosexual visa. That never fully came into public discussion until the minister now puts down a regulation that followed that discussion—and what the minister says is half correct—allowing immigration to this country where consideration can be given to a relationship between persons. That is all it says. It has nothing to do with any kind of definition of a homosexual relationship within a family; it has to do with the relationship between a niece or a nephew and a great aunt; between two elderly people, whether sisters, brothers, cousins or just people who work in the same place who have lived together for a long time and in which case, because one is involved in a family reunion or migrating to Australia, it is appropriate because of the relationship that that other person come to Australia.

There is no implication, there is no meaning given to that relationship, that there is anything like a homosexual relationship. What there is—and the minister is, as I say, half correct—is a category under the Migration Act which defines some access to immigration to this country on the basis of a long established relationship, a bona fide relationship, between two people—completely undefined. Whilst the minister has made references in the past that may have led someone in her own department or another department to give her this regulation under the Migration Act, it has no status with regard to definitions of family. It certainly does not have any precedent with regard to a homosexual relationship being recognised in Australian law or in regulations under a law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was listening in my room to this interchange and I want to support very strongly the remarks just made by my colleague Senator Teague. Frankly, the minister has got it absolutely all wrong. To use the migration regulations' definition of `family' in the context in which she has—at least this was the implication—is an absolute red herring. The definition of `family' in the migration regulations is that of close relationship between persons. The minister is saying that `family' means a close relationship between persons, without gender. In fact, the particular regulation which she quoted—I think it was class 814—is the interdependency visa, and the interdependency visa is expressly for homosexual couples. Senator Teague explained the reasons why such a visa was introduced. This has no bearing at all, as I understand it, on the definition of `family' in the context of this debate. I think we ought to have that clearly on the record.

PARA.TAB: I am very surprised that the minister was not aware of that because to confuse the two is really to try to put two completely different concepts together. I hope that that is made absolutely clear not only for the record but also in a practical sense. Hopefully, the minister is now more aware of the real situation so far as the migration regulations are concerned than she appeared to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very important that the record be correct. I will not deny what the minister has said. Maybe she did say the migration regulations 1993. I have got a copy of those just in case she did say that. There is nothing in these regulations which enables the minister to assert, as she did prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch, that there is a precedent for a marriage-like relationship and a family definition to include a homosexual relationship.
—Senator Harradine is right.

—I thank Senator Teague. I am about to quote from the Hansard record of 5 June 1991—the system does work—to show that what both Senator Teague and Senator Short have just been saying is correct. As a matter of fact, on 5 June 1991 I raised this issue with Senator Robert Ray, who was the minister in charge of the government response to the motion for disallowance of the migration regulations. In response to my question about this issue, Senator Robert Ray stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no equation with marriage in this. There was no equation with it when the first lot of regulations were drawn up—nor the second. The statement I made—which Senator Teague was kind enough to put on the record—stands. This is not the thin edge of the wedge and Senator Teague knows that. He knows that this was a specific response to try to create a regime of regulations which made immigration law fair for all—not just at the whim of a Minister.
I repeat what the minister, Senator Ray, said:
There is no equation with marriage in this.
Senator Crowley comes into the chamber and says, `There is. This was the precedent'.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is trying to use this as the thin edge of the wedge and it is not.

—Exactly. This was a clear try-on. And she is trying it again. Senator Crowley, as Minister for Family Services, when asked whether the family can be defined so as to include a homosexual relationship, always says the same thing: `The family is a self-defining unit'; in other words, anybody can define what a family is. That is what she always says.

PARA.TAB: I know that the chamber has a lot of business but this matter is very important. On the eve of the Year of the Family, the minister should get up and say on behalf of the government, `No, a definition of the family or marriage-like relationship cannot include a homosexual couple or a lesbian couple'. That is all she needs to do. If she did that the matter would be then put to rest.

I want to reiterate that there is no question of discrimination against a person's sexual preferences here; none whatsoever. It has now been admitted all round—as I knew from the beginning—that there is no question of that. In fact, the reverse is the case if we exclude a homosexual relationship from the definition of `family', as the minister is now proposing. But there are people who are hell-bent on promoting and proselytising their view that a homosexual relationship must be regarded in the community as equally a valid lifestyle as marriage, even in the face of disadvantaging, in a monetary sense, some of the very people who are in homosexual relationships.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would draw attention to the other point. I was present prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch when there was an obvious and clear attempt to deceive the committee in relation to this matter. The Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) referred to the migration act and said that this was a precedent. She did that on the advice of her advisers. Either there was a clear attempt at deception on her part or she got bad advice from her advisers, which does not surprise me considering their behaviour on a previous occasion, which has been referred to the President. I think it is up to the minister to state clearly where she stands on this matter. As I did before the suspension of the sitting, I would ask Senator Crowley, as minister for the family, to have the courage to state her position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly support my colleagues Senator Herron and Senator Harradine on the matter that we have just been discussing. If the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) is not prepared to answer, then I presume that she pleads guilty by her silence to what she was attempting to do. The minister owes me an answer to a question concerning the definition of a `family' that I asked just before we adjourned at 7.30 p.m. on 24 November. Clause 5(2)(b)(iv) states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the person and other person are not within a prohibited relationship for the purposes of section 23B of the Marriage Act 1961.

Then such a relationship is described at the bottom of the page. Bearing in mind the fact that the minister has always said that her prime concern is for the child—and Senator Lees has said the same—I asked her to tell me, just before we ran out of time, how a child in the care of persons in that situation would be treated.

PARA.TAB: However, my main aim is to ask the minister how she defines, in that section, what sort of a relationship it is. When someone, presumably living in the household, is described as an ancestor or descendant of the other, or brother or sister, whether of whole blood or part-blood, how do we define whether or not there is a prohibited relationship? As I said previously, a brother and sister may be running a household for reasons I put forward the other day—the sister could be widowed, divorced or a single mother.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or never married.

—Or never married. I ask the minister to tell me how we define, without invading the household, whether the relationship is what is called a prohibited relationship or whether it is, as I describe it, a household of convenience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The definition in this legislation exactly parallels the definition under social security in these matters. Under the social security definitions, in large part, we have to weigh a balance as to how much we interfere in pursuing whether or not what people say about a family is true.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Panizza turns over the page of the definitions and looks at 5(3), he will see that there are a number of criteria as to how one can form an opinion about a relationship, if one needs to. That has been defined in that kind of way to try to balance an assessment about whether there is a relationship, with minimal need to interfere. That is the way those definitions are managed now under social security. I think there is no difference here from how it is dealt with under social security.

Mr Temporary Chairman, I ask for your assistance here. I am happy to answer the honourable senator's question, but we have not actually moved to clause 5 yet. PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: AMENDMENTS TO CHILDCARE REBATE BILL 1993

This Bill is predicated on the argument that child care costs are a legitimate cost of earning income. It is therefore assumed that they ought to be deductible against income for tax purposes. This is the rationale advanced by the government for the view that child care is an economic issue, not a welfare issue.

The first point to be made on this Bill is that it ought to be consistent with its rationale. It should ensure that child care costs are treated no less generously than a simple deduction for income earning costs under s 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

I realize the government has proposed paying this tax-related measure as a cash rebate to cover those cases where taxpayers would be in training or study and thus have low incomes against which to claim a normal deduction. But that is no reason to treat taxpayers with child care costs less fairly than a large company with business expenses. The amendments I have circulated are designed to secure that result by eliminating the threshold for claims and the cap and to base the rebate on the marginal tax rate to be faced by most taxpayers.

The second point to be made is that child care costs exist for every family—unless people here are willing to say that the labour of a spouse at home minding children is there for nothing. Too often, in talking about child care, people forget that parental child care is the basic form of child care—all other carers stand in loco parentis.

Thus, if child care is an expense of earning income for a woman acting a second earner in a family, it is equally a cost for a wage earner supporting a spouse caring for their children at home. The only reason this is not always seen is that we have a tendency to miss the obvious—we take for granted what has usually been the norm. But this is no reason to ignore what economists would describe as an implicit contract situation. Indeed, I note that in 1974 the Federal Treasury did observe that a tax deduction or rebate for child care did raise the question of the appropriate treatment for families where one spouse undertook the care.

I should also mention here that there are cases—often tragic—where one spouse works but has to pay for child care because the other spouse cannot do it. A spouse may be dying, suffer from schizophrenia, multiple sclerosis or some other mental or physical disability. In these circumstances, the employment of a carer for the children (or indeed the spouse at home) is just as much a work related expense as in the two income case assumed in this Bill.

Households can organise their labour supply in various ways. They can opt for having 2 earners with external child care or they can opt for having one earner undertaking to pay the other—whether explicitly or implicitly, whether in cash or in kind—for providing child care so the other spouse can work.

Indeed, in family law it is well recognised that the contribution of a non-earning spouse to the earning of income or the accumulation of assets by the other can be substantial. As Lord Denning remarked in 1952 "A wife is no longer her husband's chattel. She is beginning to be regarded by the law as a partner in all affairs which are their common concern." Sir Jocelyn Simon put it more colourfully when he said "the cock bird can feather his nest precisely because he is not required to spend most of his time sitting on it." Thus the Family Law Act in s 79 requires the Court to take into account "the financial contribution made directly or indirectly by . . . a party . . . to the acquisition . . . of the property . . . .". It makes the point even clearer by directing the Court to take into account non-financial contributions "including any contribution made in the capacity of homemaker or parent."

If family law recognises the implicit contract involved in one parent undertaking to care for children so the other can earn an income, there is no reason why in principle this Bill should not recognise it also. Even if one were to take the view that a spouse's care of a child should normally be regarded as a duty owed to the other spouse without reward or payment, you can still see cases where one spouse's care of the children may be seen as above and beyond a 9 to 5 duty. For example, one spouse may well want to compensate another for extra care undertaken when he or she has to attend to work out of hours. We hear a great deal from the government about level playing fields. I would like to see a level playing field in child care. It is really a rather discriminatory situation—indeed, it is a sort of sexist discrimination on the grounds of marital status—if we are to say that a spouse cannot claim the child care rebate for payments for child care made to another spouse.

On principle the tax system and this rebate system should be neutral between different family choices in regard to labour force participation. We should not discriminate against one income families by saying they will get a less than $2.85 increase per week in the home child care allowance, while others will get up to $61.20 per week. I might add the $2.85 per week has already probably been gobbled up by the sales tax and petrol tax increases pushed through in the Budget and I note that, unlike other low income earners, the spouse at home did not get an extra rebate to compensate even in part for the extra tax burden.

I hope that we can consider more carefully the sorts of biases we are introducing into our social arrangements through disguised tax penalties. I feel this Bill is a useful place to start questioning the unstated but plain assumption that spouses caring for children at home are not working and are not contributing to the ability of their partners to earn income through paid work.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 28, page 11, line 27, omit "each parental", substitute "a parental".

It is too harsh to insist that both parents must be in the paid work force to be able to claim the child-care rebate. Work related child-care expenses can occur when only one parent is earning an income. I would like the minister to focus on this example: a spouse at home is suffering from terminal cancer or schizophrenia or another mental or physical illness. One illness that readily comes to mind is the early stages of MS—multiple sclerosis. The spouse in paid employment has to pay for child care and spouse care before he or she can go out and earn an income. The social security system will income test this family out of any benefit on the basis of the earning spouse's income. Yet child care in such case is clearly just as much a cost of earning an income as in the two-income case assumed by the bill in its present form. What justification can there be for denying the child-care rebate to such a taxpayer, especially when it is remembered that such a family will have a lower disposable income and an extra dependant compared with the vast majority of families? There are other less dramatic examples. Suppose two spouses are in the paid work force using external child care and one gets a posting overseas for three months. They may agree that one will pay the other to care for the children on a paid basis in lieu of employment for the period. Another example would be where a spouse who undertakes night shift works and pays the other for the extra burden of care required. Child-care centres are not available at night. The labour of the spouse in caring for children in such circumstances is just as much a cost of earning a family income as if the children were cared for elsewhere.

PARA.TAB: At law, husbands and wives are free to contract with each other as much as anyone else for child care. It is wrong to assume that the labour of a spouse is available for nothing. If couples adopt a contractual basis for child care there is no double dipping possible on the home child-care allowance. Any amounts paid are a reward for services and are taxable as income. The home child-care allowance is reduced by any such earned income. Take the case of the spouse who is a family day carer on a part-time basis. There are a number of examples which I will not go into.

I particularly refer the minister to a couple of the earlier examples that I gave which, as I see it, are not covered under this legislation. Everyone in this chamber will regard those situations as justifiable, particularly where the spouse of the income earner is suffering from, say, multiple sclerosis. Those examples seem not to be covered by the legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure why Senator Harradine is looking at clause 28. If he looks at clause 29, he will see that recognised work or work-related commitments also include the case of a person who is receiving a carer pension, which may well be the situation for somebody who is very ill. Senator Harradine may be able to find an example which that clause does not cover, but this legislation certainly recognises that someone may be looking after an ill relative and finding it useful to have child care while they are at home getting a carer's pension. That is covered under this definition, recognising just the sorts of contingencies that Senator Harradine is raising. Someone who is receiving a domiciliary care benefit under part B of the National Health Act is also covered.

PARA.TAB: The net is cast so as to try to deal with the sorts of contingencies that Senator Harradine was referring to. I do not believe that some of the examples he gave are persuasive. I am not sure what he means in the case of a family day care worker who works part-time. The definition is an attempt to try to fairly and reasonably allow that where both parents or a couple in a relationship caring for a child are in paid work and are using child care, the costs are rebateable. It is not for other than that. There is very clear intention in this legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the time constraint, I will direct my comments to the first two amendments that Senator Harradine is moving because they really go together. Basically, they alter the rebate scheme by requiring only one parent to be in paid work; in other words, one parent can be at home. I listened to Senator Harradine go through a number of examples. I will add only one more of the many that we are concerned about. A particular example is one parent doing extensive amounts of voluntary work, such as working in a school canteen.

PARA.TAB: We agree with what Senator Harradine is trying to achieve. It is something that the Democrats have been talking about for a long time. We have consistently argued for child-care benefits to extend beyond work related care. We have called for a formal recognition of unpaid work.
I note that the government has put the cost of these amendments at $51.7 million. Considering the change that we are looking at, this does not seem exorbitant. We will be supporting these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept Senator Harradine's request. The bill makes it quite clear that this cash rebate legislation is designed for the situation when both parents are in the work force in paid work. As the bill says, they will be eligible for the cash rebate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees gave the example of people doing voluntary work. They would most likely be using occasional care. Occasional care fees is a similar form of assistance to child-care assistance. That definition of `not two parents in the paid work force' is not acceptable to the government under the clear policy of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be supporting the amendment. As has been previously mentioned, the bill is not specifically concerned with the needs of single income parents. It is concerned with the needs of families where both parents are working or studying. The child-care rebate policy that the coalition outlined in the 1993 child-care policy statement is similarly concerned with families where both parents are working or studying. The dependent spouse rebate is designed to address the needs of single income families. Whether the level of the dependent spouse rebate is appropriate is a matter for debate on another occasion.

PARA.TAB: We do not agree with the issue of paid work. The bill already covers small business people, contractors, et cetera, by the definition of work related commitments in clause 29(a). So the coalition will not be supporting the amendment.
Request negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 29.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 29, page 12, after subclause (2) add the following subclause:

SPEECH.PARA: "(3) In this section `paid work' includes any income producing occupation, profession, business or calling including being an employee or an independent contractor and also includes the earning of income as a partner, beneficiary, or director of a partnership, trust or company carrying on a business.".

This amendment deals with the definition of paid work. My concern is that it will not cover those people whom the minister might wish to have covered. The reason I have moved the amendment is that the definition of paid work in the bill should avoid the danger of any court holding that being in a business partnership does not amount to being in paid work for a number of other reasons.

PARA.TAB: Although I have oral assurances from the minister's office that the definition of `work' covers business proprietors, one may still question whether the qualification of the noun by the adjective `paid' connotes only arrangements for the sale of labour to another party, be it as an employee or an independent contractor. This might seem pedantic, but it is very important. Honourable senators should note that the full force of the Crimes Act could potentially be brought to bear against any claimant if a fraud case arises and a court decides that some self-employed situations are not covered by the term `paid work'.

I have had confirmatory advice about this. These questions need to be answered by the government: what is the government's definition? How we will be told about the definition? How will there be certainty about this clause? The definitions of `pay' and `paid' in the Macquarie Dictionary and the Oxford Dictionary generally define the term `paid' as requiring there to be some obligation to discharge.

There will be circumstances where a person receives money without there being any obligation to make that payment. For example, if a person works for his or her own company, which receives payments from clients, and there is no obligation on the company to pay wages or a dividend, it can be argued that any money the person receives from the company is not pay. So, without my definition, the person would not be performing paid work. A similar situation may arise where a person works for a trust and there is no obligation on the trustee to make a disbursement or a distribution from the trust.

What concerns me is the term `paid work'. That term is capable of different interpretations. One of the problems is that we do not know what those interpretations will mean in practice for people attempting to claim under this legislation. Presumably, the initial interpretation will be made by the department when it prepares the guidelines.

Unlike regulations, those guidelines will never return to this chamber and will not be subject to parliamentary scrutiny. Later interpretations will be left to the AAT or the Federal Court and that will be at the expense of the person arguing against the department's guidelines. I do not think that is satisfactory. That is one of the reasons why I included that definition in the amendment now before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept Senator Harradine's amendment. The definition of `paid work' in the Childcare Rebate Bill reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . paid work (whether or not a person performs the work as an employee)

It is cast in that way to allow a wide definition of the term `paid work'. It not only applies to employees but it also covers the many definitions that Senator Harradine spells out, I think unnecessarily, in his amendment.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that the definition of `paid work' in the bill will cover those contingencies. No doubt there are likely to be a few examples that may cause interest or concern at some stage. The government will keep this matter under close review and if that turns out to be the case then we would certainly address it at the time. But the definition as written covers most contingencies without being prescriptive.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not support the amendment for a number, but not all, of the reasons outlined by the minister. It is the opposition's belief that the amendment moved by Senator Harradine covers other groups that should not be covered by the Childcare Rebate Bill.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 30 to 32—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 33.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition had moved amendments to clause 33 but they were consequent upon the amendments moved to other clauses. As those amendments were not passed, these amendments are subsequently invalid and I withdraw them.

PARA.TAB: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 34 and 35—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 36.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw the opposition's amendments to this clause because they were consequent upon the other amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 36, page 14, paragraph (c), lines 18 and 19, omit the paragraph.
The issues relating to this amendment have already been canvassed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept Senator Harradine's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition also will not support Senator Harradine's amendment.

PARA.TAB: Request negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 37 to 39—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 40.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw the opposition's amendments to this clause because they were

SPEECH.PARA: consequent upon the other amendments.

PARA.TAB: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 41 and 42—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 43.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 43, page 16, omit the clause.

I oppose this clause. My amendment is actually a request. I need to move it as a request because it is not constitutionally possible for me simply to omit the clause. Clause 43 really means that no amount of child-care rebate is actually payable where the claimant's weekly child-care expenditure does not exceed a minimum threshold which is basically equal to some 50 hours of child care per week. This surely discriminates against women in part-time work. This is often the preferred choice of women, especially when they have young children. If child care is regarded as a legitimate cost of earning income, it should be deductible from the first dollar of expenditure.

PARA.TAB: After all, if BHP can claim a business deduction for the first $10 on a $20 million oil exploration project, why should the parliament deny a deduction for part-time care. In her second reading speech, the minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the childcare rebate recognises that the cost of child care is a legitimate expense for parents earning an income.
Just like other concessions for expenses incurred in earning an income, it will not be means tested.

PARA.TAB: Tax deductions of $4.9 billion each year are provided for work-related expenses such as subscription for professional associations and trade unions, car expenses and professional libraries.
The introduction of the child care rebate is a long overdue recognition of the costs of child care borne by parents and particularly mothers, in earning an income.

SPEECH.PARA: The Childcare Rebate Bill should be made to be completely consistent with this statement. If a cost is incurred in earning income, then no matter how large or small the amount of child care, it should be equally deductible against that income.

PARA.TAB: This amendment seeks to make this bill consistent with the view expressed by the minister in her second reading speech. This bill is going to impact adversely against mothers working part-time in the paid work force.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept the request moved by Senator Harradine.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also do not support this request. We understand that the minimum threshold is $16 a week. People who are under that either have very little child care indeed or are already receiving quite a large amount of fee relief. We will not be supporting this request.

—Clause 43(2), as it stands, means that a minimum threshold of child-care expenses, currently around $16 after fee relief, must be paid before the rebate takes effect, and the coalition accepts this. Our 1993 child-care policy statement states that after the first $15 a week of child-care expenses after fee relief the rebate would be payable. So for that reason we do not support the request.

PARA.TAB: Request negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Remainder of bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clause 44, pages 16 and 17, omit the clause.
5.Clause 45, page 17, omit the clause.
6.Clause 46, page 17, omit the clause.
7.At the end of Subdivision C, Part 4, page 17, add the following clause:
"43.(1) The amount of childcare rebate payable to a claimant in respect of weekly child care expenditure is the amount worked out using the following formula:
0.354 x Weekly child care expenditure.

"(2) If the claimant, or another member of the claimant's family, has previously made any other claims relating to child care provided during that week, the amount of childcare rebate that would otherwise have been payable under subsection (1) is reduced by the amounts of childcare rebate that have been paid, or are payable, in respect of such other claims.".

These clauses in the Childcare Rebate Bill to which I am making the requests limit the rebate for child-care expenses and they all need to be replaced. They limit the recognition of child-care costs in three fundamentally illogical ways. First, the minimum weekly threshold amount of expenditure is ignored as a cost of earning income which, as I noted in my address to the previous request, is totally illogical. It also discriminates against families who are likely to be on lower incomes.

PARA.TAB: Second, there is discrimination against families with more than two children in care. They have extra costs for the third child and any additional children, but the clauses which I am requesting the House of Representatives to omit do not recognise the extra costs for the third child and other children. These are not recognised as costs of earning an income because of the limit imposed by section 44(3). That is a discrimination against people with more than two children in child care.

Third, the rebate is fixed at only 30c in the dollar. For many families the extra amount of tax imposed on additional income is not 30c in the dollar but 34c in the dollar. For some earners the marginal tax rate could be even higher—up to 47c. When account is taken of the Medicare levy of 1.4c in the dollar, additional income for many families may be taxed from 35.4c in the dollar up to 48.4c in the dollar.

It is acknowledged that the rebate is being paid outside the tax system to cover cases such as students who may not yet have an income, but that is no reason to treat taxpayers less fairly than in the case of other work-related deductions. Since the bulk of full-time workers are likely to be paying a tax at a marginal rate of 35.4c in the dollar by next year—and if there is a jobs levy they could be paying 40.4c in the dollar—the rebate should be calculated to more fairly reflect tax burdens on additional income. At this stage, I believe that that should be calculated at 35.4 per cent of the total weekly child-care expenditure. While this is not fully fair to the taxpayers on higher incomes, at least it is fair to most persons who will be claiming the child-care rebate.

Amendment No. 7 is a request for certain insertions to be made. It gives effect to making the rebate more consistent with the underlying tax principles espoused in the minister's second reading speech. Subclause 43(2) is designed to avoid double claims, but if it is felt that this is sufficiently covered by subclause 36(d) it may be omitted as unnecessary.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept Senator Harradine's amendments. I do not want to take the time of the chamber by going through the points. I have not even made the points on the other clauses. These amendments, in particular, add very extensive costs to the bill and, for that reason alone, they are unacceptable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will also not be supporting these amendments. Effectively, Senator Harradine is getting rid of the maximum amount which can be claimed, and that means that there is no ceiling on the rebate. Therefore, no matter how expensive a family's child care is, it will still get 35 per cent of the cost reimbursed. We see this as possibly skewing in favour of very expensive child care. We believe there would be very few families with more than two children under the age of five in care. We see that it might encourage families to seek very expensive child care and, of course, they would generally be families on high incomes. I also acknowledge the minister's point that there are limits on the public purse and we do not believe, in view of our budgetary restrictions and constraints, that this is the best way to spend additional money, if there is any.

—Strictly speaking, the child-care rebate is not a tax rebate. It is not offset against taxable income, but is paid according to the level of child-care expenses outlaid. Senator Harradine's amendments are seeking to turn the child-care rebate into a tax deduction, and that is not valid. The level of the rebate is set at 30 per cent and the coalition does not oppose this level. The coalition thus rejects the line of argument underpinning Senator Harradine's amendments and will not support them.

PARA.TAB: Requests negatived.
Remainder of bill agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendment; report adopted.
