DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 14 December of House of Representatives message.
Clause 6, page 3, omit the clause.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1993, which has been returned from the House of Representatives, extends the development allowance to projects in the motor vehicle industry and the print production aspects of projects in the print media.

PARA.TAB: These amendments fulfil an election promise. The Senate originally passed an amendment that removed the $50 million threshold requirement for these projects, arguing why should only big players get the benefit. The government asks why projects in these two industries should not be subject to the threshold when projects in other industries have had to meet the threshold. Also, there could be a difficulty when so-called big players which also have small projects miss out in respect of their small projects.

It is not only a big players' benefit. We have indications, for example, from the car component manufacturers that they are prepared to put together joint venture projects which will qualify, and the legislation specific allows this. The $50 million threshold plays an important part in defining what a project is. The broad project definition, `a discrete productive facility' becomes less clear without the threshold, particularly for upgrades and expansions. Also, there will be a revenue cost associated with removing the threshold which the government is not keen to wear, particularly as it would apply to projects already commenced. I move:
That the committee agree to the amendment made by the House of Representatives in the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the amendment that we are being asked to agree to is, in effect, the House of Representatives' rejection of the amendment we made to the bill here in the Senate, which was to remove the $50 million minimum threshold level for projects for the motor vehicle industry and the print media. That amendment to remove the $50 million lower limit for projects to qualify under the Investment Development Allowance Authority Bill was moved by the coalition and supported by the Democrats when the bill was before the Senate in September and early October.

PARA.TAB: Without taking too much of the committee's time, the chronology was as follows: the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill was introduced here by the government a few months ago to extend the development allowance—this was contained in the original Development Allowance Authority Bill—to projects in the motor vehicle and printing production industries.

When the original Development Allowance Authority Bill was introduced in 1992—it had its genesis in the government's One Nation statement—it provided a tax deduction of 10 per cent on eligible plant during the first year of installation or use. Eligible projects were to have a capital cost of over $50 million and be approved by a special statutory authority called the Development Allowance Authority.

When the original bill came in, we on this side of the Senate had difficulty with the $50 million figure below which projects would not qualify for this special allowance because we felt that it discriminated against small and medium sized business. Unfortunately, we were unsuccessful in gaining the support of the Democrats, in particular, for the carriage of an amendment to remove the $50 million lower threshold.

But when the amendment bill came back here as one of the budget bills for 1993—I think it was one of the budget bills; it was debated here as part of the budget process—to extend the original bill to cover the motor industry and the print media, which had not been included in the first bill, for reasons that are difficult to comprehend, the second time around we did get the support of the minor parties. As a result of that, we found the odd situation, which we are now debating, whereby the Senate approved the abolition of the $50 million lower limit for the motor industries and print media projects but retained, by virtue of the original bill, the $50 million lower threshold for everything else.

We have always had difficulties with that lower threshold. First, it discriminates against projects with a capital cost of less than $50 million. Second, it did nothing for investment in plant and equipment in the poorest areas of the economy that most needed fixing. The original problem arose because the government, as is now its wont, did not think it all through.

Despite the fact that the One Nation statement was supposed to encourage investment in plant and equipment and in investment generally to get this economy going—at that stage the economy was in desperate straits so far as its depressed condition was concerned—the putting in of a $50 million lower limit to qualify for the investment allowance did nothing at all to help the small and medium sized companies and ventures. They were the ones that really needed helping. In that sense it was a classic example of this government's absolute lack of understanding of what was needed to get economic recovery going. It is quite ridiculous for the government just to concentrate its efforts in getting the big boys in the economy going if, in the process, it will disadvantage and do nothing at all to encourage small and medium size ventures to get going.

We have always had this problem with the $50 million lower project limit. Frankly, we were somewhat surprised that we got support the second time round in relation to the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill when the proposal was extended to cover the motor industry and the print media, which had been excluded the first time round. We got support from the minor parties the second time round on getting rid of the $50 million lower limit, although we did not get it the first time round. That in itself created an anomaly which the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) quite rightly pointed out earlier.

If the Senate's amendment to the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill that we are now discussing had been accepted by the House of Representatives, then we would have had the distinction whereby motor industry and print media projects would not have had any lower threshold at all, whereas everything else would have had the $50 million lower threshold. That is inconsistent and we accept that. But I would have to say that the whole process, which finished up in a mess, was due entirely to the government's incompetence in the first instance in putting in that threshold at all.

Reluctantly, the coalition will accept the government's amendment in the House of Representatives; namely, to reject our initial proposal to abolish the $50 million limit. We will not press our amendment. However, we do think that our original position is correct in the sense that if the government is really serious about getting this economy going again and about providing encouragement and support to those sectors of the private sector that are the lifeblood of this country, which is small and medium size business, then it would not have allowed itself to get into this position.

The simple fact is that this government, firstly, is totally incompetent in economic policy making and economic management; and, secondly, that arises in important degree because of an ideological mind-set against small and medium size business in this country. I think the only reason why that is the case flows from the fact that this government, without exception throughout our history, is a corporatist government. It believes that the only way to get things done is to do deals between big government here in Canberra and big business and big unions. So far as small and medium size businesses are concerned, they can go hang and the devil take the hindmost with them.

We totally reject that approach. That was why we adopted the attitude and the situation towards these bills that we did. Having said that, we will not press to retain the Senate's amendment that was moved the first time round because we do understand the anomalies that it produces.

In conclusion I want to stress two points that come out of all of this. The first is the government's absolute disregard for the needs of small and medium size business in this country. The second is that this is another classic example of the government's inability to put together an economic policy package and to administer it with any coherence at all. With those few brief remarks, on behalf of the coalition I will leave the matter there. We will not be pressing the matter further.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—The question now is:
That the resolution be reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not object to the resolution being reported, but perhaps I could make just one other point. Another important reason why we will not press our earlier approach is that if we were to continue to press it, it would cause more delays in the bill's passage.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, the present situation with regard to eligibility for the development allowance has attached to it a deadline of 31 December. If this bill is not passed and royal assent is not received by 31 December, then a lot of those projects that would otherwise have been advantaged as a result of the legislation will miss out. That is a significant reason why we will not be pressing our amendment.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the committee agree to the amendments made by the House of Representatives in the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments made by the House of Representatives are technical amendments, consequential to changes to the ABC bill made in the Senate during its initial consideration in May this year. The ABC bill contained amendments to simplify and update the technical services provisions of the ABC act; those amendments were omitted by the Senate. A close examination of the technical services provisions, following the making of those amendments, has made it clear that many of the archaic definitions in the act can be removed without affecting the operation of the technical services provisions. The proposed amendments, therefore, remove the unnecessary definitions.

PARA.TAB: The bill passed by the Senate modernises the terminology in the ABC act by removing an outdated distinction between broadcasting—meaning broadcasting by radio—and television. The proposed amendments insert a new definition of `program' to support the modernisation of terminology. They also update the terminology in the technical services provisions which were retained as a result of the Senate amendments. The amendments will not affect Commonwealth expenditure or revenue, and I commend them to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would simply like to say that, acting in the spirit of Christmas and on the basis of good faith which is, from time to time, forthcoming from the other side of the chamber, I am sure I can confidently take what Senator Faulkner has said at face value.
—Have I ever misled you?
—Not intentionally, I am sure. Some of Senator Faulkner's interjections leave a lot to be desired, I might say.
—Let's not canvass any of yours.

—True; we will talk about that later. All I can say is that, to the extent that this does update and modernise the definition of broadcasting services, it would seem to be a long overdue amendment. Certainly, removing distinctions between radio and television when it comes to broadcasting, I would have thought, is a very worthwhile improvement. Therefore, we would certainly support any attempt to bring the broadcasting services legislation into line with the rapid rate of technological change. It would seem to us that this will assist in the process of ensuring that legislation does reflect what is actually going on in the real world.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

This bill proposes amendments to a number of Acts administered within the portfolio of the Prime Minister and to other legislation dealing with matters relevant to the Prime Minister's portfolio. Details of the various amendments are set out in the explanatory memorandum which accompanies the Bill. I will deal only with the more important aspects.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill contains amendments to the Freedom of Information Act 1982 and the Archives Act 1983 relating to access to documents known as Cabinet notebooks. The Archives Act will be amended to provide a clear and sensible archival mechanism that, for the first time, will allow public access to notebooks recording the deliberations of Cabinet after a period of fifty years. At the same time, Cabinet notebooks will be protected from access under the Freedom of Information Act during that period. While these Acts do not fall within the portfolio responsibilities of the Prime Minister, the amendments are included in this portfolio bill because of the Prime Minister's responsibility for the Cabinet process.

Mr President, honourable Senators may be aware that, on 16 December 1992, amendments to the Archives Act, the Freedom of Information Act and the Evidence Act were introduced into the House of Representatives in a bill titled the Cabinet Notebooks (Access and Protection) Bill 1992. That bill lapsed on the calling of the last federal election in March. An explanation of the Cabinet notetaking system was included in the second-reading speech accompanying that bill.

In April 1993 the High Court handed down its decision in relation to the appeal by the Commonwealth against a decision of the Full Court of the Federal Court in the case of the Northern Land Council v Commonwealth in which the Council sought access to a number of Cabinet notebooks from the 1970s. While not finding that there is an absolute immunity from production of Cabinet notebooks in court proceedings, the High Court found that there were "extremely strong" considerations of public policy weighing against their production. Only exceptional circumstances, such as non-disclosure impeding defendants in the conduct of their defence or allegations of serious misconduct on the part of Cabinet Ministers, should justify disclosure in such proceedings.

On the basis of this decision, the Government has decided that it is unnecessary at the present time to include provisions regulating the use of Cabinet notebooks in court proceedings in the Evidence Act or the proposed Evidence Bill.

Mr President, this bill also implements the Government's December 1992 response to the Report of the Review of the Office of the Ombudsman by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. In line with the recommendations of the Standing Committee, the major amendments to the Act will:

PARA.TAB: give the Ombudsman jurisdiction to investigate administrative actions of federal court registries and Commonwealth parliamentary departments.
give the Ombudsman a discretion to decline to investigate or to cease investigating commercial activities of Commonwealth agencies; and
allow the Ombudsman to transfer complaints to the Australian Broadcasting Authority, the Merit Protection and Review Agency or an industry ombudsman, where appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the amendments to implement the Government's response to the Senate Standing Committee's report, a number of other minor amendments to the Ombudsman Act will be made.

Mr President, the bill also includes amendments to the Public Service Act 1922 and the Superannuation Act 1976 to enable effect to be given to the Government's decision to allow secretaries of departments and a limited number of equivalent-level statutory office-holders to relinquish their continuing tenure in the public service, and the value which attaches to that tenure, in return for a reasonable loading on their salaries being set by the Remuneration Tribunal. (The Government has recommended to the Tribunal that the loading should be set at 20 per cent.)

The changes we are making are a natural evolution of the changes made 10 years ago when the Parliament removed the right to tenure in particular departmental head positions and the policy of rotations on a five year basis was introduced. Enabling secretaries of departments to choose whether to retain their tenure in the public service or to relinquish it in return for a salary loading is a logical progression which has taken place in many other public services both here and overseas. Even with the loading, which will be set by the independent Remuneration Tribunal, the remuneration of Commonwealth heads of departments, with their national level responsibilities, will not match that of their counterparts in Victoria and New South Wales.

In sharpening the focus on the policy of rotation by making greater use of fixed-term appointments, the Government will continue to retain the traditional virtues of the public service with the emphasis there has always been on having heads of departments with great personal integrity, political impartiality and preparedness to offer the frank and fearless advice we expect of them.

The bill includes other amendments of a minor nature to the Public Service Act 1922 to ensure that the Act adequately reflects the requirements of contemporary public sector administration. For example, amendments are included relating to the discipline process, excess officers, Joint Selection Committees and the mobility provisions of the Act.

The discipline process as it relates to unattached officers will be brought more into line with the process that applies in relation to other officers. The amendments reflect the recommendations of the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in December 1992 on its inquiry into the management of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

The amendments relating to excess officers will ensure that the appeal mechanism available to excess officers in relation to transfers is only available to those excess officers who have applied for transfer to a position.
Other amendments will allow for the use of a Joint Selection Committee order of merit in filling identical and subsequent vacancies.
The bill also makes a number of minor or technical amendments to a number of other Acts. Details of these are set out in the explanatory memorandum.
I commend this bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 proposes some changes to the act. Due to the implementation of the guillotine in the other place, this is the first opportunity that has arisen in the parliament for any debate on this bill.

PARA.TAB: The bill proposes to amend two acts—namely, the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1991. Briefly, what is proposed is that first of all amendments be made to section 52, division 8 of part III, and section 5J in regard to assessing allocated pensions and annuities according to the managed investment rules for the purpose of the income and assets test. Managed investments is a loose term generally used to describe market linked and capital guaranteed investments.

Market linked investments are subject to fluctuations in value because of market forces, for example, friendly society bonds, public unit trusts and certain approved deposit funds. If an investment is unlikely to decrease in value through market fluctuations, it is regarded as an accruing return investment or a capital investment, and this sort of investment includes insurance bonds, approved deposit funds and deferred annuities.

Allocated pensions are a type of retirement investment that pays a retiree a regular income each year in return for a lump sum investment, and annuities are another retirement investment product with a life office which treats the original capital differently. The second change is the inclusion of shares and securities listed on any stock exchange other than an Australian stock exchange in subsection 5J(1) of the principal act.

The third change is the extension of children of veterans or members of the Australian Defence Force in receipt of extreme disability adjustment through an amendment to section 116 of the principal act. The fourth and final amendment is to extend the sunset clause for the payment of advance pharmaceutical allowance for a further 12 months through an amendment to section 17 of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1991 and section 118F of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

In regard to the extension of advance pharmaceutical allowance, the opposition has no difficulty with this extension and will be supporting it. The payment of this allowance is an advance of up to seven fortnights worth of a person's pharmaceutical allowance, and it is to the advantage of those who are chronically ill or those who, due to some illness, require a large volume of medication. To repeal this without ensuring that some alternative mechanism is in place could seriously disadvantage some veterans.

Similarly, the opposition will be supporting the extension of eligibility of the veterans' children education scheme to the children of veterans or force members in receipt of extreme disability adjustment. Currently, only the children of a deceased veteran who was on an EDA, extreme disability adjustment, may receive this assistance. This amendment is logical and fair.

The principal act contains a number of such cases where a particular pension or benefit becomes available on the death of the veteran. Yet it is very likely the awarding of additional assistance to the spouse or dependant would be particularly helpful during the remaining life of the veteran.

A point of contention for us is the allocated pensions and annuities. The opposition will not be supporting the amendments concerning the assessment of allocated pensions and annuities according to the managed investment rules; nor will the opposition be supporting the change to the definition of `shares' and listed securities. We oppose these changes for one clear and simple reason—that is, that an inquiry has been established by the government, thanks to pressure from the opposition, into retirement incomes and means testing.

This review into retirement income streams and means testing of retirement incomes, which the opposition has said we would undertake when in government, is long overdue. The need for this review has become more apparent with the government's controversial treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares and investments.

The opposition has put amendments to the government draft terms of reference and these have been accepted. We believe that the terms of reference needed to be more focused. The opposition also believe the view needed to reflect that any retirement or incomes policy needs to expand and maximise incentive for self-provision. Hopefully this review will get under way as soon as possible as the inequity of some of the government's ad hoc schemes for saving money needs to be exposed.

As a result of current policy of the government, we have the situation where veteran service pensions and social security aged pensioners are being actively discouraged from trying to provide for themselves, even partially, during their retirement years. Additionally, the treatment of retirement packages such as allocated pensions by the tax office and the Department of Social Security is different. In his Security in retirement paper issued in June last year, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) announced that the government was endorsing allocated pensions. He indicated that the taxation treatment afforded to traditional life office annuities would be extended to allocated pensions.

The Treasurer at that stage also acknowledged the flexible nature of allocated pensions. He recognised the important role allocated pensions could play in encouraging Australians to look to income streams rather than lump sums. Yet within a couple of weeks of this statement being released by the Treasurer, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) made a public announcement of proposals which would have a detrimental impact on people who had taken the Treasurer's statement to heart for the Minister of Social Security's announcement ensured people who invested in allocated pensions would be penalised.

It is difficult for people to prepare for their retirement when the rules are changing so constantly. But it is dishonest when statements encouraging the taking up of a particular scheme are made by one minister and statements announcing the retirement scheme is to become a milch cow are made by another.

Then there is the vexed question of the formula which is being used to calculate the amount of income which is being earned. I have received many letters—as I am sure have many of my colleagues in this chamber—which show quite clearly that the amount the person actually receives and the amount the Department of Veterans' Affairs assesses them to have received is quite different. In some cases that amount is quite small. In some cases, dependent on the amount invested and the type of investment, it can be quite substantial. Ultimately, the point is that the pension is being reduced according to an amount of money which has not being received by the pensioner.

There is also the case of those people who invested a certain amount of capital and investment last decade and saw the value of that investment decline dramatically because of the prevailing economic circumstances at the time. Many of those investments are now starting to recover and their face value is improving. But in most cases that improvement is not with regard to the purchase price of the original investment. All we have seen is an improvement in the current market price of those investments as opposed to the immediate past. But according to the government this is a real benefit to the beneficial owner and it is being assessed as capital growth. That is totally without logic or any fairness.

The point must be stressed because it represents one of the main anomalies in the system of calculation the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Social Security are using. For many pensioners the value of their income units is still less than what they originally paid for them. But because of the listing of the units on the stock exchange and their gradual recovery in price, pensioners are being assessed at a high rate despite the fact that they have still not recovered to their purchase price.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Social Security are making a paper assessment, which is reducing pensions to such a level that some pensioners are having to sell part of their investment in order to regain some real as opposed to notional income. In many cases these units are being sold at a loss. It is quite absurd to call this an act of policy of encouraging people to provide for themselves.

The unfairness and the anomalies under the present means test are affecting an estimated 200,000 pensioners who hold managed investments and who have been receiving assessments under the same unfair scheme since March. In September this year 55,670 pensioners had their pensions decreased because of a reassessment by the Department of Social Security. This resulted in a net saving for the government of $1.055 million per fortnight. In July, almost 35,000 social security pensioners experienced a pension decrease.

To propose the changes we are dealing with in this bill at this time is unacceptable. We believe that there can be no more fiddling around the edges of the retirement income and means testing system until the inquiry into retirement incomes and means testing has completed its investigation, made its recommendations and the report is thoroughly studied.

The opposition is aware that these amendments mirror amendments proposed under the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992, which has been passed as act No. 230 of 1993. The income and assets test for service pensions under the Veterans' Entitlements Act and for aged pensions under the Social Security Act have always been identical tests. They have been identical as essentially each of these pensions was designed to meet a similar purpose—the provision of retirement income.

When the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) was debated in the Senate, it was resolved to have the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation inquire into the changes in the treatment of allocated pensions and annuities for social security purposes. The actual wording of the reference to the committee was that it was to inquire into and report on:

SPEECH.PARA: the likely effect of the changes in the treatment of allocated pensions and annuities for social security purposes contained in Division 19 of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act (No. 3) 1992—

The superannuation committee has spent quite some time on this reference. It has received considerable evidence of the hazards of treating allocated pensions as managed investments for social security purposes. Yet, irrespective of the evidence presented to or recommendations of the committee, the minister has announced that the changes to the social security treatment of allocated pensions will commence as soon as the report has been presented by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Last week, the chairman of the superannuation committee, Senator Watson, announced that the committee would be preparing a paper for the Minister for Social Security before presenting its report to the Senate. Senator Watson estimates that the report will be tabled during the autumn sittings next year. Irrespective of the weight of evidence presented, the minister intends to proceed with the changes. The minister should wait until the committee has reported and until the matter has been discussed in the Senate, but Mr Baldwin insists on charging ahead. Regrettably, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs intends to follow Mr Baldwin down the same path.

If the review finds, as the Senate superannuation committee apparently has, that there are hazards in treating allocated pensions as managed investments, then the government may be forced to move additional amendments to clean up the system. In the meantime, many pensioners will have been forced to sell at a loss to ensure that they receive some real, as opposed to notional, capital gain.

There is also the matter of the considerable inconvenience that the government will be imposing on elderly veterans for possibly a short period of time. Along with the legislative changes come the actual mechanisms for assessing investment income and, therefore, the amount of service pension.

What we are talking about here is a massive, inconvenient and costly amount of paperwork. It is massive both for the department and for the veteran. It is costly for the department and the veterans, who have to prepare and copy and phone investment houses and so on to come to an assessment of what their investment is worth.

Finally, there is the inconvenience. Elderly people are being asked to check and report every couple of months. If we know anything about elderly people at all, we know that they dislike change; they particularly detest constant change. The lack of consistency in their planning, the worry and the uncertainty that comes from this all adds to the stress on elderly Australians and they should not be subjected to these pressures. They should not be subjected to constant change and the inherent anxiety that comes from it.

If some of the bureaucrats that put this scheme up to the minister had any knowledge or contact with the elderly of this community, they would realise the truth of what I am saying. I am sure they would not propose this constant change and the uncertainty that brings on the elderly people who intellectually, mentally and emotionally do not have the resources to cope with it.

The opposition will also be opposing the change to include overseas share markets and not just shares that are listed securities on the Australian Stock Exchange. Until the review is complete, a stop has to be put at some stage to any more changes to the system. The opposition will be more than happy to reconsider this amendment after the findings and the recommendations have been made by the review committee.

The opposition has no intention of being a party to any more changes to the system while it remains a pasted together series of amendments and mechanisms which are all aimed at collecting dollars rather than providing fairness, equity and simplicity for those no longer in the paid work force.

Additionally, we are ill-disposed to accept unnecessary tax on the incomes of the veterans of this nation. The changes to the managed investment area have impacted quite heavily on many service pensioners, pensioners who served this nation in time of war and, as such, qualified for this pension. Veterans have also felt the impact of the changes in regard to unrealised capital gains on shares and listed securities.

What the minister is proposing here is that the trigger for the commencement of the assessment of allocated pensions and annuities, according to the managed investment rules, will be the tabling of the superannuation committee's report. It does not seem to matter what the contents of that report might be and it does not seem to matter to the minister that the review of retirement incomes and means testing will be also under way. Nor does it matter that the independent review might come down with a series of recommendations which could drastically change the system again.

What is going to come out of all of this is an area of great uncertainty and great stress for those elderly veterans who simply cannot cope with it. The opposition therefore will be opposing these moves. In the quest for a more certain economic environment for the veterans of this nation, we will be opposing those amendments. We hope that the Democrats and the Green senators will join us in helping to provide a more certain and more predictable environment for Australian veterans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the time restrictions on us and, indeed, the very short amount of time before we rise for Christmas, I seek leave to incorporate my speech. As we move through the committee stage I will speak to each clause of the bill as we come to it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: VETERANS AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993
Mr Chairman, I am not going to take up much of the Senate time because we still have so much to get through.
The Australian Democrats have no problem with two of the measures in this bill, in fact we welcome them.

Firstly, we are pleased to see the extension of benefits under the Veterans' Children Education Scheme to the children of veterans who receive Extreme Disablement Adjustment, which was announced in the budget.

We also believe it is sensible to extend the operation of Advance Pharmaceutical Allowance for a further twelve months. This up-front payment is valuable to those who have a need for a large number of prescription items and it should be continued.

I now turn to the measure to change the definition of "shares and listed securities". The Democrats are strongly of the opinion that we in this place have interfered too much in the incomes of retirees over the last few years. Some of the measures have been beneficial, but more often, all the government has done is reduce benefits, and to add insult to injury, combine that reduction with copious amounts of paperwork which serve only to worry and confuse people as they get to a stage in their lives when they don't cope so well with change.

In fact, it is our view that there should be no retrospective changes to age pensions. People who have already made the financial arrangements for their retirement in good faith should not have to cope with changes. We must stop sending the message to pensioners that no matter how carefully they invest their retirement income, we are quite likely to change the rules down the track to their disadvantage.

We in the Democrats were very much opposed to the latest assault in pensioner income, that is the assessment of unrealised gains on stock and shares for income purposes. The Senate will remember that we voted against this legislation when it came before us in December last year. Unfortunately, it passed through this chamber with the support of the opposition.

The measure then went to the Senate Community Affairs Committee and it soon became obvious that there was country-wide opposition. The Democrats collected more than 7,500 signatures on petitions which we presented in this place. As we all know now, the government was forced to back down on the retrospective element in the bill but unfortunately we were left with this unfair measure for those pensioners who bought shares after August 1992.

Now we have yet another change—this time to bring veterans legislation in line with social security legislation. The Democrats will not vote against this particular part of the bill because I can see that it does make sense that we don't send signals to veterans that they should divest themselves of their Australian shares.

As far as Allocated Pensions are concerned, this is not just a little measure to put things right as is the change in definition of shares and listed securities. This is a very big change indeed for veterans' retirement income.

The Democrats are not going to support this provision. We voted against the corresponding provision in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act when it came before the Senate in December of last year and we have not changed our minds.

When the matter of Allocated Pensions was considered by the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, my colleague, Senator Kernot, put in a dissenting report stating that the vast majority of allocated pension holders would be assessed to be receiving more income than they actually received, with a consequent reduction in pension.

The matter was referred to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and I understand that this committee is due to report in March 1994. I therefore ask why we cannot wait for the report of the committee before we do anything further to retirement incomes.

I know that the date of commencement for this provision is tied to the commencement of the corresponding provision in the Social Security legislation and will not operate retrospectively. However, if we agree to this measure now, surely we are assuming that the findings of the committee will have no impact on the government's intentions on retirement incomes, no matter what recommendations are made.

In addition, we will be loading veterans with yet more worry about their pensions now, and we could well be looking at further changes in the autumn after the committee has reported. As I said earlier, retirees have had so many changes to the treatment of their income of the last few years, it is simply not fair to present them with more changes which might not be necessary. We should wait just a few months for the committee to report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make some brief comments now and also one or two in the committee stage in the interests of moving this along as quickly as possible. The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 gives effect to one budget decision as well as three other policy amendments.

PARA.TAB: The bill extends the benefits available under the veterans' children education scheme to the children of veterans in receipt of extreme disablement adjustment. The bill also extends for a further year payment of an advanced pharmaceutical allowance to chronically ill service pensioners with a high volume of prescription drug use. This extension already applies to the Social Security Act.

The bill contains two other provisions, which of course Senator MacGibbon spoke to at length, which relate to the income and assets tests—one amending the definition of shares and listed securities, and the other relating to allocated pensions. Both mirror existing provisions in the Social Security Act and both deal with addressing potential loopholes in the existing legislation. I commend this bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.

Senator MacGibbon—The opposition will be voting against clause 4. At this stage, I indicate that clauses 4, 5, 6 and 7 in division 2, and clause 8 in division 3 would all be opposed by the opposition and they could be put cognately to save time.

Senator Faulkner—I think it would assist the committee, given that there might be a different outcome in relation to voting on these issues, that clauses 4, 5, 6 and 7 in division 2 could be taken together and that clause 8 in division 3 be taken separately.
Senator Lees—The Democrats support clauses 4, 5, 6 and 7 being taken together.
Clauses 4 to 7—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of economy of time, because I have outlined to the chamber my views on this matter, I think it would be repetitive if I spoke again on these clauses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are not prepared to support these clauses, just as we did not support them when they were put before us in social security legislation. We do not believe that we should be continuously changing the rules for pensioners once they have retired. We support what Senator MacGibbon said about the inquiry that is under way and also the Senate committee that is due to report early in the new year. We see no need for the minister to put these changes before us at this time, and we recommend that they be removed now. Perhaps they could be brought back before us once we have the findings of both those committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —In October this year the government announced an independent review of the income and assets test for service and social security pensions. The opposition wants to delay any amendment to the income and assets test until the review hands down its recommendations. Senator MacGibbon made that clear in his contribution. There may even be one or two arguments for that. However, where there is clearly an anomaly that will result in inconsistency in the treatment of social security, or where change is beneficial to pensioners, I do not believe that as a responsible government we ought to wait what could be anything up to a couple of years. That would be an extraordinary position for any government to adopt—and, I would have thought, for any opposition to adopt.

PARA.TAB: It seems likely that the results of the review will take perhaps the best part of two years to become law. The independent review will hand down its report in September next year. The government's response will be considered in the context of the 1995-96 budget and announced in the budget. The drafting of any amending bill, the passage of such a bill through the parliament and the ultimate enactment all take time. The pensioners allegedly being protected by the opposition's tactics are those pensioners who can best afford to fund their own retirement and not rely on government support.

The government is keen on not making any major changes until the review has reported, but the result of the opposition blocking these amendments will be a piecemeal and inconsistent approach to pension assessment by creating differences and maintaining anomalies.

The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No.3) 1993, which was introduced into the House of Representatives, contains a number of amendments to the income and assets test. These changes are minor in nature but are beneficial to the pensioner. I wonder how the opposition might react to those beneficial changes while awaiting the findings of a review. In the interests of moving through this quickly, that is all I plan to say at this time, but at a later stage I want to make a couple of comments about what would be the impact of the opposition's position on this bill.
Question put:
That clauses 4 to 7 be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Clause 8.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be opposing clause 8 in division 3.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will not be agreeing with the opposition in this case. This in fact is a loophole. The last thing we want to do is to see people moving their shares offshore. I understand this measure would affect very few veterans. Nevertheless, we do not need to put any further problems in the way of what is already a very difficult and, as we have discussed in this chamber at length, an unnecessary provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —The minor amendment to the definition of shares and other listed securities ensures that the income and assets tests apply to both foreign sourced investments and Australian ones. The measure does not directly relate to matters recently debated in the public arena and in the parliament. It corrects an anomaly and addresses concerns that the current definition would adversely affect the Australian investment industry by encouraging pensioners to divest themselves of their Australian shareholdings in preference to overseas ones.

PARA.TAB: These concerns in fact were raised by Senator MacGibbon during his second reading speech for the private member's bill he introduced on 10 May this year dealing with the treatment of shares and listed securities. He indicated at that time that he was concerned about the movements of investors offshore.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got a quote?
—I have got a quote. He actually said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a strong argument that this proposal could have the effect of moving many small investors offshore. The Australian Stock Exchange has pointed out that unrealised capital gains on investments on overseas stock exchanges would not be subject to the veterans' affairs income test. The Australian Stock Exchange has made considerable headway recently in attracting small investors into the local share market. This proposal has the potential to discourage small scale investment in Australian companies at a time when such investment is desperately needed.

So I do think there is an element of hypocrisy in the approach that is being taken by the opposition. As soon as the government tries to amend the act to ensure that this anomaly does not occur and to ensure that the treatment of shares and listed securities is consistent with provisions of the Social Security Act, the opposition does what it probably does best of all—opposes it. I think reasoning and fairness and consistency in treatment and consistency in argument has been forgotten on this matter. I support this clause of the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can remember talking to one of my colleagues many years ago and I asked, `What sort of an organisation is such-and-such university?' and he said, `It all depends on who the dean is'. He said that leaders set the style and the pattern for an organisation. In the case of the government which has a leader like Mr Keating, who is totally irrational and who is governed by his emotions—never by reason—I suppose one could expect the sort of statement that we have just heard from Senator Faulkner.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Faulkner had been endowed with the usual auditory apparatus and the cerebral links to interpret what he had heard, he would have realised that I had made it specifically clear that I was not defending investments in overseas exchanges. I was using the argument that we, on this side of the chamber, have had enough of the constant change, the insecurity, and the emotional trauma that comes from this government changing the legislation so that elderly Australians have their retirement income packages attacked constantly, month after month.

The opposition opposes the clause on overseas investment on the basis that, until the government thinks through of what ground rules it wants for retirement income policies for Australians, we are not prepared to countenance any further mindless change—particularly of an ad hoc nature. My personal view, and the view of my colleagues, is that we would prefer all Australians to invest their money in Australia. We certainly do not encourage anyone to invest overseas. We believe that the interests of all Australians are served by putting money here. I counsel the minister very carefully to try to listen and to try to understand what we, on this side of the chamber, are saying, because we do think about what we are saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —The impact of the amendment which was carried in the committee stage—and of this subsequent amendment, if carried—will be that this bill will not be accepted by the House of Representatives in its amended form. The failure to pass this bill—this is what Senator MacGibbon will be responsible for—will mean that the proposal to extend the VCES benefits to children of EDA veterans will not proceed. The sunset clause controlling the operation of advanced pharmaceutical allowance will come into effect and will repeal this provision.

PARA.TAB: This calendar year approximately 250 advance pharmaceutical payments were made. If this bill does not pass the Senate this week, no further payments of advance pharmaceutical allowance can be made after 1 January 1994.

The Department of Social Security has similar advance pharmaceutical allowance payments. The sunset clause for the social security payments has been extended. Therefore, a failure to pass the extension of this sunset clause in this bill will again result in inconsistencies between the two departments. In relation to VCES benefits to children of veterans who are severely disabled—those with the most extreme disabilities—this will mean that an estimated 32 grants of benefits under the scheme will not proceed. I must say to Senator MacGibbon and the opposition that I am afraid the opposition will be responsible for that. Fatuous, false and hypocritical arguments have been put forward in support of the amendments moved in the committee stage of this bill.

Finally, the coalition will, of course, support the advance pharmaceutical allowance issue—it will let that one go through to the keeper. But the impact will be that it will not go ahead because amendments to other parts of the bill will not be accepted in the House of Representatives. A service pensioner can only access the advance payment if he or she has ordinary income of less than $20 a fortnight. A failure to pass that part of the bill—which will be the impact of what we are talking about here—will affect service pensioners who can least afford to pay for the prescription co-payment from their pensions. That is something for which the opposition will stand condemned.

I do not intend to say any more on this bill. The issues have been canvassed and they are clear. I believe the position that the opposition has adopted in this is unprincipled, unfair, unreasonable and brings a great deal of discredit upon it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that Senator Faulkner has not been a minister for very long and he has not been in the Senate for terribly long. My advice to him—
—We have been in government a long time.
—He will not be in government much longer. As soon as those opposite go to the polls, it will be bye, bye.
—You said that last time.

—But I will be right next time. Senator Faulkner has to realise that in politics one does not win everything; one actually loses many things and one has to be a good loser. What we have seen tonight on the floor of the committee is really a very bad loser.

PARA.TAB: The argument that Senator Faulkner put forward simply will not stand up in political terms. If he feels that there are now anomalies in relation to the treatment of veterans, it is within his power to introduce a bill to correct those anomalies; nothing could be simpler. The fact that there is now a disjunction for the first time between Social Security's legislation and the Department of Veterans' Affairs legislation is similarly amenable by legislative action.

If Senator Faulkner had the wit, the will and the concern, in respect of which he has been crying crocodile tears in this chamber tonight, he could move to amend the social security legislation to make it parallel with what we have resolved tonight. If he were genuinely concerned about the veterans of this country, he could introduce a new bill which would overcome the anomalies which he pretends to be distressed about.

So let us not fill this chamber with humbug. Let us get down to the heart of the matter. It is because the government has not run a decent legislative program that the minister is in the mess he is in tonight.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL TRAINING AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 21 and 26 October, on motions by Senator Faulkner and Senator Schacht:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this late stage of the budget sittings of the Senate, six education bills are listed for debate and will be dealt with within the next few hours. We have before us at the moment two of those bills—namely, the Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill 1993.

PARA.TAB: My colleagues on both sides have encouraged me to limit my remarks to a few minutes and to address specifically in the committee stage those amendments which I have every expectation will be successful. Despite admirable speeches by my colleagues in the House of Representatives, where there is an iron majority for the government of the day, the government always wins in that place. However, with education bills it is possible for a coalition spokesman, a Democrat spokesman and occasionally a spokesman from one of the other minorities in the Senate to come together and pass amendments that make sensible improvements for the benefit of Australians.

The opposition expresses support for these two bills but it will propose one significant amendment. The bills provide funding for technical and further education programs—these days, they are more often called vocational education or adult education programs. These programs bring real benefits to hundreds of thousands of Australians.

I am delighted that my close colleague, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), is in the gallery. He has spoken on technical and further education—vocational education—in the House of Representatives and other places around the country. He has done so with discernment and careful preparation. I look forward throughout this parliament to our working together to put pressure upon this government, where we can be convincing, to see improvements made for the benefit of Australians. As I have said in earlier speeches, frankly, the only remedy will be a change of government. That is what is needed to see a real improvement in technical and further education, and higher education in schools.

The Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill transfers certain national programs from the Commonwealth to the Australian National Training Authority—ANTA—which has its secretariat in Brisbane and which will operate fully from the first day of next month. It has been 18 months in preparation.

My views and the opposition's views were expressed at the time of ANTA's establishment. Despite our scepticism and our not being fully convinced by the centralising arguments of the Labor Party to take over some of the responsibilities and initiatives of the states, we saw merit in support for the ANTA initiative. We will continue to monitor ANTA to ensure that it is not just another layer of bureaucracy which soaks up taxpayers' money but that it will, month by month, lead to outcomes in every state of Australia that are of benefit to the technical and further education of Australians.

The ANTA bill corrects a minor drafting problem contained in the original act. This is more evidence—we see it all the time these days—of the sloppiness of the Labor Party in preparing its legislation.

The Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill provides supplementation funding for the TAFE sector in the 1993-95 triennium in accordance with movements in price indices. This is quite routine legislation and we support these elements of that legislation. From 1 January funding for TAFE moves to a rolling triennium. It is a situation which I and the opposition welcome. It is a positive strength to planning for this sector of education in Australia.

There is one particular aspect of this legislation that the opposition will oppose and I will be moving amendments to it in the committee stage. At the last minute an amendment was moved by Minister Beazley in the House of Representatives debate which arrogated unilaterally—without consultation with the States—a power to the Commonwealth minister to veto funding to the states. This unilateral veto of the Commonwealth, without consultation with the states, took the states, ANTA and certainly this parliament by surprise. The numbers in the House of Representatives ensured that the amendment got through. Here in the Senate we will try to remove the provision which would give the minister the power under this ANTA legislation to veto any funding for technical and further education.

In the committee stage I will refer to letters I received from the Western Australian Minister for Education, Mr Moore, the Tasmanian Minister for Education and the Arts, Mr Beswick, the Victorian Minister for Tertiary Education and Training, Mr Storey, and the New South Wales Minister for Education, Mrs Chikarovski. I will incorporate the letters received from those ministers, setting out their dismay at this Labor government's taking the states by surprise. I believe the government has broken the original agreement between the Commonwealth and the states which was very finely balanced to allow ministerial council supervision of ANTA and of all the funding mechanisms with regard to vocational education.

The time allowed to me by my colleagues has elapsed. I will conclude by again commending my colleague the honourable member for Menzies who, in a longer speech in the House of Representatives, was able to set out more positively the constructive ideas of the Liberal and National parties with regard to this area of education. In great contrast to the present government's inadequate management of these matters, we want to initiate a fresh approach which will see much improved outcomes for Australians in technical and further education. I will have much more to say in the committee stage of the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have copious notes which I will seek to incorporate in Hansard. They successfully convey the Democrats' position with regard to the Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2). The description of the bill given by Senator Teague is perfectly accurate and can be supported. I foreshadow that we will be moving a small amendment to the Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill which would insert a requirement that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training consult and have regard to the advice provided by the authority. Having said that, I have virtually outlined our opposition to the bill. I could spend time qualifying it but I think it would be wiser to seek leave to incorporate my notes in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —That being the case, I think it is appropriate that I make sure that Hansard records an accurate explanation of the Democrats' attitude to this bill. The Australian Democrats have long supported the development of a uniform and disciplined national training sector in this country. The announcement of the establishment of the Australian National Training Authority in July 1992 was a welcome move. It formalised a coordinated and national approach to training for both TAFEs and private providers in Australia.

PARA.TAB: ANTA forms an important part of the new national training system, along with the ministerial council and a network of training authorities. It symbolises the strengthening of links with business and industry in the provision of training in Australia and a more effective training market and improved cross sectoral links.

As part of the government's training reform agenda a number of reports have been published about the role of education and training in this country. While we have seen a dramatic increase in secondary school retention rates as a result of recommendations contained in the Finn report of 1991, which established new targets for young people's participation in post-compulsory education and training, and there has been a consequent rise in further education aspirations amongst young Australians, the government has failed to provide the necessary expansion in education and training places. That has been a matter of some criticism.

Certainly over the last two years we have seen an unprecedented increase in the levels of unmet demand—that is the way it has been described—for further education. Certainly the Democrats have repeatedly warned against the simple expansion of this sector as a means of alleviating the effects of overcrowding and trying to diminish the dole queues.

The Carmichael report was introduced in July 1992 to respond to issues in the Finn report. It outlined a competency based approach to training in Australia. It envisaged a simple structure of vocational training that promoted and enabled progression from one level to another in all industries. In some ways the proposal to provide what was termed `articulation' is something which should be supported.

The Democrats see a strengthened role for industry in the provision and assistance with training in Australia. But we do not see this as an opportunity or an excuse for the government to reduce its role in education and training provisions. We believe that education and training has to be part of a well coordinated, strategic plan designed to cope with the needs of the changing work force. That is a consequence of technological restructuring that has been brought about by other changes in the workplace. Part of the charter of that whole system should be to give all Australians, regardless of their background, access to institutions of learning.

The government still needs to comprehensively consider the complex issue of growth in education and training. It is with concern that I read of Minister Beazley's statements regarding growth in universities. That has been discussed in another forum.

The Democrats, along with groups such as the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Higher Education Round Table, believe that a higher level of growth is sustainable and we support moves for increased funds for the provision of those places. It is a sad and shameful fact that student funding in our universities has decreased below 1983 levels under 10 years of federal Labor rule.

We look forward to the creation of a diverse and flexible education and training system which will lead us into the 21st century. We do see ANTA playing an integral role in identifying Australia's training needs for the present and well into the future. But integral to this is a cooperative and workable relationship between the states and the Commonwealth, and the Democrats encourage this cooperation. We have examined claims by this coalition that proposed section 14A threatens to breach that harmony.

We certainly do not support bullying tactics by the Commonwealth government. In fact, former Senator Sowada, in addressing the Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill in 1992, expressed our concerns about some of the tactics then being used by the Commonwealth in the debate over whose funding and whose administrative responsibility the training sector was in this country.

To be specific, with regard to the concerns expressed by the coalition and various state education ministers about proposed section 14A of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill, we find that this proposed section gives the minister the ability to withhold funds intended for the states and territories if, in the minister's opinion, the state has failed to comply with the statement.

This amendment was introduced belatedly by the government in the House of Representatives. Examination of the coalition's legal and financial concerns about this clause reveals that the consequences that it feared—namely, that all states and territories could be affected by the failure of one state or territory to comply with the statement—are not valid. According to the New South Wales Minister for Industrial Relations and Employment, the Hon. Kerry Chikarovski, the implications are both significant and would penalise the states unnecessarily.

Although the minister has the discretion to withdraw the Commonwealth funding in respect of one state or territory if that state or territory fails to comply with the statement as outlined in the schedule of the act, this relates specifically to Commonwealth sourced funds. This is specified in the act where VET funding is defined by the act as Commonwealth sourced funds.The Democrats fully support a set of guiding principles to which the states are subjected to ensure a uniform and coordinated national training system—that is what it is all about—especially as it involves allocation of state and federal funds.

To alleviate the concerns of state ministers and to facilitate consultation between the minister and ANTA, which should take place anyway, we propose to change the clause and to insert at the appropriate place, as indicated by the amendment which we will be moving in the committee stage, that the minister, in forming his or her opinion, is to take account of, but is not bound by, any advice provided by the authority. We support the continued expansion and strengthening of our vocational education and training system and believe that by supporting this bill that will be achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill provides a mechanism for the transfer of responsibility of national programs from the Commonwealth to ANTA. It also allows the minister to direct ANTA not to allocate certain funding to a particular state or territory. The coalition does have some very deep concerns about this particular measure.

PARA.TAB: It is a great pity that this government is doing that at this time because I believe ANTA is a symbol of what can happen in a successful federal system of government. We have shown with the creation of ANTA the sort of flexibility that is needed in the system when we are faced with an intractable problem of a lack of funding for a particular area of education. We had a situation where the authority originally was totally with the states and the funding was largely provided federally. An insufficient amount was getting through to TAFE in the blocked grants that were given.

With the creation of ANTA, we have seen a situation where the ministerial council, with all the ministers relating to the TAFE sector, can sit down with an agreement of a federal pool of money and work out the allocation of growth money to this sector. Unfortunately, what this bill does is put this whole cooperative arrangement under threat and does betray what a very carefully worked out agreement between the state and federal level originally provided.

The Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill will amend the Australian National Training Authority Act 1992 by inserting proposed new section 14A. It will allow the minister to direct ANTA not to allocate funding to a particular state or territory. The opposition has serious problems with this proposal as it undermines the original agreement and erodes the authority—and I think this is probably the most serious aspect—of the ministerial council, which was set up under the agreement as the ultimate authority governing ANTA. It was established after long negotiation and with specific purposes for the allocation of vocational money and training so that a national approach could be taken in line with what was advocated in the highly acclaimed Finn report.

The federal government and the state governments came into line on this report. ANTA was the result and now the agreement is under threat. The whole arrangement was to create an additional pool of money, which comes to $100 million in recurrent funding. For 1994 and 1995, 80 per cent of this cumulative growth fund, which equals $112 million and $168 million respectively, is to be allocated according to population share, with the balance allocated by the ministerial council. Unfortunately, because of this amendment, all these agreements on funding are now threatened. We believe that the possibility of any state or territory not complying with the ANTA agreement has been adequately dealt with in the original act. Thus it is clear that ANTA was established under the full cooperation of these various government bodies and, unfortunately, the goodwill is now being threatened.

At the heads of government meeting in 1992 it was agreed that if the states were found to be not in compliance with the ANTA agreement then it would be up to the ministerial council to take action. It was also agreed that any action by the ministerial council would apply only to that part of the ANTA fund pool which was represented by Commonwealth growth money. However, because of these amendments, the whole of the money allocated by the states is being put under threat. This, I believe, in a cooperative federal arrangement is intolerable.

The minister has stated that the purpose of his amendments is to ensure compliance by the states. However, ANTA has already stated that it is quite happy with compliance by the states and territories under the current agreement. As we find in so many other areas of education, as we have discovered with ESOS and as we have discovered with higher education funding, the government is using a sledgehammer to crack a tiny problem. Again, it has overreacted.

This bill, as amended, gives the minister far too wide powers of discretion. It does not indicate in any way in what respect the states or territories may be deemed to have not complied with the ANTA agreement. It is also of great concern that the minister may need only to have an opinion that there has been non-compliance before he or she issues a directive to disallow funding. This is an extraordinary power. It is completely unnecessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no criteria set out.

—Yes. We are going to be dealing with ESOS later on. That is another loose piece of legislation that has absolutely no indication of principles or the way in which something is to be developed. We will leave it all to regulation later. As Senator Teague quite correctly points out, this is another sloppy piece of legislation. The dangerous side effect of that sloppiness is that it gives the minister extraordinary powers of discretion, which is very dangerous. He would be better acting under the advice of his ministerial council and taking the advice from the states. But this is not necessarily the way in which this bill is being revised at the moment.

PARA.TAB: It would appear that, in bringing about such revisions and amendments to the bill in the lower house, there was very little consultation undertaken with the various states or with ANTA before the government decided to go down this path. In all, this particular aspect of what is otherwise a reasonable piece of legislation is an enormous over-reaction. The coalition recognises the importance of vocational education and training. That is why we have supported ANTA and support most of the amendments in this bill. However, it is impossible to support amendments as draconian and as unnecessary as the 14A proposal, which holds a gun to the head of the states.
