As Mr Beazley explained in his letter of 1 December, it is quite clear that the new provision which would be inserted by the Bill in the Australian National Training Authority Act 1992 (ANTA Act) would enable the Commonwealth Minister to direct ANTA to withhold from a particular State Commonwealth-sourced funds only. The new provision refers to `VET funding', which is defined already in subsection 4(1) of the ANTA Act as `money paid to the Authority under Part 3 of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992'.

Although both Commonwealth- and State-sourced funds are in a sense `pooled' and become ANTA's money under the ANTA Act, the Act already requires (in section 14) reference back to the source of the funds when ANTA allocates the total pool. The new provision does not alter that arrangement.
By referring only to `VET funding' (ie, Commonwealth-sourced funds), the new provision would not enable the Minister to direct ANTA to withhold State-sourced funds.

The new provision would not affect adversely any State which was not the subject of a withholding direction' issued by the Minister to ANTA. Such a direction would have the effect of prohibiting ANTA from paying funds to a specified State in contravention of the direction but it would not reduce the allocation and payment of funds to other States, which remains under the control of the Ministerial Council.

It is possible for the Minister to revoke a withholding direction at any time, including if a State's breach of the ANTA agreement were remedied and, therefore, the funds could flow ultimately to that State. Alternatively, if the funds were to be withheld permanently, the Minister could exercise his existing power under subsection 9(1) of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992 to determine that the amount to be paid to ANTA from the total of the funds appropriated should be reduced by the withheld amount. If the Minister did not reduce the amount to be paid to ANTA, then the funds withheld from one or more States could be available to increase the allocation among the remaining States.
As I am satisfied that the bill would not result in the problems which you have outlined, it will proceed in its current form.
Yours sincerely
Ross Free
7 December 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to note in broad, because of the pressure of time, that all of these letters from state ministers express their surprise, their dismay, at the action of the Commonwealth government in this amendment. They urge the Senate in this debate to remedy the situation. To be fair to those state ministers, some say that this clause should be completely removed; others that it be at least confined to the Commonwealth minister only having the power to block Commonwealth funds. There is also a leftover reference in one of the minister's letters to the fear, the anxiety, that the blocking of any money will have an effect upon the pool of all moneys to block the lot.

PARA.TAB: I put it to the Senate that the state ministers for education are broadly in support—some highly specifically in support—of the amendment that I am now moving on behalf of the opposition. I do not wish to spend a great deal of time going over the letters, but I certainly thank our state colleagues for their advice in this matter. I wish to refer to the response to Minister Chikarovski by the Commonwealth Minister Beazley when he gives this assurance—and if this amendment fails, at least we will hold him to this assurance—

SPEECH.PARA: These funds are the Commonwealth's contribution to the ANTA funding pool for allocation among the states, that is, base and growth funds. The new provision would enable the Commonwealth minister to withhold any proportion of the funds provided by the Commonwealth, potentially including base funds as set out in my earlier letter. The amount of funds which might be withheld would be decided in the light of the seriousness of the states' breach of the agreement.

I still regard this whole power of the Commonwealth minister as an arrogance, and I reject it all. But the minister is saying that it is confined to the Commonwealth portion of the money. Again, in the second paragraph:
. . . that is, as Commonwealth sourced funds only.
Minister Free, in his letter to Minister Chikarovski of 7 December, makes a similar statement in the fourth paragraph of his letter. He states that this change to the ANTA Act:
. . . would enable the Commonwealth minister to direct ANTA to withhold from a particular state Commonwealth sourced funds only.
Later on in that letter he actually gives the assurance. This is an assurance that I do not fully believe but it is based upon how lawyers will interpret the act and the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—I am being as genuine as I can. Minister Free gives the assurance that it is in his mind as minister that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it would not reduce the allocation and payment of funds to other States.

In so far as any legal advice may arise that contradicts these two assertions—limitation to Commonwealth money only; no effect upon the other states if there is an action with regard to one state—then it will prevent the Commonwealth minister from acting at all. I take these as self-binding upon the ministers of the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: I will listen carefully to our colleague Senator Bell. I understand that he will be moving an alternative amendment, should this amendment fail. Senator Bell's amendment will put a set of words around the power placed by this bill in the Commonwealth minister that go a long way towards the concerns that I referred to during the second reading debate and just now. I believe the best way is to see the whole of the power removed. I am appealing across the chamber to the independent senators—the Greens and Senator Harradine. Should they be persuaded by my arguments, we would be able to see this amendment established. I foreshadow that if there are not the numbers for my amendment on behalf of the opposition, we would support the Democrats' amendment which goes three-quarters of the way towards the position I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadowed the Australian Democrats' response to the proposed amendment, which has now been moved by Senator Teague, during my second reading contribution. We have inquired into the effects which were alleged to be likely to occur by letters from the Hon. Kerry Chikarovski, the New South Wales Minister for Education and the Hon. Norman Moore, the Western Australian minister. It is our contention that those alleged effects are not accurately based.

PARA.TAB: Although we agree that the late inclusion of the amendment in the lower house provided a flurry which really should not have occurred and provided reason to question what is going on, we believe that we have a proposition which would satisfactorily encompass the powers of the minister. To some extent, it rightly hinges on the question of how the minister shall form an opinion. There is always some conjecture as to how ministers of the crown form an opinion, but in this case we offer a little guidance that that opinion should be formed in consultation with the authority. For the reason that we have put some work in and found out just what the consequences will be, we will not be supporting the coalition's amendment but foreshadow an amendment to have another effect.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept the amendment proposed by Senator Teague. First of all, it is to be made clear that this Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2) is designed to put ANTA on a firm footing and to encourage the states to fulfil their obligations with regard to training. The provision in the legislation is a precautionary measure and I can tell Senator Teague that it applies only in respect of 1994 and 1995.

PARA.TAB: I listened to Senator Teague's concern in the face of assurances by the two relevant Commonwealth ministers, which he seemed to suggest he accepts. I am pleased to hear that because there was, for a minute, an implication that despite the assurances of the ministers Senator Teague did not take them at their word. The ministers have given that assurance. That is also spelt out in the explanatory memorandum. The minister has reiterated this in response to an opposition question in the other place. Senator Teague has already given us the benefit of the ministers' assurances in writing in correspondence with the New South Wales minister. There is no substance to the concern that Senator Teague has raised, particularly in the face of those assurances.

Senator Bell wonders how the minister might form an opinion. As I understand it, these arrangements were agreed by the states in July 1992 and only one state to this point has introduced complementary legislation. Certainly the failure to introduce complementary legislation would seem to me to be an indication that might assist the minister in forming an opinion. In the light of the assurances given by the minister on a number of occasions, there is absolutely no substance to the opposition's fears in this matter. The government will not be supporting this amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1993HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition, while not opposing the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1993 and the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 overall, does have difficulties with some defined parts which I will outline now and I will also put amendments at the committee stage to both bills.

PARA.TAB: As we know, the legislation provides schools funding on a rolling triennium basis. We do not oppose this provision. It assists many hundreds of thousands of primary and secondary students throughout Australia. We welcome further funding for students at risk and also for the pilot program for transitional support for students with disabilities. Also in this legislation we welcome funding for hostels for rural students. But it seems that boarding schools will not receive any of the money, and I put the first of some six or seven precise questions to the minister and ask that he might address them in his response.

TALK.START.PARA: —You never know your luck in a big city.

—I thank Senator Schacht. The first question is: why will boarding schools not receive some of this money? Of course, we do not want to deny rural hostels. Can the minister explain why boarding schools seem to be excluded from this new initiative?
—Do you mean all boarding schools or country boarding schools?

—All boarding schools. Parents have raised concerns about the structure of special education funding arising in this legislation and whether the three sector funding in part 6 will prove too cumbersome and lack flexibility in meeting the needs of disabled children. I also understand that funding for non-school organisations is being quarantined for the year 1994 pending further evaluation. So my second question is: would the minister please confirm this, or otherwise, and explain how this quarantining is being done and how the evaluation will occur during 1994 for the non-school organisations eventually to be included under this provision?

PARA.TAB: We have always strongly opposed Labor's new schools policy. It is, of course, best understood as an anti-new schools policy. Ever since Senator Ryan, the Labor government has put every barrier it can construct in the way of new independent schools in this country. In great contrast, the Liberal and National parties wish to give freedom of choice to parents and communities to build new independent schools.

Clauses 3 to 13 of this bill add to the obstacles already in place from several ministers of education in this Labor government. There is a lengthening of the required period of notice from two to three years of certain proposed changes at a non-government school. We will oppose these clauses as we would seek to oppose any of these quite unjustified barriers being placed in the way of new non-government schools.

I refer to an amendment to clause 15 that we will move in the committee stage. It addresses an excessive rigidity in the way in which this bill would require the counting of enrolled students attending a school on a daily basis. This rigidity seems to overlook absences from attendance at school simply on the grounds of sickness or attendance at a school excursion. We would not wish such a harsh provision to reduce funding for any school that has a genuine entitlement based upon what anyone would sensibly see as the genuine enrolment at that school.

I turn to the funding for the national equity program. This bill seeks to broadband the categories that have existed for a number of years. I commend the Commonwealth, especially when we were in government 10 to 17 years ago—my first five years in the Senate were in a Liberal and National Party government. The initiatives that were taken under the Fraser government and the Hawke and Keating governments to initiate programs in the schools area have been a real asset to children in city and country areas. I see from this what is broadly understood by all of us to have been the eventual broadbanding of a number of these programs so that the states, with flexibility, can use the wider pool of moneys and judge more locally the way in which those moneys are apportioned.

However, this seems to impose new requirements for reporting by the states in such detail that it will be extraordinarily burdensome, and I do not think fully justified. This will lead to difficulties in accountability for the use of Commonwealth money. My third question is: what is the status of negotiations with the states with regard to the numerous agreements required by this bill between the Commonwealth and the states? Are they concluded? Are there difficulties? Has there been any area of difficulty or disagreement?

My fourth question is: is it correct that the Commonwealth is seeking to make the states so accountable to the Commonwealth that they actually have to account for their own money, their own programs—that the states' own funding will need to be reported to the Commonwealth?

One part of this refinement of national equity programs will be to lead an opposition amendment, and that concerns the very successful country areas program—I would like it to have been even more successful with more resources. It is of enormous concern to rural communities out in the bush, where the country areas program is of enormous value to Australia's children living in isolated towns and families throughout the countryside.

The opposition is of the view that the merger proposed in this legislation of the disadvantaged schools program and the country areas program into one pool may put in jeopardy the quantum of moneys that is to be spent on the country areas program. A quarter of the money is currently spent on the country areas program and three-quarters on the disadvantaged schools program. Accordingly, we will move amendments at the committee stage to preserve the country areas program.

Because my colleagues wish this debate to proceed as quickly as possible, I do not have time to instance rural communities all over Australia, in all states, that have a total commitment to ensuring that there is no diminution of resources for the country areas program.

I now move to the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill. This, in the usual way, provides funding for 1996 and extra funding for preceding years in this rolling triennium. This bill does have the opposition's support, but particular aspects deserve comment and criticism. The main area is the new provisions with regard to the higher education contribution scheme.

The government in the budget sought to introduce for the first time a rate of payment by students in our universities at 1 1/2 times the normal rate if they did not make progress through their course at a speed that suited the Labor Party in government. Of course, this led to many of us expressing dismay at how this would operate and to the deleterious effects this would have on many students. I recognise and support the government's withdrawal of this proposal which occurred as a result of the pressure that has been put on it since the budget. An amendment was introduced in the House of Representatives with the effect that students who, according to Ministers Beazley and Free, go too slowly through their courses no longer face the prospect of paying HECS at 1 1/2 times the normal rate.

The one matter that does remain in the bill before us is the imposition of double HECS—that is, twice the rate of the higher education contribution scheme. The Labor government's proposal is that this apply to those undertaking second degrees. First of all, the opposition is quite appalled that this is being applied retrospectively. It will not apply only to those enrolling for a second degree for the first time from January 1994. It is imposed retrospectively on many students who are already involved in second degree courses. There has not been a proper assessment of the impact this will have upon women, upon disabled students or upon students who have gained their first degrees overseas, some of them refugees, whose qualifications are not accepted in Australia. Also, some amalgamations of universities will lead to its being very hard to define whether someone has a first degree or not and there will be all sorts of inequity because some will fall on this side of the line and some on the other.

Then there is the very important matter that for years, indeed decades, there have been some approved combined degrees, for instance for Austudy purposes. These approved combined degrees include, for example, law/economics and medicine/science and a wide range of combined degrees. In all these months the opposition was not assured by the Labor government or by any clear statement of Labor ministers that even these worthy combined degrees were sacrosanct from this double HECS. Accordingly, the opposition moved in the Senate that this matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. In due course my colleague Senator Tierney will refer to the Senate committee's consideration.

As a result of the Senate committee's findings, which were basically that this proposal had inequities that were contradictory to the government's intentions for this measure, and as a result of all the matters I have already referred to, the opposition has resolved to oppose the whole measure completely. We will move an amendment in the committee stage that will completely abolish the double rate of higher education contribution scheme with regard to any student in Australia.

The major reason that the opposition has arrived at this position, quite apart from the half a dozen matters that I have already referred to, is that we in Australia need to make sure that we have graduates who are not just specialists but who have a combination of skills at a high level which in each profession will serve this country very well.

There are also in this bill—I am sure the Democrats will refer to it more than I am able to—increases in the repayment levels for contributions to repay the higher education contribution scheme debt when a graduate is employed and earning an income. The opposition has given very careful consideration to this matter and has consulted many of those affected, but we recognise that there is an elected government and that this is integrally connected with the budget as a whole. Therefore, consistent with our position over many years, although we would not have proposed this ourselves and our policy will come forth nearer to the coming election, we will allow the government's proposals on this matter.

Let me make it clear that the students of Australia have been cheated and deceived by a Labor government that did not disclose this measure before the last election. Those opposite were the ones who said, `Beware a Liberal government', even though we were promising in the election $3 billion more of resources for education. The Labor government stayed silent about this matter and has laid more penalty upon the students of Australia. We will remind the students of Australia of the cheating and deception, indeed the lies, of the Labor government with regard to support for students. The responsibility for this measure lies with the Labor government, and the students of Australia must understand that.

I have only a few minutes to refer to open learning. This bill extends HECS to open learning and we support that measure. We see that it is not fully extended to those whom I would call `part time' in open learning. I expect an amendment will be moved by another senator to extend it more fully from the opposition's point of view, but we will ask the government to keep this matter under review. If there is a change on the grounds of equity, on the grounds of the outcome being to the benefit of Australia, then we would wish the government to put arguments for an extension of open learning-HECS availability even to part-time students. It is not a matter of policy for us. We are just saying that we wish to monitor it. I have a fifth question: what is the government's intention with regard to the part-time enrolments in open learning with regard to access to HECS?

I come to the government's measures in this legislation with regard to research funding. We are not convinced about what the government is doing here—neither are universities; neither is the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. There is a great deal of dismay about what the Labor Party is doing with regard to research funding. Again, we will observe this matter as an opposition and be fully open to hear the views of our universities on this matter, postgraduate degrees and course work as undertaken by postgraduate students. We think the present proposals are unfortunate but, by virtue of the fact that this is an elected government which has a budget to maintain, we will allow the government's measure.

Sixthly, will the minister explain why in the short term the number of postgraduate awards will decrease from 23,730 to 20,700 before in the middle term it rises again? Finally, funding is provided to facilitate workplace bargaining and higher education. Will the minister please indicate the present state of progress with the national framework agreement for agency bargaining referred to in the second reading speech? I ask for the last three paragraphs of my speech to be incorporated in Hansard, as my time has nearly elapsed.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Generally: Let me repeat the opposition's overall rejection of the government's interventionist/centralising approach. The opposition rejects this.

This bill in context of minister persisting with highly interventionist policy for which Dawkins noted. Recent example of more intervention and manipulation in higher education to come with Beazley's speech on 15 November at University of Melbourne. Immediate adverse reaction from Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. In Australian of 17 November "The Executive Director of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, Mr Frank Hambly said that the federal government was moving towards a more regulated tertiary system, with serious consequences for universities that could not meet government criteria."

Again in Australian of 24 November, "The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee has criticised the federal government's higher education funding policy as incoherent and renewed its call for a user-pays system to help mop up unmet demand."

Finally I make brief mention of Auditor-General's report tabled on November 25 entitled "Growth, Change and Equity—Recurrent Funding of Higher Education". On page xi we are informed, after a summary of the key points of the report, that the department's response was "The report was generally rejected by the Department". I regard this response as an appalling arrogance and urge the minister and the department to give substantial responses based on careful facts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a complicated cognation of bills because several issues are being dealt with and it is hard to find a relationship between them which justifies the cognation.
—There isn't any.

—I agree with Senator Tierney. The Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill amends what is called the HEFA act to provide $4.6 million-plus for higher education funding and introduces budget measures that include HECS hikes, increased HECS repayment rates, further deregulation of the postgraduate sector and a deferred payment system for the open learning initiative. As foreshadowed before the budget, during the budget and after the budget, the Australian Democrats will be opposing the changes that entrench the user pays principles for higher education.

PARA.TAB: I foreshadow amendments that are designed to soften the budget blow. The 1993-94 budget will be remembered as a punitive and brain-draining budget. It introduced some of the harshest measures for students in the area of fees and charges, as well as penalties for slow progress. It hit hard at students, imposing crippling debt levels and education penalties, and it symbolises further entrenchment of the user pays principles in higher education. That is a trend that is becoming a feature of our secondary school system as well. I think that ought to be recognised. It is being recognised by the media, but it has been insufficiently recognised in this place. I intend to do something about that the next time this parliament sits.

The most disturbing aspect of these changes is the decision to impose double HECS for second degrees. It is amusing to me that the acronym HECS is reminiscent of a medieval witch's curse—and there is nothing worse than a double curse. The rationale behind this move is apparently to free up undergraduate places for school leavers and other first timers in the system. I suggest that that is an excuse rather than a rationale. It does not bear scrutiny. It is blatantly a money-grabbing exercise.

Since the announcement on budget night, the Democrats have been opposed to double HECS for second degrees. It was with great relief that we welcomed the final announcement during this week that the coalition will adopt a similar position. We had heard hints of that. We were rather incredulous at first, but we now congratulate members of the coalition for staying firm and for convincing their shadow cabinet that such a move was justified. That is not a hollow congratulation. I know that, in particular, senators with a particular interest in and knowledge of education have persisted to convince their shadow cabinet. The double HECS should never have been accepted because it is a double whammy for students seeking to upgrade their skills and their knowledge and for those, such as teachers, who have to continually upgrade their professional skills to keep pace with an ever-changing career environment.

At the Senate standing committee hearing on this issue, the Department of Education, Employment and Training officials admitted that this measure was a deterrent—for goodness sake, fancy calling it that; fancy admitting that—for students who had already accessed the system to deter them from further participating in it. This smacks of the attitude that somehow these people are privileged. This is despite a purported commitment to access and equity. People are only allowed to access it once, regardless of talent, regardless of merit and regardless of benefit to the wider community. This is a cherry to be tasted just once.

This proposal is not only a psychological but also a blatant financial disincentive to study that will discriminate against the disabled, against women, against Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and against other traditionally disadvantaged groups. It will also disadvantage people who have come from overseas to add to Australia's pool of talent and ability. The Democrats will be opposing clauses 12 and 13, which refer to double HECS for second degrees.

The other punitive budget proposal which has since been defeated—as a result of combined criticism from the Democrats, students and, eventually, opposition, as well as round criticism—was the introduction of the minimum time rule, in which students were required to complete their degree in a certain time or else incur a 50 per cent increased penalty in their HECS debt for each additional unit they studied.

The National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling produced figures which demonstrated that women are already five times less likely than men to repay their HECS debt by the age of 30, yet the government introduced a set of measures which discriminates against women, particularly mature age women returning to study, who often experience interrupted periods of study as a result of employment commitments which may be particular to their age group and their other commitments, whether they be family or others. The research highlighted the debt burden that many women face well into their forties and fifties—a lifetime of debt for a group that suffered in education until the removal of tertiary fees in the 1970s.

I note that in the other place Mr Snowdon claimed in his speech in the second reading debate that the budget measures will reduce Commonwealth government outlays to higher education and, hence, the public sector financial burden. It is extraordinary that the provision of public education at all levels—primary, secondary and tertiary—should be considered a burden as opposed to an inalienable right for all Australians. If it is reflective of the government attitude that a member of the House of Representatives, speaking on behalf of the government, can characterise it as a burden, I think it should be challenged.

The Australian Democrats are proud to be a political party which is committed to a publicly funded and fair education system for all. Our voting record supports this. Even when the Labor Party chose to sell out students, and education in general, in the 1980s, we retained our opposition to this concept of user pays education, which we believe eventually leads to a system of the privileged having access to education and the meritorious suffering a denial of access. This from a government that touts access and equity at every opportunity!
The duplicity is revealed when we examine further the doublespeak. According to Mr Snowdon:

SPEECH.PARA: The HECS measures in this bill are essential for the government to meet its ongoing commitment to increased access.

How is the government increasing access? Is it doing so by increasing the tax burden on the student body, by condemning the country's future generations to debt so that they begin their non-student life with a massive debt hanging other their careers?

PARA.TAB: As part of our support for education as a life-long process, the Democrats believe that the advent of new learning techniques such as open learning provide opportunities for those groups previously denied access to further education, such as the geographically isolated, the disabled, the socially isolated, the economically disabled—at least the economically disadvantaged. Since the introduction of open learning, the Democrats have argued for a deferred payment for open learning students. While this bill introduces a HECS-style payment mechanism for those open learning students who are studying at a 75 per cent full-time load minimum, we seek to amend that load to decrease the full-time load minimum. There are valid educational reasons for doing so.

The accepted, longstanding validity of the approach that has been adopted by well established institutes that provide distance education has been that an over-commitment in the early phases is not recommended; that an introduction at a level which is able to determine the students' commitment and ability is by far the most economical way to approach it. That sort of approach does not force dropouts from overload. It does not force people to engage in two or three course units and then eventually find they are unable to meet the learning requirements, at great expense to the institution.

With a number of students committing themselves to several units of study, there is the consequent administrative and infrastructural commitment that is required from the institution. It is no different from open learning. I would have thought that the conventional wisdom that has been well established in distance education could have been followed in this regard. It is amazing that the open learning pattern has been established with a 75 per cent load minimum.

The Democrats do not support the proposed increases in the rate of HECS repayment from two or three or four per cent to three, four and five per cent respectively and the parallel lowering of the threshold at which students begin to repay their HECS debt from $27,748 down to $26,402. This is occurring at a time when graduate starting salaries are at a 16-year low and we have incredible unemployment figures for graduates. The government has chosen to implement these measures which have little support from academic or student groups. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee opposes these sorts of measures from the educational perspective. They are punitive; there is no validity from an educational perspective in following these measures.

Other opposition is well documented. An increasing and comprehensive number of submissions have been sent to the Senate standing committee and to my colleagues. We have had all the available techniques of expressing opposition taken advantage of. As well as that, almost every sitting day since the budget I have tabled in this place a petition opposing the HECS increases; the cumulative total is well over 5,000 signatures from people who oppose these HECS changes. These petitions should have woken the government out of its user pays thoughts. They should have reminded the government that education is a right; it is not a privilege, and that these reforms are unfair and regressive.

Whatever it was that provoked and consolidated the coalition's position on this issue, it is pleasing to see that it has occurred. I do not know whether it was the petitions or the contact from the vested interests in this area; whatever it was, I am pleased to see that it has happened.

The other problem associated with this was revealed at the Senate standing committee hearing into this bill. It concerned the further deregulation of the postgraduate sector in this year's budget. Postgraduate course fees are already as high as $33,000 at some institutions. Inadequate research funding, which was revealed at yet another hearing by the same standing committee, exposes the fraud of the government's commitment to research for a clever country.

As I pointed out this week in this place by way of a notice of motion, there is no assurance of quality control for postgraduate fee-paying courses, nor is there any pattern in fee paying arrangements. The Australian Democrats support calls by the Council of Postgraduate Associations of Australia which calls for stronger guidelines to accompany this further deregulation. The other end of the spectrum of this bill reveals a questioning that we should apply to the government's commitment to the provision of quality education at a secondary and primary level.

I turn to the State Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1993. There is a contentious issue in relation to this bill which deserves much greater consideration than is allowed by the time we have for debate. The issue of broad banding the country areas in the disadvantaged schools program has been an area of interest during the lead-up to this debate. It is not hard to see why there has been confusion. The country areas program and the disadvantaged schools project play a fundamental role in ensuring that schoolchildren are not educationally disadvantaged by their geographical isolation, by their low socioeconomic status or by any other disadvantages.

We strongly support these programs but accept that there is room for improvement in certain areas. That was the subject of much of our questioning at the committee's hearing into these programs. We are committed to the continuation and the strengthening of the country areas program for schools. The Democrats supported the dissenting report which was written by the committee of inquiry. Having supported that, we followed the arguments that we had put at that stage to ensure that the problems that had been identified were explained and rectified. At that stage, as far as I could see, the coalition accepted that its role had finished. After the signing of the dissenting report, the minority report, we saw no movement from those others who had identified problems.

I investigated the claims which were made by the department and by the parents who were involved. The community was rightly concerned. As a result of that persistence, I have been assured that participation and consultation in this program will not be lessened. I thank the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, Senator Boswell, for a copy of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training report on the country areas program. Those who were interested in this area, myself included, were already aware of that report. That report was commissioned quite a few years ago. In fact, this very report provided the stimulus for the changes that we see before us today. I am sure that Senator Boswell is aware of that fact, given that he went to so much trouble providing me with a copy of the report. I would have thought it would be quite evident that that report was the initiator of these changes.

I am particularly glad to see that a growing number of agreements are being signed between state governments and the Commonwealth government. I will examine one at random, namely, the agreement between the Commonwealth of Australia and the Northern Territory government. On examination, it reveals at schedule 2, page 20, that country areas program schools will be identified; that there is a provision for allocation to country area schools; that this is defined well and truly within this agreement; and that there is an index for identifying disadvantaged schools programs.

This is a comprehensive document. These agreements cover the Northern Territory Government, the Queensland Catholic Education Commission, other state government bodies and education providers. Anyone who reads them will, I think, see that fears of any threat to the country areas program have been resolved and that these commitments have been signed. I am assured that the matters that were of concern to us at the time of the committee inquiry have now been addressed. For that reason we support that aspect of that bill. We have many other concerns which we will address during the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the State Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1993 and the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. As Senator Bell indicated, one wonders why we are debating these bills cognately as they have absolutely nothing to do with each other.

PARA.TAB: I will start with the bill that Senator Bell finished with, which is the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1993. The main purpose of that bill is to implement a national equity program for schools. When this idea was first floated, I was initially quite attracted to it. I thought that rolling funding into a broadbanding approach would provide flexibility in the system. I was also attracted to it because it seemed to provide the states with far more flexibility in the way in which they were using their money.

But it was not long before it was drawn to my attention personally, and also through the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, that there were considerable problems with this approach. The Senate will hear from me, as it has heard from others, of problems on the CAP side—the country areas program. There are also programs coming from the other side.

The authorities of an excellent school by the name of Hopetown in Wyong, near my home town, which I visited with the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley), expressed considerable concern that this arrangement would be so flexible that the school would lose its funding. Even though there is a temporary stay on this in that it is not being applied for a year, I am aware that considerable concern is being expressed by people connected with the disadvantaged schools. I want to focus mainly on the concerns of people in the country areas program. Although CAP is a very successful program, it appears that the government is yet again interfering with a very successful arrangement. There is a great saying in politics that if it is not broken, do not fix it. But here we see the government meddling, yet again, in an extremely successful program.

In 1990, a review of CAP recommended that, in view of the widespread success which CAP has had to date in promoting positive attitudes towards schooling and in light of the new demand being placed on rural schools, funding should be increased for this program. The great danger of broadbanding, particularly if the government wants to find some extra money for its disadvantaged schools, is that it will drain it away from CAP. That is not to say there should not be extra money for disadvantaged schools, certainly there should be, but it should not be at the expense of this CAP program.

A unique feature of CAP which the government is endangering is the cooperative arrangements that exist in many areas between parents, teachers and the community. They have brought about some excellent innovative approaches when they have applied for CAP funding for special projects. Cooperative arrangements have been put in place in different country areas between different types of schools. In many areas intersystemic, Catholic, independent and government schools are working together in isolated areas on particular programs.

The programs that have been developed in these isolated areas have provided these children with a very wide range of educational, social, cultural and recreational experiences that are not available locally. These are now under threat because of the uncertainty created by this program.
This aspect is perhaps best summed up by Mr Swales from the Isolated Children/Parents Association. In praising what CAP is doing, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: This covers the whole area of sporting contact and social contact, as well as simply seeing what a musical instrument looks like, let alone the ability to see an orchestra.

Those of us who live in urban areas take the facilities that are available in urban areas completely for granted. Those of us who live in cities take for granted the fact that we can go to opera houses and attend concerts. It is a bit hard for us to realise that in these isolated areas they do not even get to see musical instruments unless special provision is made for this in programs like CAP. For that reason, it should not be put under threat.

PARA.TAB: The proposals in this legislation are putting it under threat. This concern was raised by many of the witnesses before the Senate standing committee. DEET representatives also appeared before us at that committee. Their arguments for trying to change these arrangements were not very convincing. They said that DEET would reduce administrative costs, that a rolling triennium will allow better planning and that the pooling of funds will allow greater flexibility. But when we listened to the community, we found that such claims were refuted. I will quote one comment made to the committee by the president of the Country Areas Association to the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: I have seen or been told of absolutely no evidence that linking CAP and DSP was a suggestion of any CAP community member.

These sorts of innovations have certainly not come from the people in the community. It is just another scheme that has been dreamed up by DEET. It looks superficially attractive but has great disadvantages.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to the work of Senator Crane, who joined me on this committee, as well as Senator Bell, in writing the dissenting report. We saw the dangers that this change would make to CAP and, therefore, to isolated children. In our dissenting report, we found that the funding of CAP was vulnerable to erosion and that DSP and CAP are very disparate in their aims and therefore should not be linked in this way. The students affected by CAP and DSP are also quite disparate, with only a nine per cent overlap between the two groups.

We also found that if such a bill were introduced, it would make one of the great innovations of CAP—the clustering of schools in a cooperative arrangement—very difficult. Dr Lloyd of the Country Areas Association said in his submission to the committee that the result of such a change in legislation would be a total undermining of the cluster system, which is fundamental to CAP right across the nation.

The program which is suggested by the government in this legislation will break funding into government and non-government streams. It will particularly disadvantage the smaller schools. There is already evidence of proposals that money originally intended for CAP is to be drifted away to the DSP.

We feel, and this was the conclusion of our dissenting report on this matter, that the status quo needs to be maintained for the country areas program. It is an extremely successful program. It is not broken so it should not be fixed. People whose funding is now in danger should have that funding secured for such a worthwhile approach.

The second bill being debated cognately is the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill. There are a number of aspects of this bill that are important, but I will concentrate my remarks in the limited time I have available to the proposal for the doubling of HECS.

It is interesting that in the time I spent before the election debating education around the country on various campuses and listening to ministers and leading backbenchers from the government, I did not hear one reference to the doubling of HECS. That was only eight or nine months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the doubling of HECS.
—What is it then?
—It is not doubling the rate of HECS.

—What does it do to the payments of students? I cannot recall at any time before the election the government's saying that it would increase these fees for HECS. Members of the government went about the country bashing the opposition over the head for what we were proposing to do with various things. It did not mention that it was going to increase anything. I cannot recall the government saying that it would put anything up for students. Throughout the Labor election campaign we found deception and lies. In this area we have found more deception and lies. We certainly would not have introduced such a proposal because it is unfair and extremely inequitable.

PARA.TAB: By looking at the number of government senators in the chamber, we can tell that they are impressed with this measure! Senator Burns is the only government senator present. Where are the Labor speakers on this bill? There is no-one here supporting the minister. The minister should look at the speakers' list. The opposition has had all the speakers on this bill and the government has not even had one. Government senators would not be game to speak on this bill and then go out into the student community. The government has been very deceiving and has misled the students. Let me assure the government that, as we approach the next election, the opposition will be reminding the students of the duplicity of this government.

I will return to some of the specific criticisms of the bill in the limited time that I have left. One of the most frequent criticisms of this proposal is that students who are often very poorly off financially and who decide to undertake a second degree to improve their qualifications now find themselves facing a double HECS arrangement. When they started they were only aware that they had to pay single HECS.

Ken Fowlie was a great supporter of the Labor Party before the election. I wonder if he is now. I used to debate this matter with him on radio around the country. He is a great advocate for the government but he is not too impressed with what the government has done in relation to this matter. He said in evidence to the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: Anecdotally, as we understand it at this stage, there are some people who will seriously consider not completing their qualifications as they do not believe they are financially in a position to be able to meet the new requirements.

To a government that touts itself as the government of social justice, access and equity, we must point out what it is doing to some of the most disadvantaged people in this community. For the sake of $10 million a year the government is taking money away from some of the most disadvantaged people in this community.

PARA.TAB: Not even Senator Zakharov, the Chairman of the committee, has come down to defend the government on this one. She was here earlier but she has now left. I was going to invite her to speak on this matter and get her to defend double HECS. As a matter of fact, Senator Zakharov let slip during the hearings that she was opposed to HECS. That is on the record. I said to Senator Zakharov, `If you are opposed to HECS, you must obviously be opposed to double HECS.' I do not think she has changed her mind on this matter. She should come in here and defend HECS. We would be interested in listening to her contribution on that matter.

Let us look at what the Labor Party has done to other people with regard to social justice, access and equity. Let us take the people who have come from overseas. They have obtained their initial qualifications at no expense to the Australian taxpayer. They come in and they find that they have to pay double HECS. They would pay double HECS if they admitted they had a degree from overseas. How would we know? People could have a degree from the University of the Ukraine, but unless they tell us that we would not know. The people who are more deceptive and sneaky will avoid double HECS and the honest ones will pay it. I do not think the government is setting up a particularly good principle there.

The former Prime Minister said that we were trying to become the clever country. Yet this whole measure works against the notion of lifelong learning, where people return to upgrade their skill. If the nature of their job has changed they may have an opportunity to retrain in some other area. They might have started with a general degree and they might choose to go back and do a degree in social work.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the person who gets a second degree in the form of a masters degree at Sydney University.
—Senator Bell has raised an example. There are many examples to show how unfair and inequitable this is. In evidence to the committee, Professor Hall said:

SPEECH.PARA: These people are repaying the debt, often concurrently while they are trying to retrain and get their professional qualifications, perhaps holding down a job that is not particularly well paid and trying to maintain a family. We are penalising them.

That is great access and great equity! It was further argued that many who undertook a second degree did not anticipate receiving significant additional income through their employment as a result of that second degree and yet the government whacked them with double HECS.

PARA.TAB: This is an impediment particularly to women who seek to re-enter the work force and retrain, having being absent for perhaps 10 or 20 years. They may want to retrain in a particular profession and the government whacks them with double HECS. We are talking about $4,500 a year and these are often some of the most disadvantaged students. How can they afford to pay that, particularly when it has been put on so suddenly? Professor Hall, of the National Tertiary Education Union, explained it thus and he gave a specific example that summed up very well what I have been saying. At the committee, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the classic example would be a woman who does a Bachelor of Arts degree at age 20-21. She then has a family, comes back into the work force 10 years later and finds that her original qualification is not going to get her a job or that she has now become interested in a professional occupation, such as social work, etc. This legislation will impose a penalty on her to train in a professional area that would be more suitable for her particular skills and talents.

PARA.TAB: Probably one of the most tragic things about this legislation is the way in which it will disadvantage another group. I am talking about people who have suffered some sort of disability. They cannot go and work in the area of their original qualification because of their disability and they have to undertake some other training to work in another area. Double HECS hits these people very hard. It singles out these disadvantaged students. This is an unfair bill; it is an inequitable bill. Yet again we have another piece of legislation from this government for which it has absolutely no mandate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1993. I will confine my comments on this bill to its effect on the priority country area programs, known in Queensland as PCAP. The National and Liberal parties will be supporting an amendment to this bill which disallows the transfer of funding in the equity component of the national equity program between the country areas program and the disadvantaged schools program.

PARA.TAB: The status quo will be maintained without any financial impact. The National and Liberal parties believe that the education needs of country children cannot be met through pooling funds of two quite separate areas of need. It would not be fair to either isolated children or socioeconomically disadvantaged children.

As it now stands, PCAP is providing a much needed and appreciated program for 150,000 country students. Rural families are very concerned that any changes to the PCAP format will deny their children educational opportunities taken for granted in city areas.

The Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training received many submissions from rural communities and country schools urging that PCAP be retained in its present form. The committee's majority report recommended only that it would monitor the operation of the country areas element. This is a bit like yesterday's child-care accreditation debate, where costs will be reviewed so many months down the track. Of course, the horse will have bolted by then. The CAP was reviewed in 1990 by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, which affirmed the value of CAP and recommended an increase in funding of $3.5 million to $15 million, which was implemented. So why change now? Why the backflip?

Many parents are very worried about what will happen in Queensland should this bill go through unamended. The problem is that in Queensland we have a state government intent on purging services from rural areas. Once it got its hands on the PCAP money, it would not be long before some of those funds were syphoned off into the highly populated urban areas to shore up its election support. That is very similar to the Ros Kelly story.

Assurances that the CAP would continue in its present form are only valid for the day they are made. The only legislative safeguard in this bill is that the Commonwealth minister may intervene if a program is compromised. This is little more than window dressing because, once the PCAP infrastructure is dismantled, the government would be most unlikely to recreate it to manage PCAP funding. Hence, there are no effective safeguards that would ensure that the PCAP program would continue in either its present form or with its present level of funding. It would be up to the Premier, and his record on rural services is not pretty.

Country hospitals are facing life threatening shortages of specialists. More than 20 hospitals have been unable to fill positions for anaesthetists. The Royal Flying Doctor Service grant has been cut by $265,000. Julia Creek is to lose its doctor and may not get another. Rural Queensland is desperately in need of at least 100 doctors. Wards have been closed in many country hospitals, such as in Maryborough, Bundaberg, Cairns and Rockhampton.

The Burdekin report concluded that mental health facilities in country communities are almost entirely non-existent. No fewer than 26 court houses have been closed throughout Queensland. Ten railway lines have been closed, five have mothballed and three are to continue conditionally. Rail jobs have been lost in every major provincial town. Meanwhile, freight charges have increased, as have registration fees for heavy farm vehicles.

Over the last three years, the DPI has suffered a 20 per cent cut in its budget. Nine hundred jobs have been cut in primary industries since Goss came to power. This includes 174 jobs in the agricultural branch of the DPI, many of which were stock and meat inspectors, thereby pushing up the costs to primary producers. Research stations have closed, as have DPI offices at Miles, Milmerran and Wandoan, and extension officers have been removed from country towns. There has been an increase in cattle duffing because of the lack of police manpower—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an education bill, Ron; you are talking about DPI.
—I am making a comment. If we give the PCAP funding to Premier Goss, he will misuse it. He has closed down all sections in country towns. That is the allegation that I am making.
—Come on!

—I am suggesting that Premier Goss has a very poor record of standing up for rural Queensland. He has made all these cuts to country towns and rural communities. If he gets his hands on PCAP funding, that will go the way that everything else has gone—
—But, Ron, surely to goodness he will start losing electoral support in the bush. You have a lot of regional seats.

—He does not have any regional seats. I ask Senator Schacht to listen to this and he may learn something. Land rents have increased by several hundred per cent as a result of changes in land categories and increased valuations. New rules for calculating leasehold land rentals have meant increases for many lessees of 500 to 2,000 per cent. Grazing rights have been gradually phased out on national parks. Rural fire services have lost funding and been downgraded. Local ambulance funds have been pooled into a central fund and there are horror stories of increased waiting times for ambulances in rural areas and country towns.

PARA.TAB: So the state Labor government is on the record for fund pooling and then discriminating in its distribution. This is the government which would be put in charge of the future of the priority country area program. No wonder parents and schools in rural Queensland are so worried. They have already experienced rationalisation and closure of small schools.

The breakdown of the education department's compulsory transfer scheme has led to a crisis in country schools. Many country school principals have been either moved or sacked. The relocation of regional education offices has resulted in lost jobs and downgrading of centres. Funds for rural school libraries have been cut. School inspector positions have been abolished. Rural TAFE projects have been cut.

These are the people whom Senator Bell wants to trust. I say to Senator Bell that, if that is their record, he would not want to buy a used car off them. The children of rural Queensland have suffered enough. If the Goss government were to administer a combined PCAP and disadvantage schools program, it would not be very long before rural children suffered some more. PCAP gives geographically isolated children a taste of opportunities that would be regarded as normal, even in low socioeconomic schools, such as tuition in music, dance, art and competitive sport.

PCAP attempts to close the gap between rural and metropolitan schools in terms of social, artistic and educational development. The federal government's willingness to subsume this program within another is evidence that it does not understand or does not care that the needs of geographically isolated children are different from schools classified as socioeconomically disadvantaged. Rural students suffer from a lack of access.
I would like to read to Senator Bell and Senator Schacht some letters that I have received from women in the bush. Kim McKelvie from Boulia wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: PCAP should be kept separate at Federal level and not put in the same bucket. Once it is in the same bucket (with DSP) the same scenario will occur, the bush kids will get rolled by the numbers—
We have heard that story before—

Our kids will be much poorer. We are 3 hours from the nearest town and it (PCAP) fills the gap. It helps with fuel costs for 7 vehicles, with 20 children in those 7 vehicles to travel to Mt Isa for one week a year where they spend 2 hours per day at the Police Youth Club doing gymnastics and 2 hours per day on swimming coaching. A lot of the kids here have no water to learn to swim in. The parents can't afford to drive the kids themselves.
Lindy Williams from Augathella wrote:
It gets things for our children where other children take for granted. Subsidised travel would have to be biggest benefit, getting away from the isolation.
Sue Carmichael from Augathella wrote:

PCAP is a terrific program; we were involved in meetings earlier this year and all voted for it to stay the same. A music teacher comes once a week and trains the children. The swimming club has benefited, PCAP has paid for the lights at the pool so children can learn to swim at night and not during the heat of the day.
I wonder whether Senator Bell is being misled by the sort of information his is getting. Judy Makim from Julia Creek wrote:

PCAP has definitely enabled our children to access things they would never have otherwise experienced. There was a swimming camp in Julia Ck for Normanton children. None of our kids would have a chance without PCAP. Our generation had nothing like this and found it very difficult to go away from the bush, to go to boarding school, to make their way. This (PCAP) sets them in good stead.
Pip Hacon from Georgina River wrote:

The local community here, Georgina River, covers 350 km in diameter and we have a Georgina River Activity Group which meets once a month. Everyone is invited, the number of children vary from 16 to 22 or 25. PCAP provides the paint, paper and brushes. It has been going for five years now and has really expanded . . . PCAP also paid for sporting equipment . . . it has really become a community thing, all the fathers come along and watch the kids play. The flying padre comes along and has a service with the children. We rotate with the other properties.

I would not like to see it change from community based to being run by the Department of Education, it would be a numbers game. It was originally set up to allow isolated children to access programs. It is an excellent program.

PARA.TAB: These are words of high praise indeed from people who have known so little of community life, so little of service on tap, down the road or a bus stop away. A recent survey of its members by the cattlemen's union showed that 33 per cent of families with children doing correspondence education were having trouble, due mainly to the property and off-farm work commitments of their parents made necessary by the drought; 66 per cent of families with children in boarding schools were experiencing difficulty meeting costs; and grade 10 students were being withdrawn with very little likelihood of going back to school. If they are the prospects in the cattle industry, I wonder how bad it would be in the wool industry. Under circumstances like these, how can any government put at risk the little that PCAP provides to these people, which is so much appreciated?

I have another two or three pages which were given to me when the Democrats did their backflip, but I do not think Christmas is the time for me to attack them. However, I will say that I am terribly disappointed in the Democrats. They actually signed a minority report with the National Party and Liberal senators and then moved away from that position because they believed they had some assurance from the government. They have been told that some of the programs are shonky. I am not saying that every program is perfect, but I do not believe that you throw out the baby with the bathwater just because something is wrong; you fix up the problem.

Anyhow, the Democrats have followed that course. I think it is a very bad course to follow. I am surprised that Senator Bell, who is well-known for his stance on education, would support the government. The Democrats are now getting very close to the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you keep attacking them, Ron.

—I am not attacking them; I am merely making a statement. I am saying that the Democrats, if they want to maintain their independence, have to start looking at things themselves instead of getting briefed all the time by the government. Senator Bell is capable. He has a constituency in Tasmania. His colleague Senator Kernot has a big rural constituency in Queensland. They should go out and talk to their constituents and find out what they want. I have just read three or four letters from women who wrote to me.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell and Senator Kernot, for their information get a briefing from the government on every issue that comes up. It is not in the interests of their constituents. The Democrats are getting fed a government line. That is not what they are here for. They are here to represent the bush kids and the bush people of Tasmania and Queensland and other states. This not only relates to education funding; it relates to many things that come across this parliament. The Democrats makes a stand and then go in and get fed a line by the government. The government comes in and briefs them, pulls a few experts, feeds the Democrats the government line and they fall for it every time.

The Democrats are not representing their constituents in the way that they should. Senator Bell is probably overloaded with work because there are only small numbers of Democrats. He is getting his feedback from the government rather than going out and listening to people such as those women who wrote to me. I cannot run the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been to Augathella to interview them personally?
—I have been to Augathella many times.
—Have you been to Ringarooma?
—No I have not been to Ringarooma. But after giving my little homily to the Democrats, I hope they straighten up and fly right and see the light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is five minutes to go to the order that we adjourn at 12 o'clock. My intention is to make a couple of remarks to conclude the second reading debate and then we will pass a resolution to adjourn until 9 o'clock tomorrow morning. I am not sure whether this bill will come back on at 9 o'clock tomorrow, or what the whips will decide before then; it is in their hands.

PARA.TAB: In view of the fact that I have been here for an hour and a half listening to the debate, and that I have now read the folder, I have made the big sacrifice to volunteer to take this bill through the committee stage. It will be easier for the opposition and the Democrats to have their questions responded to by someone who is not going to come in cold as I did an hour and a half ago.

I will deal with the specific points raised by Senator Teague, Senator Tierney, Senator Boswell and Senator Bell in the committee stage tomorrow. There are just a couple of general remarks I want to make, particularly relating to Senator Boswell's remarks about the operation of the broadbanding of the two schemes as it affects Queensland. It is a rather long bow that Senator Boswell has drawn to express concern that the so-called decline in rural services in Queensland by the Goss government means that the broadbanding in this bill will allow a further decline in rural services generally in Queensland.I do not have the information to either accept or reject his remarks about the provision of services in Queensland in rural towns, but I assure him that, as I understand it, the broadbanding provisions are a very genuine attempt to give flexibility to both the public and private schools, to provide where the need really is.

I would have thought that the private schools, which are not controlled by Mr Goss or the Queensland government, will make their own judgments about where the need is for their students. With my knowledge of rural Australia—and I did grow up in rural Australia—I would have thought that overwhelmingly the socio-economically disadvantaged areas of Australia are as Senator

SPEECH.PARA: Boswell described—in rural Australia, outback Australia, remote Australia.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the senate standing committee dealt with this issue in its recommendations and has raised queries. As Senator Boswell has admitted, some of the schemes, such as the PCAP scheme, as he called it, in Queensland, may not have been the most targeted in the provision of education services and therefore has led to some criticism. It is a bit hard to blame the Goss government in Queensland for the so-called decline in rural services. The same thing is happening in other states. They all now—unfortunately, from my point of view—have Liberal-National Party coalition governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that tell you something?
—That tells me that a cycle has gone round and the political wheel of fortune has turned in those states.
—A pretty big cycle.

—Yes. Unfortunately for Senator Teague, the cycle did not turn here in March.
